621. one purpose of the change	was to attain sympathetic enforcement of rights insured by the civil	war amendments against state interference.	4.004373041610021
622. serious difficulty arose	with the advent of substantive due process.	6.468577852425639
623. an amendment presumably	designed to deal with the problems of newly freed slaves became	a laissez-faire limitation upon state economic policy.	4.4341303785436015
624. a flood	of federal lower court injunctions seriously impeded the processes of	local government.	5.535226767350575
625. congress reacted with a series of measures modifying	in various ways what it had granted in 1875.	4.410088766172394
626. in 1910 it required the	convening of a special three-judge court for the issuance of certain	injunctions and allowed direct appeals to the supreme court.	5.27246580695102
627. such	legislation was clarified and extended from time to time thereafter.	4.897882050461599
628. in 1913 an abortive provision was made for the stay of federal injunction	proceedings upon institution of state court test cases.	5.3144085177430815
629. the essential	ineffectiveness of these measures resulted in 1934 in substantial	elimination of federal jurisdiction to enjoin state public utility rate	orders.	3.3564185518874785
630. three years later similar restraints were imposed upon injunctions	against collection of state taxes.	6.141906145129495
631. this saved for state adjudication	in the first instance the two major areas where federal injunctions	had been most obnoxious but other areas remained vulnerable.	3.6108167654478756
632. meanwhile the supreme court like congress showed misgivings	concerning this aspect of government by injunction.	6.568981968790729
633. drawing upon	the traditional discretion of the chancellor mr justice holmes	introduced a series of self-imposed judicial restraints that culminated	in mr justice frankfurter's famous doctrine of abstention.	3.657549779129475
634. whereas the earlier cases turned rather narrowly upon the availability	of adequate state remedies the new emphasis is upon the nature of	the state policy at issue.	4.841422763990498
635. the classic case is railroad commission	v pullman.	4.354479797981038
636. the commission had issued an administrative order	which was challenged as discriminatory against negroes.	5.2985701027307845
637. its enforcement	was enjoined by a federal trial court.	5.204466881930977
638. on review the supreme	court via mr justice frankfurter found southern racial problems	a sensitive area of social policy on which the federal courts ought	not to enter unless no alternative to h adjudication is open.	4.922018221417464
639. an alternative was found in the vagueness of state law as to whether	the offending order had in fact been authorized.	4.084862785309283
640. reluctant as usual	to interpret state legislation- such interpretation can only be	a forecast rather than a determination- mr justice frankfurter	led a unanimous court to vacate the injunction.	4.844563087860651
641. but it is crucial	that here unlike burford the trial court was ordered to retain	the case until the state courts had had a reasonable opportunity	to settle the state-law question.	3.857355177274152
642. the resources of equity are equal	to an adjustment that will avoid the waste of a tentative decision as	well as the friction of a premature constitutional adjudication.	4.468233567801373
643. temporary abstention ie postponement is one thing;	refusal to adjudicate is another.	4.182602481535312
644. to the extent that the jurisdictional	principle of 1875 stands unmodified by subsequent legislation federal	equitable relief against state action must be available- or so	it seems to mr justice frankfurter.	5.0740945127194
645. in alabama public service	commission v southern ry co the commission had	refused to permit abandonment of certain uneconomic train facilities.	3.690916712779116
646. the railroad claiming deprivation of property without due process	of law sought injunctive relief.	4.983105429684655
647. the court held that federal	jurisdiction should not be exercised lest the domestic policy of the state	be obstructed; this in the name of equitable discretion.	4.379928626102767
648. justices frankfurter and jackson concurred in the court's result	for they found no merit in the railroad's claim.	5.057556181613073
649. but they objected	vigorously to the proposition that federal courts may refuse to exercise	jurisdiction conferred in a valid act of congress:   by	one fell swoop the court now finds that congress indulged in needless	legislation in the acts of 1910 1913 1925 1934 and 1937.	3.2704015338175343
650. by	these measures congress so the court in effect now decides gave	not only needless but inadequate relief since it now appears that	the federal courts have inherent power to sterilize the act of 1875 against	all proceedings challenging local regulation.	4.390696933173071
651. a most	revealing recent case is textile workers union v lincoln	mills.	4.274675675810666
652. the taft-hartley act gave the federal courts jurisdiction	over suits for violation of contracts between an employer and a	labor organization representing employees in an industry affecting commerce.	4.471452536462726
653. on its face this merely provides a federal forum; it does	not establish any law for the federal judges to enforce.	3.8208840328256377
654. how	can judges exercise jurisdiction to enforce national rights when congress	has created none?	5.583228874976599
655.  the court held that congress had intended	the federal judiciary to fashion an appropriate law of labor-management	contracts.	3.890478470182828
656. in short congressional power to grant federal-question	authority to federal courts is now apparently so broad that congress	need not create or specify the right to be enforced.	5.244061430894506
657. the lincoln mills decision authorizes a whole new body of federal	common law which as mr justice frankfurter pointed out	in dissent leads to one of the following incongruities:	conflict in federal and state court interpretations of collective	bargaining agreements; displacement of state law by federal law	in state courts h in all actions regarding collective bargaining agreements;	or exclusion of state court jurisdiction over these matters.	3.1772179152489293
658. the justice's elaborate examination of the legislative history	of the provision in question suggests that congress' purpose	was merely to make unions suable.	4.524741011976274
659. with a few exceptions the lawmakers	seemed unaware of the technical problems of federal jurisdiction	involved- to say nothing of the delegation of lawmaking power to judges.	3.972001874593957
660. to avoid these constitutional difficulties mr justice frankfurter	was prepared to read the taft-hartley provision as concerned	with diversity rather than federal question jurisdiction.	5.3151701664521775
661. this	would satisfy what presumably was congress' major purpose- the suability	of unions.	4.182602481535312
662. it would also leave intact the states' traditional	authority in the realm of contract law.	6.845355387181852
663. and york decisions require federal courts in diversity cases	here again mr justice frankfurter	could not lightly accept the principle of wholesale judicial	legislation.	3.919459072011152
664. if congress wants to displace the states from areas	which they have customarily occupied let it do so knowingly and explicitly.	5.173879420231093
665. and let it do its own lawmaking and not leave that to federal	judges.	4.301089977027382
666. does lincoln mills suggest that if congress granted jurisdiction	over interstate divorce cases the federal courts would be	authorized to fashion a national law for the dissolution of marriages?	5.007239766691812
667. 	there is a common problem behind most of these federal question	and diversity cases.	4.402207777559681
668. congress has not clearly defined the bounds	between state and federal court competence.	6.425145942386993
669. it has the power to do	so but for the most part has left the matter for solution by judges on	a case-by-case basis.	4.84720636297895
670. a careful student has suggested that in any	new revision of the judicial code the legislators would do well	to remember that the allocation of power to the federal courts should	be limited to those matters in which their expertise in federal law	might be used leaving to the state judiciaries the primary obligation	of pronouncing state law.	4.417696050629847
671. obviously the goal here proposed is the	guiding principle in mr justice frankfurter's opinions- to	the extent that congress leaves the problem to judicial discretion.	3.6599163583827736
672. the same rule of specialization and division of labor guides him in	the fela certiorari cases in the administrative law area	and indeed in the whole realm of judicial review.	4.984393811368753
673. mr justice black	no doubt concurs in principle but is more apt to make exceptions to	achieve a generous and just result.	3.6965290980494823
674. he will not be fooled	by technicalities.	11.373605720290406
675. with few	exceptions congress has not given federal courts exclusive authority	to enforce rights arising under federal law.	4.050683709456662
676. to put it differently	state and federal courts have concurrent jurisdiction with respect	to most claims of federal right.	5.629284258863525
677. to insure uniformity in the meaning	of national law however state interpretations are subject to supreme	court review.	3.95272066132585
678. it may be noted parenthetically that to evade	desegregation	an ex-justice and former southern governor has urged	congress to abolish this reviewing authority.	5.577681994023852
679. the result of course	would be that federal law inevitably would mean different things in	different states.	4.251817665900261
680. it would also probably mean different things within	the same state- depending upon what court rendered	decision.	6.096703756772545
681. we consider here only a few of many problems involved	in this crucial federal-state relationship.	5.192084450576278
682. the first is that enforcement	of national law in state litigation raises in reverse the old	diversity puzzle of the relation of procedure to substance.	4.882918175514113
683. subject to	certain constitutional restraints in favor of fair trials each level	of government is free to devise its own judicial procedures.	3.8718965743570726
684. litigants	who choose to assert federal claims in a state court go into that	court subject to its rules of procedure.	5.033020485371917
685. a similar canon applies to those	who press state claims in federal tribunals eg in diversity	cases.	3.874048773215712
686. in an fela	controversy the state court followed established state procedure	by construing a vague complaint most strongly against the complainant.	5.397545216976176
687. in other words the burden of pleading clearly rested upon	the pleader by state law.	4.911246959170547
688. the result was that the plaintiff's case	was dismissed.	7.167889196408086
689. mr justice black led a reversing majority: strict	local rules of pleading cannot be used to impose unnecessary burdens	upon rights of recovery authorized by federal law.	3.745969061565264
690. here as	in the byrd case another element of state procedure was subsumed	to federal judge-made law.	5.796124236924885
691. justices frankfurter and jackson dissented:	one state may cherish formalities more than another one	state may be more responsive than another to procedural reforms.	3.467766426174774
692. if	a litigant chooses to enforce a federal right in a state court he	cannot be heard to object if he is treated exactly as are plaintiffs who	press like claims arising under state law with regard to the form	in which the claim must be stated- the particularity for instance	with which a cause of action must be described.	4.492950938337875
693. federal law though invoked	in a state court delimits the federal claim- defines what	gives a right to recovery and what goes to prove it.	3.6051505913638033
694. but the form in	which the claim must be stated need not be different from what the state	exacts in the enforcement of like obligations created by it so long	as a requirement does not add to or diminish the right as defined	by federal law nor burden the realization of this right in the actualities	of litigation.	4.59109421263137
695. another problem in the area of federal-state	relationships is this: what constitutes reversible error in	a state decision?	4.83518907222627
696.  terminiello v chicago involved a conviction	for disorderly conduct under a local ordinance.	5.583228874976599
697. the conduct	in question was a speech.	4.484814815711922
698. the accused did not object to the trial court's	charge to the jury that discourse may constitute a breach of	the peace if it stirs the public to anger invites dispute brings about	a condition of unrest h.	4.4603865584122095
699. for present purposes it may be assumed	that this charge so narrowly limited speech as to violate the federal	constitution.	4.268602696535831
700. though the accused raised many other objections he	did not object on this crucial point at any stage of the proceedings.	5.390360823851988
701. that is he did not claim in any of the four courts through which his	case progressed that the jury charge had denied him any federal right.	4.597643350176966
702. how else can one explain for example allowing the survival of the right	to amortize bond discount and premium but not	the right to amortize bond issue expenses; or allowing a deduction	for payment of certain obligations of a transferor assumed in the reorganization	but not a deduction for theft losses	sustained by a transferor prior to a reorganization but discovered	after it; or requiring a transferor to carry over its method of depeciation	but not allowing rapid amortization of	emergency facilities transferred in a reorganization; or allowing survival	of a dividend carryover to a personal holding company	381 but not carryover of excess tax credits for foreign taxes?	4.083131721283958
703. 	these items and most of the others listed above seem	quite comparable to items whose right of survival is provided for in section	381.	4.048190061295399
704. there does not seem to be any reasonable basis for distinction	either in terms of the nature of the tax attribute or in terms of	tax-avoidance possibilities.	7.843708903535889
705. with respect to items such as these the	provisions of section 381 viewed in historical perspective suggest	a rule requiring survival whether the items are beneficial or detrimental	to the surviving corporation.	3.635545912373673
706. to this extent some stretching	of the literal meaning of the committee report seems justified since	the literal meaning conflicts with the clear implication if not the	language of the statute.	5.303778333234471
707. it is not contended that section	381 should prescribe the survival of all of the transferor's tax attributes.	5.012243480412929
708. such an interpretation could not be justified by a construction	of the statute alone; it would certainly violate the intention of	congress as expressed in the committee report; and in at least	one instance involving refund claims it might be contrary to another	provision of the united states code.	5.432008230242809
709. section	203 of the united states code voids an assignment of a claim against	the government unless made after it has been allowed the amount due	has been ascertained and a warrant for its payment has been issued.	3.695531496653318
710. if it were not for judicial development of certain exceptions this	section would prohibit a suit for refund by an acquiring corporation for	taxes paid by a transferor corporation even though the reorganization	meets the requirements of section 381.	5.108286252774374
711. a clearly recognized	exception is a statutory merger or consolidation.	4.43026810195405
712. the leading case	seaboard air line railway v united states held that	the transferee could sue for a refund of taxes paid by the transferor	and it has been consistently followed.	4.792388202248253
713. the court said the purpose	of the section was principally to spare the government the embarrassment	and trouble of dealing with several parties one of them a stranger	to the claim and to prevent traffic in claims particularly tenuous	claims against the government.	3.389392238612453
714. neither reason said the court applied	to the case at hand; furthermore congress could not be presumed	to have intended to obstruct mergers approved by the states.	5.42101243529272
715. other	exceptions are assignments for the benefit of creditors corporate dissolutions	transfers by descent or transfers by subrogation.	4.046453970113321
716. exceptions	are often classified as transfers by operation of law.	6.144814417540349
717. a tax-free reorganization not complying with the merger or consolidation	statutes of the states involved is difficult to fit into an operation	of law mold.	3.936996706038057
718. although it is in some ways comparable to	a voluntary sale of assets for cash to which section 203 quite clearly	applies the courts and treasury have held that acquiring corporations	in several types of non-taxable reorganizations may sue for refund	of taxes paid by transferors.	4.977360859233531
719. a recent case in point is mitchell	canneries v united states in which a claim against the government	was transferred first from a corporation to a partnership whose	partners were former stockholders and then to another corporation formed	by the partners.	3.7010383832872678
720. holding the final corporation entitled to sue on	the claim the court cited the seaboard novo trading and roomberg	cases for the proposition that h transfers by operation	of law or in conjunction with changes of corporate structure are not	assignments prohibited by the statute.	4.349111605180708
721. in an earlier case	kingan + co v united states an american corporation	was formed for the purpose of acquiring the stock of a british corporation	in exchange for its own stock and then liquidating the british	corporation.	3.669745674587005
722. the anti-assignment statute was held not to prevent the	american corporation from suing for a refund of taxes paid by the british	corporation.	4.736404456293487
723. the transaction presumably would have qualified under	section 368 as a contractual reorganization followed	by a section 332 liquidation but not under section 368	as a statutory merger of consolidation.	3.1687540627978983
724. the court nevertheless relied	on the seaboard case and also mentioned that the shareholders	of the two corporations were the same.	4.876476442162927
725. in substance said the court	there was no transfer of equitable title.	4.412076471587193
726. the treasury arrives	at substantially the same conclusion but skirts the problem of section	203 of the united states code.	6.4522114109677995
727. revenue ruling 54-17 provides	that if the corporation against which a tax was assessed has since been	liquidated by merger with a successor corporation a claim for refund	should be filed by the successor in the name and on behalf of the	corporation which paid the tax followed by the name of the successor	corporation.	3.514722646516913
728. proper evidence of the liquidation and succession must also	be filed.	6.235063150943504
729. if the succession is a matter of public record certificates	of the secretaries of state or other public officials having custody	of the documents will suffice; if the succession is not of record	all documents relating to such succession properly certified are	required.	3.4925274347855835
730. the former proof seems applicable to a statutory merger	or consolidation the latter to a contractual acquisition.	5.109511617432157
731. the ruling	would not however apply to an acquisition of assets for cash.	3.700289227276755
732. a recent	ruling although rather confusing cites and follows rev rul	54-17.	5.866330554951393
733. the ruling suggests also that it applies to either a statutory	or contractual reorganization.	3.729902546439966
734. hence a successor corporation	in a c reorganization appears entitled to sue for a refund of taxes	paid by the merged corporation despite section 203.	5.017340036258649
735. in a b	reorganization followed by a section 332 liquidation those cases	which hold that section 203 is inapplicable to transfers in liquidation	appear to permit the successor corporation to sue for refund of taxes	paid by the transferor.	3.5451824571043153
736. in fact a cash purchase of a corporation's	stock followed by liquidation might also be an effective way to transfer	a claim for refund if the kimbell-diamond doctrine is not	applied to eliminate the intermediate step.	4.856093225578196
737. as stated in seaboard and numerous other cases the two	primary reasons for the enactment of section 203 of the united states	code were to prevent the government from having to deal with more	than one claimant and to prevent the assignment of meretricious claims	on a contingent-fee basis.	3.805443897702458
738. the cases have allowed transfer of claims	if beneficial ownership is not changed.	5.178943078380889
739. the first reason would never	apply to a reorganization transfer which meets the conditions of section	381 which is the only type presently under discussion.	4.143939176682372
740. section	381 applies only to a transfer by liquidation of a subsidiary	owned to the extent of at least 80 per cent a statutory merger or consolidation	an acquisition of substantially all a corporation's assets	solely in exchange for voting stock or a change of identity form	or place of organization.	4.808370277648574
741. in virtually every case the transferor corporation	is liquidated and its former stockholders either own outright	or have a continuing stock interest in the assets which gave rise	to the tax.	3.588064225900743
742. in these circumstances the possibility of multiple or conflicting	claims is exceedingly remote.	7.125151136964095
743. furthermore in a c reorganization	the continuing interest of stockholders of the corporation	which paid the tax must be greater than is necessary in a statutory merger	to which the statute is clearly inapplicable.	3.4638135315928906
744. nor is it	at all likely that a desperate claim against the government will	be assigned on a contingent-fee basis in the guise of a tax-free reorganization.	5.0336835831256925
745. if the transferor has substantial assets other than the	claim it seems reasonable to assume no corporation would be willing to	acquire all of its properties in the dim hope of collecting a claim	for refund of taxes.	3.581377076566162
746. if such an unlikely transaction were to take place	it would more logically be accomplished by a stock purchase followed	by the prosecution of the claim by the wholly-owned subsidiary followed	by liquidation.	4.85276211468655
747. in the rare case where a corporation's only	substantial asset or its most important one is a claim for refund perhaps	its transfer should not be permitted whether the reorganization	takes the form of a statutory merger or of the acquisition of assets	for stock.	3.677120421822672
748. it appears then that although the matter is not	dealt with in section 381 a successor corporation in a reorganization	of a type specified in section 381 is entitled to sue for refund	of taxes paid by a transferor corporation.	4.943223136903516
749. section 203 of the united	states code has been interpreted as not applying to claims against	the government transferred in tax-free reorganizations.	3.641935767281418
750. the successor	corporations have been held entitled to sue on such claims.	5.335826637227673
751. tax attributes of the transferor	there are certain tax attributes	of a corporation whose nature and effect might depend on the facts	of the particular reorganization involved.	3.69105667323623
752. for example property used	in the trade or business of a transferor corporation as defined	in section 1231 presumably would not retain its special status following	a non-taxable reorganization if it is not so used in the business	of the acquiring corporation.	5.579956380882717
753. the parent of a group filing consolidated	returns might be treated as the same corporation following a reorganization	defined in section 368 but as a different corporation	for this purpose after a tax-free acquisition by another corporation	which had not for example elected to file consolidated returns	with its own subsidiaries.	3.139637245856878
754. similar considerations presumably made	it difficult to prescribe a general rule where the acquired and acquiring	corporations have different methods of accounting	or depreciation.	4.93864050117996
755. other sections	of the 1954 internal revenue code provide for survival of certain of	a transferor's tax attributes following a tax-free reorganization.	3.739010109868995
756. section 362 requires carryover of the transferor corporation's basis	for property transferred and section 1223 provides for tacking on	the transferor's holding period for such property to that of the transferee.	5.088386629096709
757. section 169 permits a person acquiring grain-storage facilities	to elect to continue amortization over a 60-month period.	3.77920257541938
758. however	a similar privilege was not specifically provided in section 168 for	attributes similar to a loss	there may be certain items which are quite similar	to a net operating loss carryover or operating deficit and whose right	to survive a reorganization should perhaps be subject to the conditions	applicable to those items.	4.245643275926462
759. for example suppose another excess profits	tax similar to prior laws is enacted providing for carryover of	excess profits credits.	4.059413287344407
760. this carryover right has a number of things in	common with a net operating loss carryover.	6.260171486704967
761. it is an averaging device	intended to ease the tax burden of fluctuating income; it is a tax	benefit which might be of substantial value to a corporation which expects	to have a high excess profits tax.	3.9478173571938084
762. under the 1939 code this item	was permitted to survive a tax-free reorganization in the stanton	brewery case but only over the dissent of judge learned hand	who wrote the majority opinion in the sansome case a leading case	requiring carryover of earnings and profits in a non-taxable reorganization.	4.416059745238803
763. since this type of item was not in the statute when	section 381 was enacted in 1954 one cannot say with certainty what effect	the enactment of that section should have.	3.9524063733658554
764. with respect to this	type of item one might properly apply the language of the committee	report quoted above which cautions against using section 381 as a	basis for treating other tax attributes not mentioned therein.	4.987784269829134
765. actually there do not presently appear to be items in the statute comparable	to a net operating loss carryover.	4.451378773098925
766. probably the primary reason	for special treatment of a net operating loss carryover is the unique	opportunity it presents for tax avoidance.	5.210153024070426
767. there were two	methods that could have been used for conducting the study within the	resources available: interviews in depth with a few selected	companies and the more limited interrogation of a large number of	companies by means of a mail questionnaire.	4.404815256686396
768. while the method	of interviewing a small number of companies was appealing because of the	opportunity it might have furnished to probe fully the reasons and	circumstances of a company's practices and opinions it also involved	the risk of paying undue attention to the unique and peculiar problems	of just a few individual companies.	4.667948210746442
769. as a result it was decided that	a mail questionnaire sent to a large number of companies would be more	effective in determining the general practices and opinions of	small	firms and in highlighting some of the fundamental and recurring problems	of defense procurement that concern both industry and government.	3.949889497724167
770. it was also hoped that responses to a mail questionnaire would suggest	fruitful inquiries that might be made in subsequent studies of a more	detailed nature.	5.53647529242737
771. it is recognized that a mail questionnaire	has inherent limitations.	5.385302660581431
772. there is the danger that the questions will	mean different things to different respondents.	6.977195634145078
773. simple yes or	no answers do not reveal the different shades of opinion that the	various respondents may have.	3.685338251241182
774. a respondent may want to make alternative	answers because he does not know the precise circumstances assumed	in the question.	6.400366061770748
775. there is also the problem of the respondent's frame	of reference.	6.952536411646172
776. is the respondent making a recommendation for his own	benefit for the benefit of his industry for the benefit of a specific	government department or service for the benefit of the defense	program for the benefit of small business or for the benefit of the	taxpayers?	5.71423267304871
777.    there is also the question of whether the respondent	based his answers on factual information and carefully considered	judgment or whether his answers were casual guesses.	4.417037370040519
778. finally there	is the question of how strongly an expressed opinion is held- whether	it is a firm opinion or one that the respondent favors only slightly	over the alternatives.	5.194111566291157
779. the research team was very mindful of	these dangers and limitations of a mail questionnaire.	3.767201939714623
780. under the circumstances	however the team considered it would provide the most useful	information at this point.	5.87502402992453
781. in the preparation of the questionnaire	the problems noted above were carefully considered and the structure	and phraseology used were designed to minimize the effects of these	limitations.	3.906297360133464
782. the questionnaire was	designed to elicit three types of information: the facts regarding	certain characteristics of the respondents including their experience	with and interest in securing defense business; the actual	selling and buying practices of the respondents; and the attitudes	and opinions of the respondents concerning bidding procedures and	the methods of awarding defense contracts.	4.104890769835029
783. it was hoped that the facts	concerning the characteristics and practices of the respondents would	offer clues to the reasons why they took the positions and made the	recommendations which they did.	3.556369465541301
784. the major sections of the questionnaire	are devoted to the following:	information for classifying respondents	characteristics of defense sales activities	respondents' practices in participating	in advertised bidding for defense business	respondents' practices in participating in	negotiated bidding for defense purposes	respondents' opinions regarding advertised bidding	respondents' opinions regarding	negotiated bidding	respondents' preferences regarding the methods of awarding defense	contracts   the questionnaire	provided a place for the name of the respondent but stated that identification	of the respondent was optional.	4.395403172865091
785. the questionnaire also stated	that in any event all replies would be treated confidentially.	3.865388856439537
786. it is interesting to note that 75 per cent of those who returned the	questionnaire identified themselves.	7.465465753213227
787. the questionnaire	the research team prepared and then revised the questionnaire	over a period of six months.	3.819045104115996
788. in june 1960 an early draft	of the questionnaire along with a cover letter was mailed to fourteen	companies in the state of washington.	6.139359403633505
789. several days after the companies	had received the questionnaire members of the research team contacted	the presidents of eleven of these companies in person or by phone	to discuss any ambiguities or difficulties the addressees might have	experienced in completing the questionnaire.	3.638910031306172
790. this test resulted in	further revisions of the questionnaire.	6.928243302983153
791. the research team was	concerned that responses from firms in the state of washington might	not be typical of those throughout the country or that the results might	be different when no phone or personal follow-up was made.	3.4888815788547545
792. accordingly	another test of the questionaire was made.	7.1094963127735795
793. the revised draft	was mailed in july 1960 to 100 firms throughout the united states.	3.5918083310632283
794. fifty of the 100 firms were selected on a random basis from 3500 names	submitted by member companies of the aerospace industries association	and fifty were selected in a similar manner from	a list of 1500 names compiled by the research team from the thomas	register.	4.5581724439049465
795. the method of compiling the aia and	tr lists will be described later.	3.999489988811217
796. ten days after the questionnaires	were mailed follow-up airmail postcards were sent urging	those companies which had not yet returned their questionnaires to do	so at once.	5.099781937057576
797. twenty-eight returns in all were received.	5.219666477665999
798. the responses	were carefully checked for obvious errors in the answers or for questions	that were apparently not understood by the respondent.	4.675870265133493
799. the cover	letter questionnaire and follow-up postcard were then revised into	final form	of mailing lists	the objective of the study was to determine the	opinions and practices of small firms selling to defense programs.	3.1228519642324772
800. the	firms to receive the questionnaires were selected with this objective	in mind.	6.25382857689881
801. three lists of companies were made and used in the	study.	4.808952092658866
802. the first was a list of fourteen manufacturing companies	located in the state of washington which were personally known to	the research team to be active in defense work.	5.832958424330793
803. the primary consideration	in the compilation of this list was convenience in discussing the	questionnaire with company officers.	3.5539344386360034
804. the second list was derived	from a group of approximately 8000 names supplied to the research	team by the aerospace industries association.	5.459666208873187
805. these names were secured	from member companies by the association from the forty-four sources	listed in appendix f.	4.084236481766257
806. each source selected from its approved	bidders list about 200 firms which it believed to be small businesses	that participated in the production of weapons and weapon support systems.	5.402991052683834
807. where possible the name of an executive was supplied along with	the company name and address.	4.674086385728136
808. the forty-four lists supplied	by the aia member companies were merged and duplicate names were	eliminated.	4.900432726990401
809. there was further elimination of all companies that were	not accompanied by the name of a responsible company executive.	4.82557969794832
810. the	remaining names were then checked against the thomas register list	and duplicate names were removed from the aia lists.	5.401581460413553
811. by these steps the final aia list was reduced from 8000 to 3500.	4.283677846046473
812. the third list was selected by the research team on a random	basis from the thomas register.	5.31153441974541
813. it was compiled as a control sample	to determine if the opinions and practices of companies on the	lists	submitted by the members of the aerospace industries association	were materially different from those of other small firms selling to defense	programs.	3.681226392639841
814. such a difference might have resulted from:	the fact that the aerospace industries association members whose	lists were used did not comprise all firms engaged in defense programs.	5.3557388070455705
815. the fact that companies on the aia lists were already	participating in the defense program because of the manner of their	selection.	4.314672178294789
816. accordingly as in-group they might have different	opinions	and practices than an out-group composed of those companies	not so participating but interested in defense business.	4.963790946898937
817. the fact that aia lists might not have been selected on a random	basis.	4.824578746168095
818. the control sample was selected by taking the bottom	name of each of the two columns of names on each page of the alphabetical	listing of manufacturers in the thomas register.	4.853166071528881
819. if the bottom	name in each column did not have a responsible executive identified	the next name above which identified such a responsible executive was	substituted.	4.15006808260693
820. fifteen hundred names were selected in this fashion.	6.792261177931099
821. mailing the questionnaire	each questionnaire was mailed with a	cover letter addressed personally to the president or other executive	of each firm.	3.5853166747464886
822. the questionnaires were mailed in seattle washington	and sent by regular mail to addresses in the states of idaho montana	oregon and washington.	4.8696390024344725
823. airmail was used for the addresses outside	the pacific northwest.	5.380573745424214
824. each letter contained a postage-prepaid	return envelope by regular mail for addresses in the pacific	northwest and by airmail for those outside the pacific northwest.	4.954127836202233
825. approximately ten days after the questionnaire was mailed a	follow-up	airmail postcard was sent to each of the original names.	4.656089896643281
826. the	first test mailing was made in june 1960.	7.656672186800748
827. the second	test mailing was made in july 1960.	4.64818604601887
828. the final	mailing of the questionnaire was made late in august 1960 to 4900	firms consisting of 3450 from the aia list and 1450 from the	tr list.	4.398528065430878
829. returns received	over 1000 returns were received	within two weeks after the final mailing was made.	3.911034540509635
830. they continued	to arrive until the end of december 1960 by which time a total of	1343 returns were received representing 26.	5.729208983105886
831. 8 per cent of the 5014	questionnaires	sent out.	7.82609221165182
832. fifty-seven returns could not be used because	they were incomplete or received too late to be processed.	5.803907039605092
833. the remaining	1286 returns that were processed came from the categories in table	2.	4.096615103921759
834. each questionnaire was audited	for obvious mistakes and for comments and was identified by a serial	number by the source list from which the company name was selected	and by the geographical location of the company as determined by the postmark	on the return envelope.	4.835350608229893
835. all responses except comments were	numerically coded to permit use of data-processing equipment.	4.437978198919889
836. the codes	were key-punched	into ibm punch cards and verified.	5.650577481330174
837. each return	required three cards and involved key punching 228 digital columns.	4.573656184950225
838. in order to be able to properly relate the data for a single company	each of the three cards comprising the set for each firm was identified	with the appropriate serial number of the respondent.	5.746426361528097
839. the cards were	then processed using standard ibm punch card equipment including	an ibm 650 computer.	3.570845587849075
840. the first step in processing was	to analyze the returns from questions 1 2 and 3 to determine	whether the respondents were large businesses or small businesses in	accordance with the definitions contained in aspr section 1-701.	4.696434978984038
841. the results are shown in table 3.	4.729339608989771
842. the returns from companies classified as large businesses were set aside	and not used because they were not relevant to a study of the opinions	and practices of small firms.	4.942576098676822
843. the second step in processing	was to compare the responses from companies on the aia list with	those from companies on the tr list in order to determine whether	it would be appropriate to merge the responses for the purposes of	the study.	3.4004889237823255
844. the methods and results of this comparative analysis are	described in appendix h.	5.207168246864651
845. it was concluded that it would be appropriate	to process the two groups of responses as a single sample of all	small businesses engaged in or wishing to sell to defense programs.	3.885136108446715
846. in the first place the two groups of firms when combined had characteristics	and practices that were more representative of companies	that were the subject of this study than did the firms from the aia	list alone.	5.091329867255602
847. the vast central valley of california is one of the most	productive agricultural areas in the world.	4.165938584987967
848. during the summer of 1960	it became the setting for a bitter and basic labor-management struggle.	6.38144220936163
849. the contestants in this economic struggle are the agricultural	workers organizing committee of the afl-cio	and the agricultural employers of the state.	3.4069613876257354
850. by virtue of	the legal responsibilities of the department of employment in the	farm placement program we necessarily found ourselves in the middle between	these two forces.	5.981645932316214
851. it is not a pleasant or easy position but one	we have endeavored to maintain.	4.964485158670992
852. we have sought to be strictly neutral	as between the parties but at the same time we have been required	frequently to rule on specific issues or situations as they arose.	5.834080777388598
853. inevitably one side was pleased and the other displeased regardless	of how we ruled.	4.646000573291814
854. often the displeased parties interpreted our decision	as implying favoritism toward the other.	6.29536899014373
855. we have consoled ourselves	with the thought that this is a normal human reaction and is one	of the consequences of any decision in an adversary proceeding.	4.460640551199589
856. it	is disconcerting nevertheless to read in a labor weekly perluss	knuckles down to growers and then to be confronted with a growers'	publication which states perluss recognizes obviously phony and	trumped-up strikes as bona fide.	4.832511733196074
857. for a number of years	there have been sporadic attempts in california to organize farm workers.	4.9043671760521725
858. these attempts met with little sucess for a variety of reasons.	6.907972232134923
859. they were inadequately financed without experienced leadership and	lacked the general support of organized labor as a whole.	4.141764277186588
860. this past	year the pattern has been different: the organizing program had the	full support of the afl-cio which supplied staff and money	to the awoc as well as moral support.	5.198164933244895
861. leadership was experienced	and skillful and financial resources were significant.	4.477601198394805
862. regardless	of where personal sympathies may lie as between the parties failure	to recognize these changed conditions would be to ignore the facts	of life.	5.0609444082818955
863. as a result of these changed conditions the impact	of the organizational effort on agricultural labor-management relations	has been much greater than in the past.	4.306535278791379
864. the awoc has been able	to employ the traditional weapons of labor- the strike and the	picket	line- with considerable success particularly in the area of wages.	4.8542881886067555
865. by the very nature of the situation it is the union which	has been able to select the time and place to bring pressure upon management.	5.143371215832481
866. to date at least the strategy of the awoc has been	selective; that is to say to concentrate on a particular crop or activity	in a particular area at a strategic time rather than any broadside	engagement with management throughout an area or the state.	4.881925416420497
867. primarily we became involved in these disputes because of our referral	obligations under our farm placement program.	3.744109221929566
868. normally because	agricultural labor is not covered by unemployment insurance we would	not expect any issues to arise regarding benefit payments under the trade	dispute provision of the unemployment insurance code although	such a situation is quite within the realm of possibility.	4.589817874203458
869. but the current	issues arose out of the wagner-peyser act concerning referrals	to an establishment where a labor dispute exists and out of public	law 78 and the migrant labor agreement if mexican nationals were	employed at the ranch.	3.7940144723977696
870. most of us remember and think of the wagner-peyser	act in its historical sense as a major milestone in the	development of public placement services.	5.877989075957505
871. infrequently do we think	of it as a living continuing operating control over the system.	4.451357065792638
872. however	when labor disputes arise its provisions come clearly into play.	5.9245075971793435
873. california has accepted the provisions of that act	by enacting into our code a provision that	the state of california accepts the provisions of the	wagner-peyser act h and will observe and comply with the requirements	of that act.	3.1964015653323035
874. with respect to labor disputes the wagner-peyser	act states only   in carrying out the provisions	of this act the secretary is authorized and directed to provide for	the giving of notice of strikes or lock-outs to applicants before they	are referred to employment.	4.723491587993776
875. other provisions of the act empower	the secretary to adopt regulations necessary to carry out its provisions	and he has done so.	4.024580199146585
876. the pertinent regulation for our purposes	is section 602.	5.650577481330174
877. 2 as follows:   referrals in labor	dispute situations.	5.682046289038164
878. no person shall be referred to a position the	filling of which will aid directly or indirectly in filling a job which	is vacant because the former occupant is on strike or is being locked	out in the course of a labor dispute or the filling of which	is an issue in a labor dispute.	4.6305248085622335
879. with respect to positions not covered	by subparagraph of this paragraph any individual may be	referred to a place of employment in which a labor dispute exists provided	he is given written notice of such dispute prior to or at the time	of his referral.	3.5467003379089017
880. in analyzing this regulation let us take	the last sentence first.	6.3182816472690195
881. it permits referrals under certain circumstances	even when there is a labor dispute provided the individual is	given written notice of such a dispute.	4.470458478894249
882. assume for example a situation	where a farm has a packing shed and fields.	6.005928707707263
883. the packing shed workers	go on strike.	4.484814815711922
884. there is no dispute involving fieldwork.	9.278860368731365
885. we concluded	that we may refer workers to the fieldwork	provided we give them written notice of the packing shed dispute.	3.8798556860991007
886. so far no troublesome cases have arisen under this provision.	7.13045210872502
887. it is the first part of the regulation that is currently at issue.	6.109262210152714
888. note that it prohibits referrals under either condition	or condition.	7.06461043021643
889. employer representatives have contended that the secretary	has gone beyond his authority by such a prohibition on the	grounds that the wagner-peyser act requires only written notice to	the prospective worker that a dispute exists.	3.230113137190338
890. the matter	got into the courts this way: one of the early strikes called	by the awoc was at the digiorgio pear orchards in yuba county.	5.553895303222247
891. we found that a labor dispute existed and that the workers had left	their jobs which were then vacant because of the dispute.	4.571935965307797
892. accordingly	under clause of the secretary's regulation we suspended	referrals to the employer.	5.739974350684024
893. the employer seeking to continue his harvest challenged	our right to cease referrals to him and sought relief in the superior	court of yuba county.	3.441727307797516
894. the court issued a temporary restraining	order directing us to resume referrals.	5.661784471302859
895. we of course obeyed the court	order.	5.903741271583776
896. however the attorney general of california at the request	of the secretary of labor sought to have the jurisdiction over	the issue removed to the federal district court on grounds that	it was predominantly a federal issue since the validity of the secretary's	regulation was being challenged.	5.309403777733264
897. however the federal court	held that since the state had accepted the provisions of the wagner-peyser	act into its own code and presumably therefore also the	regulations it was now a state matter.	3.509181689192708
898. it accordingly refused to assume	jurisdiction whereupon the california superior court made the	restraining order permanent.	5.822387324843191
899. under that order we have continued referring	workers to the ranch.	4.945621750837393
900. a similar case arose at the bowers ranch	in butte county and the superior court of that county issued similar	restraining orders.	5.0430757226280996
901. the growers have strenuously argued	that i should have accepted the superior court decisions as conclusive	and issued statewide instructions to our staff to ignore this provision	in the secretary's regulation.	3.1524264895335206
902. i cannot accept that view	either as a lawyer or as an administrator.	6.479213893531513
903. first let us examine briefly some of the legal considerations involved.	5.886976836567446
904. it is an accepted juridical principle in california that a superior	court decision does not constitute a binding legal precedent.	5.529698819939636
905. it	is conclusive unless appealed only upon the particular parties to	the particular action which was heard.	4.12970940785518
906. it is not binding upon another	superior court which could rule to the contrary.	6.382855243222662
907. only when a decision	is rendered by the district court of appeal	is a binding precedent established.	4.179700189433925
908. in that event	we can correctly say that we have received an authoritative interpretation	of the matter and one which we can follow statewide with confidence	that the policy will not be overthrown in other superior courts.	5.296798841417015
909. but over and beyond the compelling need for a binding precedent	decision i am convinced that the decisions of the superior courts	which in effect nullify the secretary's regulation are not a	correct interpretation of the secretary's power under the federal	law.	3.578347160060221
910. i believe i am in good company in this view.	7.037620271278468
911. the attorney general	of california concurs in this interpretation and has filed an appeal	from these decisions to the district court of appeal.	3.3530711693172566
912. the attorney	general of the united states in considering the power of the	secretary to issue similar regulations under the wagner-peyser act	relating to the interstate recruitment of farm workers has rendered	an opinion sustaining his authority.	5.117153883766834
913. further and as an evidence of	legislative intent only the senate of the united states recently	defeated by a substantial majority the holland amendment to the	fair labor standards act which would have specifically limited	the regulatory authority of the secretary in these matters.	3.9521023988570025
914. next	let us consider briefly the program and administrative implications	of a failure on our part to pursue our appeals.	5.396660831725867
915. there is far	too much at stake for all of the parties concerned to leave the matter	hanging in midair.	4.915083511808039
916. the ramifications of the issue are enormous.	5.8743971957932475
917. a	decision to refer workers to jobs vacant because of a strike would have	to be applied equally to nonagricultural situations and might in	effect place the public employment services in the position of acting	as strikebreakers.	3.5795066591703564
918. the public interest is so dominant in such an issue	that i cannot be so presumptuous as to attempt to settle it by an administrative	order based upon conclusions reached in a summary action	in one or two superior courts in the state.	4.581705212756214
919. it is an issue which	may well reach the supreme court of the united states before judicial	finality is achieved.	5.7086759331414685
920. as an administrator i cannot place	the employment service in california in jeopardy of being out of compliance	with the federal laws by my failure to pursue the avenues of	appeal open to me.	4.878816919268261
921. to have applied statewide the decisions of the two	cases heard in superior court in my opinion would have placed us	clearly out of compliance with the wagner-peyser act and would have	immediately opened the way for the secretary of labor were he so	inclined to notify the governor of such noncompliance set a date for	hearing and issue his finding.	3.527716629306207
922. the impact of noncompliance under	the wagner-peyser act is clear: the withdrawal of some $11 million	a year of administrative funds which finance our employment service	program or as a corollary the taking over by the federal government	of its operation.	4.509905776961325
923. thus far the cases which have come before	the courts have involved only the issue of referral where the job is	vacant due to a strike- condition in the regulation of the secretary.	3.4357165697257344
924. none has yet arisen under condition relating to referral	to jobs the filling of which is an issue in a labor dispute.	5.617429765982198
925. here the problem is essentially one of defining the word filling.	5.438472439261005
926. should it be defined in a narrow sense to include only such elements	as job specifications union membership union jurisdiction and	the like?	5.083250441587281
927.  or should it have a broader connotation of including wage	demands and other factors not necessarily associated with the	mechanics of filling the job.	3.6869397080082185
928. because of the uncertainty	of this definition i solicited the interpretation of the secretary	of labor.	6.765182913011023
929. he has advised me that the narrower interpretation is the	proper one; that is that if wages for example is the only issue	in a labor dispute and no workers have left their jobs because of the	dispute we may continue to make referrals.	3.494633108451513
930. martin and stendler present evidence that infants and young	children can and do solve many problems at a relatively simple perceptual	level simply by combining objects and counting them.	4.861821061560637
931. after they	have developed concepts they are free from the necessity of manipulating	objects; they do symbolically what they once had to do concretely.	4.403591078845857
932. the ability to think seems to increase consistently with age.	5.952967917556376
933. one	experiment showed the greatest one-year difference occurring between	the eleventh and twelfth years.	4.0683852436856025
934. many studies indicate that	elementary-school children's interests cover the whole field of science;	that their questions indicate a genuine interest in social processes	and events; and that as they mature their interests and capabilities	change and broaden.	4.605727696363613
935. how a child	feels about himself about other people and about the tasks confronting	him in school may have as much influence on his success in school	as his physical and intellectual characteristics.	3.5493379294442353
936. a considerable amount	of evidence exists to show that an unhappy and insecure child is not	likely to do well in school subjects.	5.278256563308104
937. emotional maturity is the result	of many factors the principal ones being the experiences of the	first few years of the child's life.	3.8485016262063008
938. however the teacher who understands	the influence of emotions on behavior may be highly influential	in helping pupils gain confidence security and satisfaction.	5.487401163814721
939. concerning this responsibility of the teacher suggestions for helping	children gain better control of the emotions are presented in chapter	11.	4.117317582873366
940. the following generalizations about the emotional characteristics	of elementary-school children may be helpful.	5.786486379755926
941. typically	the young child's emotional reactions last for a relatively short	time as contrasted to those of an adult.	4.048715548613717
942. as the child grows	older his emotional reactions lead to moods or emotional states	drawn out over a period of time and expressed slowly rather than in	short abrupt outbursts.	5.7069358557416034
943. studies of the growth and decline	of children's fears indicate that fears due to strange objects noises	falling and unexpected movement decline during the preschool years	but that fears of the dark of being alone and of imaginary creatures	or robbers increase.	3.178958748424949
944. ridiculing a child for being afraid	or forcing him to meet the feared situation alone are poor ways of dealing	with the problem; more effective solutions include explanations	the example of another child or conditioning by associating the feared	object place or person with something pleasant.	4.433255443611828
945. children	need help in learning to control their emotions.	4.6724501027054846
946. the young child	learns from parents and teachers that temper tantrums screaming kicking	and hitting will not get him what he wants; the older child learns	that intense emotional outbursts will not win approval by his peers	and therefore makes a real effort to control his emotions.	4.305387946273037
947. children differ widely in their emotional responses.	4.913686410369733
948. among infants	the patterns of emotional responses are similar; as the influence	of learning and environment are felt emotional behavior becomes individualized.	5.299375092431005
949. although no national norms exist	for the social development of children the teacher can find a great	deal of information concerning types of social behavior normally displayed	by children at various age levels.	3.5409358837834084
950. the following summary will	give the student some idea about the social characteristics of elementary-school	children; the student will certainly want to explore more	deeply into the fascinating study of immature individuals struggling	to meet their developmental needs and at the same time trying to learn	the rules of the game in the ever-expanding number of groups in which	they hold membership.	4.695462395488581
951. during early childhood children	are more interested in the approval of their parents and teachers than	they are in the approval of other children; after they have been in	school a few years their interest in playmates of their own age increases	and their interest in adults decreases; the child who had once	considered it a treat to accompany his parents on picnics and family	gatherings now considers it a bore.	3.7865836031052305
952. in late childhood the influence	of the group on the social behavior of the child continues to increase;	the group sets the styles in clothing the kind of play engaged in	and the ideals of right and wrong behavior.	4.831346288937501
953. in early childhood	the choice of a companion is likely to be for another child of his	own age or a year or two older who can do the things he likes to do;	such factors as sex intelligence and status in the group do not	influence his choice much at this time.	3.664690668177192
954. in later childhood	an interest in team games replaces individual play; loyalty to the group	a feeling of superiority over those who are not members and unwillingness	to play with members of the opposite sex become dominant traits.	5.343343652835193
955. during early childhood boys tease and bully on the average	more than girls; those who feel inferior or insecure engage in	these activities more than do well-adjusted children.	3.669363008493217
956. during	late childhood boys like to tease jostle and talk smart to girls;	girls who are more mature than boys frown upon the youthful antics	of boys of their own age.	4.762306869012796
957. by the time pupils reach the sixth	grade their ethical and moral standards are fairly well developed;	they exhibit a keen interest in social political and economic problems	but they frequently have vague and incorrect notions about the	terms they use rather glibly in their routine school work.	3.4213482205273174
958. between	the ages of two and four years negativism or resistance to adult	authority is noticeable; after the fourth year it begins to decline.	4.781103268798495
959. however as we have seen in later childhood the child begins to	substitute the standards of the peer group for those of parents and teachers.	4.137285232688852
960. the elementary-school child grows gradually in his ability	to work in groups.	5.187735111958531
961. the child in the primary grades can play harmoniously	with one companion but his desire to be first in everything	gets him into trouble when the group gets larger; he wants to be with	people but he hasn't yet learned to cooperate.	3.407738556001332
962. in the middle grades	however he begins to participate more effectively in group activities	such as selecting a leader helping to make plans and carry on	group activities and setting up rules governing the enterprise.	4.972076408971061
963. the teacher should study the individual pupil	much progress has	been made in the last two decades in developing techniques for understanding	children yet in almost any classroom today can be found children	whose needs are not being met by the school program.	3.6435085679124284
964. some are failing	to achieve as much as their ability would permit; others never	seem able to enter fully into the life of the classroom.	6.220821185432304
965. these children	have been described as those who were trying to say something to adults	who did not understand.	3.984800322203241
966. many school systems now employ school	psychologists and child guidance specialists.	6.641940942877285
967. these specialists	perform valuable services by helping teachers learn to identify children	who need special attention by suggesting ways of meeting the needs	of individual children in the regular classroom and by providing clinical	services for severely maladjusted children.	3.4617531228284557
968. it is the classroom	teacher however who has daily contacts with pupils and who is in a	unique position to put sound psychological principles into practice.	5.355161202731254
969. indeed a study of the individual child is an integral part of the work	of the elementary-school teacher rather than merely an additional	chore.	5.011104556602069
970. teachers and administrators in many elementary schools	have assumed that dividing the pupils in any grade into groups on the	basis of test scores solves the problem of meeting the needs of individuals.	5.003825338668009
971. what they should recognize is that children who have been placed	in one of these groups on a narrow academic basis still differ widely	in attributes that influence success and that they still must be	treated as individuals.	3.835889022667651
972. although the teacher must be concerned with	maintaining standards he must also be concerned about understanding	factors that inhibit	studies conducted in various	sections of the united states indicate that many children in elementary	schools are maladjusted emotionally and that many of them are	failing to make satisfactory progress in school subjects.	5.242933230132896
973. one study	which involved 1524 pupils in grades one to six found that 12 percent	of the pupils were seriously maladjusted and that 23 percent were reading	a year below capacity.	3.4673337865341547
974. it is apparent therefore that the teacher	needs to know what factors have a vital bearing on the learning and	adjustment of children.	5.5563516039141545
975. when a child fails to meet the standards of	the school in his rate of learning insecurity unhappiness and other	forms of maladjustment frequently follow.	4.025972827012357
976. these maladjustments in	turn inhibit learning and a vicious cycle is completed.	6.066364874867253
977. it is	easy for the teacher to rationalize that the child who is not achieving	in accordance with his known ability is just plain lazy or that the	child who lacks interest in school who dislikes the teacher or who	is overaggressive is a hopeless delinquent.	3.368237723175595
978. the causes of retardation	and maladjustment may be found in physical factors such as defective	speech or hearing impaired vision faulty motor coordination a frail	constitution chronic disease malnutrition and glandular malfunctioning.	4.659583179454925
979. they may be caused by poor health habits such as faulty eating	and sleeping habits.	4.746008110300879
980. they may be related to mental immaturity or lack	of aptitude for certain types of school work.	6.317364404748039
981. the curriculum may	be too difficult for some and too easy for others.	3.8220924861144594
982. teaching methods	learning materials and promotion policies may inhibit learning and lead	to maladjustments for some children.	5.2693531817812636
983. unwholesome family relations	broken homes and undesirable community influences may also be contributing	factors.	4.46142869435397
984. this is only a minimum list of the factors that inhibit	learning and contribute to maladjustment among children.	6.816641466935386
985. moreover	these conditions do not influence all children in the same manner.	5.387933134909964
986. a	vision handicap that may produce nervous tension and reading	disability	for one child may spur another child on to even greater achievement	in reading.	4.807873378411027
987. an impoverished home that may discourage one child may constitute	the motivation causing another to work harder for successful	achievement in school.	3.701367932436392
988. at any rate the teacher who recognizes common	causes of retardation and maladjustment can frequently do a great deal	to eliminate the causes of pupil discouragement failure and maladjustment.	5.201833887943073
989. successful teaching	involves getting enough information about each pupil to understand	why he behaves as he does in certain situations and how his achievement	in school is being influenced by various factors in his environment.	3.327093690009675
990. the classroom teacher cannot be expected to be as proficient in the	use of the techniques of child study as the clinical psychologist;	he cannot be expected to administer all the tests and gather all the information	needed about each child in his classroom.	4.814454359513155
991. he can be expected	however to examine and interpret the information already available;	to refine and extend his own techniques for studying individual children;	and to utilize opportunities arising in connection with regular	classroom activities for gaining a better understanding of his	pupils.	3.5548878029613884
992. this section deals with some of the sources of information that	can be tapped by the classroom teacher; chapter 15 provides more	detailed information about specific techniques used in evaluating pupil	progress.	5.40048908069017
993. most school systems today maintain	a system of cumulative records of pupils.	4.659276624172286
994. these records when systematically	maintained provide much information about the children which	the teacher can use in guidance instruction grouping and reporting	to parents.	5.3321550398349675
995. each teacher has in his classroom a metal file equipped	with a lock which is used to store cumulative record folders.	4.013228842855323
996. during	summer vacation periods these records are stored in the office of	the principal.	5.7535564091527815
997. only the teacher and other professional personnel are	permitted to see or use these records.	4.501681747676017
998. each new teacher to whom the	pupil goes is expected to study the information in the cumulative record	and to bring it up to date.	5.542071985406273
999. some school systems provide written instructions	to principals and teachers designating when certain information	is to be recorded on cumulative record forms and explaining how	the information is to be summarized and used.	3.6237522783835563
1000. the summary report on desegregation progress in education in	the middle-south region 1959-1960 clearly shows two pieces of	information.	4.705010556909502
1001. the summary report which was prepared for this conference	indicates first that actual or pending school desegregation is	increasing; second that both actual and pending desegregation is	with few exceptions the product or result of court order.	3.1182152175531104
1002. the report	together with other information suggests that desegregation in the	schools is slow.	5.078074081494962
1003. the middle-south region as defined by the	national association of intergroup relations officials	consists of the states of kentucky maryland tennessee west	virginia delaware virginia and the district of columbia.	3.338041037036823
1004. the	states and the nation's capital all have some desegregation in	fact some dating back to 1954; but the region also embraces some of	the staunchest opposition.	4.67288338831304
1005. desegregation has been opposed by massive	resistance interposition pupil assignment	and hate bombings.	4.231197729340223
1006. now let's look at the evidence that shows the increase in desegregation	and such increase as a result of court order.	7.195893523791992
1007. elementary school desegregation came to owen and union counties	which already had high school desegregation.	3.8849121559715263
1008. the action was a result	of a court order the citation for which	is taken from the summary report for this	conference.	4.949366264608476
1009. in maryland the harford county board of education	had prepared a desegregation plan which the court approved but	which a plaintiff had challenged; thus county school board and federal	court joined hands here to promote school desegregation.	3.2555846333207885
1010. additional	school desegregation in tennessee resulted from a court	order opening a school serving children of military personnel.	5.138210239895059
1011. similarly	further desegregation may come from suits pending in three tennessee	cities chattanooga knoxville and memphis.	3.8849121559715263
1012. in west virginia	the number of white and negro children attending the same school	has increased almost twofold.	5.511953053517552
1013. there are no court decisions here.	7.097800126220946
1014. as in maryland a district court has approved an official plan	of school desegregation in delaware.	5.988297558997049
1015. as a result of the state	board of education plan negro children entered heretofore white	elementary schools in five districts.	4.5157557260973755
1016. the third circuit court of	appeals is reviewing an appeal from the plan.	5.559898878383699
1017. in virginia	court orders led to desegregation in charlottesville and floyd counties.	4.372974062082154
1018. desegregation in pulaski county is pending because of court	order although date of admission is not yet determined.	5.215171351768844
1019. negro parents	have filed application for admission of additional children to schools	in alexandria arlington fairfax and warren counties.	3.8078316992707273
1020. desegregation	can also result from additional suits brought by negro plaintiffs	against school boards in newport news fairfax county arlington	county and norfolk.	4.861416487662795
1021. as a school district the district	of columbia has had desegregated schools since 1954 shortly	after the supreme court decision.	4.477336348529096
1022. this recapitulation makes	it clear that school desegregation continues including the old dominion	state in spite of its stern resistance.	5.710732804818812
1023. the record is clear that	increase in school desegregation last year came largely as a result	of a court order; that on the immediate horizon if further large-scale	desegregation comes it will result from court	orders on suits filed in several middle-south states.	3.099464254342051
1024. knowledge	that thousands of school districts are involved and observation that	school desegregation has occurred in only a handful in 1959-1960 leads	to a conclusion that desegregation-from-court-order is slow.	4.683918250208666
1025. before turning to my views as to the problems and issues before us at	this regional conference i wish to note a small item in the summary	report as it refers to the district of columbia.	3.7706963653809518

1027. 1 per cent to 76.	8.545823072995299

1030. nearby foggy bottom is ousting negroes.	7.163184125958424

1036. solve	from the summary report before us at this conference a number	of problems are apparent.	5.331440467598945
1037. they vex us and perplex us but generally	do not divide us like the issues which follow the problems.	3.8661034358684527
1038. first how can we step up the desegregation movement?	7.310020615776629
1039.  it is slow.	8.213217004394902
1040. i believe we all want more schools where white and negro together	can and do attend.	6.163066141825329
1041. i believe we all want no child denied admission to	a school on account of his color.	4.4164138348622775
1042. in general members of nairo	would certainly want a child admitted to a school nearest his residence	or within his residence zone.	5.378334496309659
1043. how to achieve this objective is	a problem but we are not divided on what we want.	5.03157154825566
1044. second as	we increase the number of desegregated school districts and schools themselves	how can we achieve this action through school board action?	5.607636051117295
1045. 	it may be county school board or state school board action as well	as that of municipal school boards.	3.632711015013689
1046. correlatively can we reduce the	role of the district courts so that the action is that of the people	of the community or other school district and not that of the law court?	6.188323860131719
1047. 	this is a problem and i believe there is little difference of	opinion that wherever possible a local school board should devise and	effect a plan of desegregation.	3.9346086831462506
1048. third how can we insure a systematic	and continuing group relations education in the schools?	6.073165079418338
1049.  not	simply a brief program when the schools are actually desegregated but	a continuing program that also promotes integration that encourages	the children and teachers not to look at each other as white or negro	but as human beings.	3.431517499197341
1050. again the problem is how to get it done and	in what form to offer the group relations education; not whether it	should be done.	6.125691157846206
1051. fourth in the segregated school system during	the period before desegregation how can we assure equal opportunity?	3.8636613819693553
1052. 	in fact in the desegregated school system which may have a good	many schools with all-negro population how can we assure equal opportunity?	5.148106107751603
1053. 	this is a problem but we are not divided over its importance	or by its existence.	4.861561810506442
1054. fifth in the segregated school system	or in the all-negro or all-white schools how can we encourage better	group relations or an improved attitude toward people who do not belong	to the group?	4.778131195087601
1055.  can we help children adjust to images of other	children when the latter are not actually present.	4.304451685372834
1056. if we have five problems whose solution we seek in relatively	united fashion then there are twice as many issues which i judge sharply	issue	since on the one hand school	desegregation	has come in virginia hand-in-glove with pupil assignment shall	we support the plan?	4.906477467832826
1057.  on the basis of pupil assignment criteria	judge albert bryan has assigned negro children to formerly white	schools in arlington and alexandria virginia.	4.230470761946717

1062. in large cities	like baltimore louisville and washington dc should school	desegregation be extended to all-negro and all-white schools by	assigning white and negro teachers respectively?	4.976569394374501
1063.  on the one hand	do we argue the supreme court decision required only that a child	not be denied admission to a school on account of his race?	4.229126556537165

1066. the earlier part of my statement deals with the court orders that	resulted in desegregation.	5.235947622867308
1067. in each instance the plaintiff was a private	citizen.	5.597373394503804
1068. in thousands of school districts indeed in the entire	state of mississippi no plaintiff has come forth.	5.469912327414678
1069. and i have established	that the action of municipal county or state school boards	or boards of education is small infinitesimally small in comparison	with the number of districts.	4.282121101368605
1070. is the requirement that the plaintiff be	a person actually denied admission to a school a sound requirement?	6.2109960547937195
1071. 	should congress authorize the attorney general to file suit to accomplish	admission of a child to a school to which he is denied entrance?	4.118693980343359
1072. 	even though in civil rights legislation in 1957 and 1960 the provision	for the attorney general to act was eliminated should we	nevertheless	support such a clause?	4.932362611101299
1073.  this is an issue for it divides	issue no 4.	5.685506387066093
1074. withholding of funds to	schools	that deny children on account of race.	6.136259031619094
1075. which in 1957 divided even a liberal group like the american	veterans committee.	4.5794027334178455
1076. should we support a clause in federal	school construction or school assistance legislation that would	deny federal funds to a school district that denies admission to a	child on account of his race?	4.8052756008117985
1077.  this is softer than earlier powell amendments	which would have denied funds to all segregated school districts.	4.185174572575757
1078. there is nonetheless considerable argument against the clause	softened though it be on the grounds that federal aid is so necessary	to the public schools.	5.522062604531797
1079. the federal funds limitation enlists the support	issue no 5.	4.13722289542765
1080. state or county	or municipality be required to furnish public education?	6.896595224650795
1081.  for the	school year 1959-1960 the prince edward county board	of supervisors voted not to provide funds for public education and	the school board therefore could provide no public education- for white	or negro children.	3.3877246439302837
1082. is public education in this american democracy	of such importance that no child should be denied public education?	5.703038261710981
1083. 	or is this subject a matter of self-determination a matter of states	rights or county rights?	5.004970471906443
1084.  if people don't want to provide public	education should they be forced to do so?	6.47689685497105
1085.  even if we marshal substantial	agreement behind mandatory public education we likely cannot	expect that all the states will enact the legislation.	4.353766724600997
1086. should the	requirement which must therefore be federal in nature be legislated	by the united states congress?	6.64785649674944
1087.  or must it become law by amendment	of the united states constitution?	5.745783773185446
1088.  we actually have two issues	issue no 6.	7.543900632520252
1089. federal	responsibility	if the above issue is settled	by requiring public education for all citizens issue no 6 may	be moot.	3.685338251241182
