1513. the	potters in particular had virtually eschewed freehand drawing elaborate	motifs and the curving lines of nature while yet expressing a	belief that there was order in the universe.	3.4867804025449143
1514. in their vases were embodied	the basic aesthetic and logical characteristics of greek civilization	at first hesitantly in protogeometric work and then more confidently	in the initial stages of the geometric style.	4.870916868870414
1515. by 800 social	and cultural security had been achieved at least on a simple plane;	it was time to take bigger steps to venture on experiments.	3.745172113229767
1516. ripe	geometric potters continued to employ the old syntax of ornaments	and shapes and made use of the well-defined though limited range of	motifs which they had inherited.	5.210834845291727
1517. in these respects the vases of the early	eighth century represent a culmination of earlier lines of progress.	4.047881796609894
1518. to the ancestral lore however new materials were added.	7.384153110503286
1519. painters	left less and less of a vase in a plain dark color; instead they	divided the surface into many bands or covered it by all-over patterns	into which freehand drawing began to creep.	3.352339000993367
1520. wavy lines feather-like	patterns rosettes of indefinitely floral nature birds either singly	or in stylized rows animals in solemn frieze bands-	all these turned up in the more developed fabrics as preliminary	signs that the potters were broadening their gaze.	4.677259010949875
1521. the rows of animals	and birds in particular suggest awareness of oriental animal friezes	transmitted perhaps via syrian silver bowls and textiles but the	specific forms of these rows on local vases and metal products are	nonetheless greek.	3.0736680476013656
1522. though the spread of this type of decoration in the	aegean has not yet been precisely determined it seems to appear first	in the cyclades which were among the leading exporters of pottery	throughout the century.	5.514838230965381
1523. as the material at the command of the	potters grew and the volume of their production increased the local	variations within a common style became more evident.	4.0214467117816115
1524. plate 12 illustrates	four examples which are ripe or late geometric work of common	spirit but of different schools.	5.057556181613073
1525. cook had discovered a beef in his possession a few days earlier and	when he could not show the hide arrested him.	3.9628890065057316
1526. thinking the evidence	insufficient to get a conviction he later released him.	6.489179364434843
1527. even while suffering	the trip to his home cook swore to moore and lane that he	would kill the indian.	4.029440946165766
1528. three weeks later following his recovery	armed with a writ issued by the catskill justice on affidavits prepared	by the district attorney cook and russell rode to arrest martinez.	4.792661693966565
1529. arriving at daybreak they found julio in his corral and demanded	that he surrender.	4.046642206484951
1530. instead he whirled and ran to his house for	a gun forcing them to kill him cook reported.	5.736028134199097
1531. both cook's	and russell's lives were threatened by the mexicans following the	killing but the company officers felt that in the end it would serve	to quiet them despite their immediate emotion.	3.978839148619181
1532. general manager pels	even suggested that it might be wise to keep the mexicans in suspense	rather than accept their offers to sell out and move away and try	to have a few punished.	5.1143983611049375
1533. on february 17 russell and cook	were sent to the pena flor community on the vermejo to see about renting	out ranches the company had purchased.	3.85752953040993
1534. while talking with julian	m beall francisco archuleta and juan marcus appeared both	heavily armed and after watching the house for a while rode away.	5.704641709484443
1535. it was nearly sundown before they finished the business with beall and	began riding down the stream.	4.030960584550162
1536. they had traveled only a short distance	when they spotted five mexicans riding along a horse-trail across	the stream just ahead of them.	5.389114820617789
1537. suspecting an ambush the two deputies	decided to ride up a side canyon taking a short cut into catskill.	3.632711015013689
1538. after spending two nights in catskill	the deputies again headed for the vermejo to finish their business.	5.87386878502588
1539. they stayed with a rancher friday night and by eleven o'clock	saturday morning passed the old garnett lee ranch.	3.8643139165915907
1540. half a mile below	at the mouth of salyer's canyon was an old ranch that the company	had purchased from a j armstrong occupied by a mexican	his wife and an old trapper.	5.108300524120971
1541. there were three houses in salyer's	canyon just at the foot of a low bluff the road winding along the top	entering above and then passing down in front of the houses thence	to the vermejo.	3.89556108685728
1542. to the west of this road was another low bluff forty	or fifty feet high covered with scrub oak and other brush.	5.851288890710507
1543. as they	were riding along this winding road on the bench of land between the	two bluffs a volley of rifle fire suddenly crashed around the two officers.	3.50679684136116
1544. not a bullet touched cook who was nearer the ambush but one	hit russell in the leg and another broke his arm passing on through	his body.	5.1442218019664745
1545. with the first reports russell's horse wheeled	to the right and ran towards the buildings while cook followed by a	hail of bullets raced towards the arroyo of salyer's canyon immediately	in front of him just reaching it as his horse fell.	3.574973373544093
1546. grabbing	his winchester from its sheath cook prepared to fight from behind	the arroyo bank.	5.448482501884564
1547. bullets were so thick throwing sand in his face that	he found it difficult to return the fire.	3.783156528932715
1548. noticing russell's horse	in front of the long log building he assumed his friend had slipped	inside and would be able to put up a good fight so he began working	his way down the ditch to join him.	5.173394753860455
1549. at a very shallow place two mexicans	rushed into the open for a shot.	4.806999441995261
1550. dropping to one knee cook	felled one and the other struggled off with his comrade sending no further	fire in his direction.	5.666545527216546
1551. just before leaving the arroyo where he	was partially concealed he did hear shots down at the house.	4.401391225522126
1552. russell had reached the house as cook surmised dismounted but just	as the old trapper opened the door to receive him he fell into the trapper's	arms- dead.	4.84149375963217
1553. a bullet fired by one of the mexicans hiding	in a little chicken house had passed through his head tearing a hole	two-inches square on the outgoing side.	3.725023294674689
1554. finding him dead cook caught	russell's horse and rode to the cattle foreman's house to report	the incident and request bloodhounds to trail the assassins.	4.739803807233411
1555. before daylight sunday morning a posse of twenty-three men under	the leadership of deputy sheriff frank macpherson of catskill followed	the trail to the house of francisco chaves where 100 to 150	mexicans had gathered.	3.6949817479553224
1556. macpherson boldly approached the fortified	adobe house and demanded entrance.	6.144814417540349
1557. the men inside informed him that they	had some wounded men among them but he would not be allowed to see	them even though he offered medical aid.	4.343870971298439
1558. the officer demanded the names	of the injured men; the mexicans not only refused to give them	but told the possemen if they wanted a fight they could have it.	4.402868911127614
1559. since	the strength of the mexicans had been underrated too small a posse	had been collected and since the deputy had not been provided with	search warrants macpherson and his men decided it was much wiser to	withdraw.	3.5935030797680594
1560. the posse's retreat encouraged the mexicans to	be overbearing and impudent.	5.315964723648707
1561. during the following week six tons of hay	belonging to one rancher were burned; some buildings farm tools	two horses plows and hay owned by bonito lavato a friendly interpreter	for the company and pedro chavez' hay were stolen or destroyed;	and a store was broken into and robbed.	3.297478321230224
1562. district attorney m	w mills warned that he would vigorously prosecute persons caught	committing these crimes or carrying arms- he just didn't catch	anyone.	5.257324219263641
1563. increasing threats on his life finally convinced cook	that he should leave new mexico.	4.003864637933735
1564. his friends advised that it would	be only a question of time until either the mexicans killed him by	ambuscade or he would be compelled to kill them in self-defense perpetuating	the troubles.	4.974892041000736
1565. by early summer he wrote from laramie that he	was suffering from the wound inflicted in the ambush and was in a bad	way financially so pels sent him a draft for $100 warning that it	was still not wise for him to return.	3.4813612969190078
1566. pels also sent a check for $100	to russell's widow and had a white marble monument erected on his	grave.	5.0670556827622395
1567. cattle stealing and killing again serious during the	spring of 1891 placed the land grant company officers in a perplexing	position.	3.7416869787591867
1568. they were reluctant to appoint sheriffs to protect the property	thus running the risk of creating disturbances such as that on	the vermejo and yet the cowboys protested that they got no salary	for arresting cattle thieves and running the risk of being shot.	5.20625479757774
1569. and	the law virtually ignored the situation.	5.289085212213691
1570. the judge became ill just as	the colfax district court convened no substitute was brought in	no criminal cases heard only 5 out of 122 cases docketed were tried	and court adjourned sine die after sitting a few days instead of the usual	three weeks.	4.509532884884049
1571. pels complained: litigants and witnesses were	put to the expense and inconvenience of going long distances to transact	business; public money spent; justice delayed; nothing accomplished	and the whole distribution of justice in this county seems to	be an absolute farce.	3.174213241857226
1572. word reached the company that the man	behind these depredations was manuel gonzales a man with many followers	including a number who were kept in line through fear of him.	5.137405728082055
1573. although wanted by the sheriff for killing an old man named asher jones	the warrant for his arrest had never been served.	3.9851895873813596
1574. on may 19 a	deputy sheriff's posse of eight men left maxwell city and rode thirty-five	miles up the vermejo where they were joined by juan jose	martinez.	5.18087146203519
1575. by 3:00 am they reached his house and found it vacant.	5.238411003773064
1576. when they were refused entrance to his brother's house nearby	they smashed down the door broke the window and threw lighted clothes	wet with kerosene into the room.	5.104701046214631
1577. still there was no gonzales and	the family would say nothing.	5.8110430238699395
1578. about 300 yards up the creek was	a cluster of mexican houses containing six rooms in the form of a	square.	5.856563100279898
1579. while prowling around these buildings two of the posse recognized	the voice of gonzales speaking to the people inside.	4.524085833842964
1580. he was promised	that no harm would befall him if he would come out but he cursed	and replied that he would shoot any man coming near the door.	5.460528996283563
1581. the	posse then asked that he send out the women and children as the building	would be fired or torn down over his head if necessary to take him	dead or alive.	3.539645351617376
1582. in deadly earnest the besiegers methodically	stripped away portions of the roof and tossed lighted rags	inside only to have most stamped out by the women as soon as they hit	the floor.	4.996144454799241
1583. when it became obvious that he could stay inside no longer	taking a thousand to one chance gonzales rushed outside square against	the muzzle of a winchester.	3.9415704592075578
1584. shot near the heart he turned to	one side and plunged for a door to another room several feet away three	bullets following him.	4.758972536424235
1585. as he pushed open the door he fell on his	face one of his comrades pulling him inside.	4.832633887485982
1586. not realizing the	seriousness of the wound the besiegers warned that if he did not surrender	the house would be burned down around him.	6.070354431284695
1587. receiving no answer	they set the fire.	5.219666477665999
1588. when the house was about half consumed his comrade	ran to the door and threw up his hands declaring repeatedly that	he did not know the whereabouts of manuel.	5.296533547801023
1589. finding it true that he	was not inside the deputies returned to the first house and tore holes	through the side and the roof until they could see a body on the bed	covered by a blanket.	3.7145890461936673
1590. several slugs fired into the bed jerked aside	the blanket to reveal an apparently lifeless hand.	5.651062519581482
1591. shot six or eight	times the body was draped with russell's pistol belt and cartridges.	4.018132735096413
1592. there was no extra horse so it was left to his comrades who though	numbering in the fifties had stood around on the hillside nearby	without firing a shot during the entire attack.	5.46993300656914
1593. early the next	morning a mexican telephoned pels that celso chavez one of the	posse members was surrounded by ten mexicans at his father's home	on the upper vermejo.	3.541875223425387
1594. the sheriff and district attorney mills	hastily swore	out a number of warrants against men who had been riding about armed	according to signed statements by chavez and dr i p george	and ordered deputy barney clark of raton to rescue the posseman.	4.75098314532253
1595. traveling all night clark and twelve men arrived at about seven	o'clock may 22.	3.994880720245243
1596. occasionally they heard gun-shot signals and a	number of horsemen were sighted on the hills disappearing at the posse's	approach.	5.406341101454559
1597. a mexican justice of the peace had issue a writ against	chavez for taking part in the murder of manuel gonzales	so he and his father were anxious to be taken out of danger.	4.320148235019697
1598. the men	helped them gather their belongings and escorted them to raton along	with three other families desiring to leave.	4.653079438027171
1599. the ten or more	dangerous parties singled out for prosecution were still at large and	pels realized that if these men entrenched themselves in their adobe	houses defending themselves through loopholes it would be most difficult	to capture them.	3.35057833249374
1600. thus he wired j p lower and sons of	denver: have you any percussion hand grenades for throwing in a	house or across a well loaded with balls or shrapnel shot?	4.783632361878977
1601.  if not	how long to order and what is the price?	5.644607109403433
1602.  he wisely decided that	it would be foolish to create a disturbance during the coming roundup	particularly since the mexicans were on their guard.	5.117156480208038
1603. his problem	then became one of restraining the american fighters who wanted to clean	out the vermejo by force immediately.	3.9411435959340464
1604. the plant was located west of the battenkill and south of the location	of the former electric light plant.	5.301028313053215
1605. the manchester depot	sewer company issued 214 shares of stock at $10 each for construction	of a sewer in that locality and assessments were made for its maintenance.	3.186273188504057
1606. it has given considerable trouble at times and empties right	into the battenkill.	6.5765012498289535
1607. fire district no 1 discussed its possible	purchase in 1945 but considered it an unwise investment.	3.8445952847590887
1608. the	sewer on bonnet street was constructed when there were only a few houses	on the street.	6.358651584939983
1609. as new homes were built they were connected so that	all residences south of school street are served by it.	3.8032504980095743
1610. b j	connell is the present treasurer and manager.	6.412214371980113
1611. the 1946 town	meeting voted to have the selectmen appoint a committee to investigate	and report on the feasibility of some system of sewage disposal and	a disposal plant to serve manchester center depot and way's	lane.	3.4114696658478114
1612. the committee submitted a report signed by louis martin and	leon wiley with a map published in the 1946 town report.	4.878682137150378
1613. the layout	of the sewer lines was designed by henry w taylor who was the	engineer for the manchester village disposal plant.	3.3253845082477778
1614. no figures were	submitted with the report and no action was taken on it by the town.	6.0630337776460275

1616. the final step was a	vote	for a $230000 bond issue for the construction of a sewage system by	the 1959 town meeting later confirmed by a two-thirds vote at a special	town meeting june 21 1960.	4.503608727555515
1617. there the matter stands with	the prospect that soon manchester may be removed from the roster of	towns contributing raw sewage to its main streams.	4.133218760683587
1618. telegraph	manchester's unusual interest in telegraphy has	often been attributed to the fact that the rev j d wickham	headmaster of burr and burton seminary was a personal friend and	correspondent of the inventor samuel f b morse.	5.195213393221973
1619. at any	rate manchester did not lag far behind the first commercial system	which was set up in 1844 between baltimore and washington.	3.9350543716420994
1620. in	1846 matthew b goodwin jeweler and watchmaker became the town's	first telegrapher in a dwelling he built for himself and his business	two doors north of the equinox house or one door north	of the bank manchester vermont.	4.642353543744491
1621. goodwin was telegrapher for	the american telegraph company and the troy and canada	junction telegraph company.	4.008679900119071
1622. shares of capital stock at $15 each	in the latter company were payable at the bank of manchester or at	various other vermont banks.	4.8285349942397575
1623. a message of less than fifteen words to	bennington cost twenty-five cents.	4.272666933230413
1624. by 1871 l c orvis	manager of the western union telegraph company expressed	willingness to send emergency telegrams on sundays from his village	drugstore.	5.265353655599153
1625. orvis even needed to hire an assistant clark j wait.	4.317068102383446
1626. the manchester journal commented editorially on the surprising	amount of local telegraphic business.	5.078044719635661
1627. in the fall of 1878	the popular telegraph line was established between manchester	and factory point by the owners paul w orvis henry gray	j n hard and clark j wait.	3.677884893690287
1628. the line soon lived up	to its name as local messages of moderate length could be sent for a	dime and the company was quickly able to declare very liberal dividends	on its capital stock.	4.430408393081206
1629. in 1879 the same clark wait with h	h holley of south dorset formed the american telegraph	line extending from manchester depot via factory point and	south dorset to dorset.	3.400170553882384
1630. besides being most convenient the line soon	proved a good investment for the owners.	5.888289822724765
1631. telegraphers at the	depot at this time were aaron c burr and mark manley of burr	and manley dealers in lumber and dry goods.	3.758043196555686
1632. early equipment	was very flimsy; the smallest gusts of wind toppled poles	making communications impossible.	6.006178025585041
1633. but companies continued to spring	up.	6.236627984188189
1634. by 1883 the battenkill telegraph company was in existence	and alvin pettibone was its president.	5.7292865156256685
1635. operating in 1887 was the	valley telegraph line officers of which were e c orvis	president; h k fowler vice-president and secretary;	j n hard treasurer; f h walker superintendent;	h s walker assistant superintendent.	3.4418403435927885
1636. two companies now had	headquarters with clark j wait who by then had his own drugstore	at factory point- the northern union telegraph company	and the western union.	4.879760343510585
1637. operators were arthur koop and	norman	taylor.	5.619635421798327

1641. the village office of western union	with george towsley as manager and telegrapher continued in hard's	drugstore until 1905.	3.4284152241159416
1642. during the summers towsley often needed	the assistance of a company operator.	6.846296955740123

1644. new yorkers were kept informed of scores by reporters who telegraphed	fifteen to twenty thousand words daily to the metropolitan newspapers.	5.3552569008840605
1645. this boosted local telegraph business and manchester basked in	all the free advertising.	4.157601580199868
1646. in 1914 when the town was chosen for the	u s amateur golf tournament a representative hurried here from	the boston manager's office.	5.040784892174685
1647. in his wake came the district traffic	supervisor and the cream of the telegraphic profession ten of	boston's best chosen for their long experience and thorough knowledge	of golf.	3.5887968743354888
1648. during that tournament alone some 250000 words winged	their way out of manchester.	7.0006493463022155
1649. the old morse system was replaced	locally by the simplex modern automatic method in 1929 when ellamae	heckman was manager of the western union office.	3.8380946947943118
1650. during	summers business was so brisk that mrs wilcox had two assistants	and a messenger.	5.448482501884564
1651. she was succeeded by clarence goyette.	6.5051435993765745
1652. since	that time the telegraph office has shifted in location from the railroad	station at the depot and shops at the center back to the town clerk's	office and drugstore at the village.	5.244258713307813
1653. after being located for	some years in the village at the equinox pharmacy under the supervision	of mrs harry mercier it is presently located in the hill	and dale shop manchester center.	3.892273174572969
1654. the first known telephone	line in manchester was established in july 1883 between burr and	manley's store at manchester depot and the kent and root marble	company in south dorset.	4.678812018689847
1655. this was extended the following year	to include the railroad station agent's office and thayer's hotel	at factory point.	4.063510391031193

1657. telephone	wires from louis dufresne's house in east manchester to the dufresne	lumber job near bourn pond were up about 1895.	3.5853166747464886
1658. eber l taylor	of manchester depot recorded the setting of phone poles in east	dorset and barnumville in his diary for 1906.	4.861416487662795
1659. these must have been	for local calls strictly as in may 1900 the only long distance	telephone in town was transferred from c b carleton's to	young's shoe store.	3.4455592004451443
1660. a small single switchboard was installed	in the village over woodcock's hardware store	.	5.885589797688273
1661. george woodcock was manager and troubleshooter;	elizabeth way was the first operator; and a night operator was also	employed.	4.286424635722977
1662. anyone fortunate enough to have one of those early phones	advertised the fact along with the telephone number in the manchester	journal.	6.370404976252499
1663. in 1918 the new england telephone company	began erecting a building to house its operations on the corner of u	s rte 7 and what is now memorial avenue at manchester center.	3.6845191423054646
1664. service running through barnumville and to bennington county	towns east of the mountains was in the hands of the gleason telephone	company in 1925 but major supervision of telephone lines	in manchester was with the new england telephone and telegraph company	which eventually gained all control.	5.278913929571701
1665. more aerial and underground	equipment was installed as well as office improvements to take care	of the expanding business.	4.630900488313977

1669. in 1932 dorset received its own exchange	which made business easier for the manchester office but it was	not until february 1953 that area service was extended to include manchester	and dorset.	3.4104219701798746
1670. this eliminated toll calls between the two towns.	7.79944952230858
1671. within a month calls were up seventy per cent.	5.351792895728755
1672. power	electricity plays such an important part in community life	today that it is difficult to envision a time when current was not	available for daily use.	5.790937219710697
1673. yet one has to go back only some sixty years.	5.179655678913753
1674. the first mention of an electric plant in manchester seems	to be one installed in reuben colvin's and houghton's gristmill	on the west branch in factory point.	4.756436068911639
1675. no records are available as	to the date or extent of installation but it may have been in 1896.	4.812305944844753
