1677. this was working by the end	of august and giving satisfactory service.	4.795202602987652
1678. in november 1900	surveying was done under john marsden on the east mountains to ascertain	if it would be possible to get sufficient water and fall to operate	an electric power plant.	5.382662834212263
1679. nothing came of it perhaps due to lack of	opportunity for water storage.	4.447651350613073
1680. the next step was construction	by the manchester light and power company of a plant on the west	bank of the battenkill south of union street bridge.	4.718146908024343
1681. this was nearly	completed may 23 1901 with a promise of lights by june 10 but	the first light did not go on until september 28.	3.7090784084340354
1682. it was at the end	of the sidewalk in front of the dellwood cemetery cottage.	7.871274216224007
1683. the	first directors of the manchester light and power company were	john marsden m l manley william f orvis george smith	and john blackmer.	3.6838463708111506
1684. the officers were john marsden president;	john c blackmer vice-president; george smith treasurer;	and william f orvis secretary.	4.875659013570204
1685. marsden was manager of the	company for ten years and manager of its successor company the colonial	light and power company for one year.	3.726322918183409
1686. at about the time	the marsden enterprise was getting under way the vail light and	lumber company started construction of a chair stock factory on the	site of the present bennington co-operative creamery intending to	use its surplus power for generating electricity.	4.76274456194701
1687. manchester then had	two competing power companies until 1904 when the manchester light	and power company purchased the transmission system of the vail	company.	3.5033994744337345
1688. this was fortunate as the vail plant burned in 1905.	6.859434136514463
1689. the colonial light and power company was succeeded by the vermont	hydro-electric corporation which in turn was absorbed by the	central vermont public service corporation.	3.4465867515764335
1690. the latter now furnishes	the area with electricity distributed from a modern sub-station at	manchester depot which was put into operation february 19 1930 and	was improved in january 1942 by the installation of larger transformers.	4.51127356754289
1691. for a time following the abandonment of the local plant	electric current for manchester was brought in from the south with	an emergency tie-in with the vermont marble company system to the north.	4.0545373534453555
1692. some who have written on utopia have treated it as a learned	diversion of a learned world a phantasy with which more amused	himself a holiday work a spontaneous overflow of intellectual	high spirits a revel of debate paradox comedy and invention.	4.622279264676277
1693. with	respect to this view two points are worth making.	4.477601198394805
1694. first it appears	to be based on the fact that on its title page utopia is described	as festivus gay.	6.899855827026082
1695. it overlooks the other fact that	it is described as nec minus salutaris quam festivus no	less salutary than gay.	3.9707474376706213
1696. it also overlooks the fact that in a rational	lexicon and quite clearly in more's lexicon the opposite of	serious is not gay but frivolous and the opposite of gay is not serious	but solemn.	5.523068616468053
1697. more believed that a man could be both serious and gay.	4.96280475064025
1698. that a writer who is gay cannot be serious is a common professional	illusion sedulously fostered by all too many academics who mistakenly	believe that their frivolous efforts should be taken seriously because	they are expressed with that dreary solemnity which is the only mode	of expression their authors are capable of.	4.833581615313831
1699. secondly to find a learned	diversion and a pleasing joke in more's account of the stupid	brutalities of early sixteenth century wars of the anguish of the poor	and dispossessed of the insolence and cruelty of the rich and powerful	requires a callousness toward suffering and sin that would be surprising	in a moral imbecile and most surprising in more himself.	3.3154949361540473
1700. indeed	it is even surprising in the canon of christ church and regius	professor of ecclesiastical history who fathered this most peculiar	view and in the brilliant professor of medieval and renaissance	english at cambridge who inherited it and is now its most eminent	proponent.	4.603573110695904
1701. but to return to the main line of our inquiry.	6.269999280952547
1702. it	is doubtful that utopia is still widely read because more was medieval	or even because he was a martyr- indeed it is likely that these	days many who read utopia with interest do not even know that	its author was a martyr.	5.032657949398206
1703. utopia is still widely read because in	a sense more stood on the margin of modernity.	4.117840216577415
1704. and if he did stand	on the margins of modernity it was not in dying a martyr for such unity	as papal supremacy might be able to force on western christendom.	6.097065361053899
1705. it was not even in writing latin epigrams sometimes bawdy ones or	in translating lucian from greek into latin or in defending the study	of greek against the attack of conservative academics or in attacking	the conservative theologians who opposed erasmus's philological	study of the new testament.	3.5197478526877233
1706. similar literary exercises were the	common doings of a christian humanist of the first two decades of the	sixteenth century.	6.26576216135074
1707. had more's writings been wholly limited to such	exercises they would be almost as dimly remembered as those of a dozen	or so other authors living in his time whose works tenuously survive	in the minds of the few hundred scholars who each decade in pursuit	of their very specialized occasions read those works.	3.4293921130339284
1708. more	stands on the margins of modernity for one reason alone- because he	wrote utopia.	5.448482501884564
1709. and the evidence that he does indeed stand there	derives quite simply from the vigorous interest with which rather casual	readers have responded to that book for the past century or so.	3.8723626117507237
1710. only one other contemporary of more's evokes so immediate and direct	a response and only one other contemporary work- niccolo machiavelli	and the prince.	5.382612303142122
1711. can we discover what it is in utopia	that has evoked this response?	6.1790722644192
1712.  remember that in seeking the modern	in utopia we do not deny the existence of the medieval and the renaissance	there; we do not even need to commit ourselves to assessing	on the same inconceivable	scale the relative importance of the medieval the	renaissance and the modern.	4.743099556198017
1713. the medieval was the most important	to chambers because he sought to place thomas more the author of	utopia in some intelligible relation with st thomas more	the martyr.	3.413473899621708
1714. to others whose concern it is to penetrate the significance	of christian humanism the renaissance elements are of primary	concern.	5.82354792234023
1715. but here we have a distinctly modern preoccupation; we want	to know why that book has kept on selling the way it has; we want	to know what is perennially new about utopia.	3.624414666832623
1716. what is new	about it?	11.749049409667752
1717.  to that question the answer is simple; it can be made	in two words utopian communism.	4.956260467940513
1718. but it is an answer which opens the	door wide to an onrush of objections and denials.	6.693160234966844
1719. surely there is nothing	new about communism.	5.289832839054316
1720. we find it in plato's republic and	in utopia more acknowledges his debt to that book.	6.086469046836519
1721. we find it	in that common way of life h pleasing to christ and h still in	use among the truest societies of christians that is the better	monasteries which made it easier to convert the utopians to	christianity.	4.044276039950847
1722. we find it in the later stoic conception of man's natural condition	which included the community of all possessions.	6.559563533577696
1723. this conception	was taken up by the early church fathers and by canon lawyers and	theologians in the middle ages; and more was far too well read not	to have come across it in one or several of the forms thus given it.	3.7510566306324935
1724. but although the idea of communism is very old even in more's	day and did not spring full-clad from his imagination in 1515 it	is not communism as such that we are concerned with.	5.187274122325691
1725. we are concerned	not with the genus communism nor with other species of the genus:	platonic stoic early christian monastic canonist or theological	communism; we are concerned with utopian communism- that is simply	communism as it appears in the imaginary commonwealth of utopia	as more conceived it.	3.3044946782775364
1726. perhaps one way to sharpen our sense of the modernity	of utopian communism is to contrast it with the principal earlier	types of communistic theory.	5.848107535680576
1727. we will achieve a more vivid sense	of what it is by realizing what it is not.	5.416348154158808
1728. in plato's republic	communism is- to speak anachronistically- a communism of janissaries.	6.001229871442224
1729. its function is to separate from the base ruled mass among	whom private ownership prevails the governing warrior elite.	3.952070047710788
1730. moreover	it is too readily forgotten that in the republic what	gave	the initial impetus to plato's excursus into the construction of an	imaginary commonwealth with its ruling-class communism of goods wives	and children was his quest for a canon for the proper ordering of	the individual human psyche; and it is to this problem that the republic	ultimately returns.	4.924125900184388
1731. in more's utopia communism is not	a means of separating out a warrior elite from the lumpish mass.	3.8043872679306676
1732. utopian	communism applies to all utopians.	8.197425186029347
1733. and in the economy of the	book it is not peripheral but central.	6.635424545672613
1734. the concern of utopia is	with the optimo reipublicae statu the best ordering of a civil society;	and it is again and again made clear that utopian communism	provides the institutional array indispensible to that best ordering.	4.546232058195505
1735. to derive utopian communism from the jerusalem christian community	of the apostolic age or from its medieval successors-in-spirit	the monastic communities is with an appropriate shift of adjectives	misleading in the same way as to derive it from plato's republic:	in the republic we have to do with an elite of physical	and intellectual athletes in the apostolic and monastic communities with	an elite of spiritual and religious athletes.	3.4323395954151508
1736. the apostolic community	was literally an elite: chosen by christ himself.	5.315964723648707
1737. and the monastic	communities were supposed to be made up of volunteers selected only	after a novitiate which would test their religious aptitude for monastic	rigors their spiritual athleticism.	4.310415910060512
1738. finally the conception	of the natural community of all possessions which originated	with the stoics was firmly fixed in a tradition by more's time although	it was not accepted by all the theologian-philosophers of the	middle ages.	4.611176831533819
1739. in that tradition communism lay a safe distance back in	the age of innocence before the fall of man.	4.320293625240173
1740. it did not serve to	contrast the existing order of society with a possible alternative order	because the age of innocence was not a possible alternative once man	had sinned.	5.624200144799142
1741. the actual function of patristic-civilian-canonist-scholastic	communism was adequately set forth by st gregory almost a	millenium before more wrote utopia.	3.4545560222394105
1742. the soil is common	to all men h.	5.9846264875949124
1743. when we give the necessities of life to the poor	we restore to them what is already theirs.	4.764438378707458
1744. we should think of it more	as an act of justice than compassion.	7.714283439624251
1745. because community not	severalty of property is the law of nature no man can assert an absolutely	unalterable right to what is his.	4.520980688180994
1746. indeed of all that is his every	man is by nature and reason and therefore by conscience obligated	to regard himself as a custodian.	6.186928900083692
1747. he is a trustee for the common good	however feeble the safeguards which the positive or municipal law of	property provides against his misuse of that share of the common fund	wisely or unwisely entrusted to his keeping.	3.80024616603665
1748. in contrast to this	stoic-patristic view utopia implies that the nature of man is such	that to rely on individual conscience to supply the deficiencies of	municipal law is to embark on the bottomless sea of human sinfulness	in a sieve.	5.16214537228069
1749. the utopians brace conscience with legal sanctions.	4.280553672808819
1750. in	a properly ordered society the massive force of public law performs the	function which in natural law theory ineptly is left altogether to	a small voice so often still.	4.664612998467164
1751. in all the respects just	indicated	utopian communism differs from previous conceptions in which community	of possessions and living plays a role.	4.147914844415574
1752. neither from one of these	conceptions nor from a combination of them can it be deduced.	6.83653642370333
1753. we do	not deny originality to the agamemnon because aeschylus found the	tales of the house of atreus among the folk lore of the greeks.	4.0959943070421
1754. in	a like sense whatever bits or shreds of previous conceptions one may	find in it utopian communism remains as an integral whole original-	a new thing.	4.889739072366804
1755. it is not merely a new thing; it is one of the very	few new things in utopia; most of the rest is medieval or humanist	or part of an old tradition of social criticism.	4.3506668617172055
1756. but to say that	at a moment in history something is new is not necessarily to say	that it is modern; and for this statement the best evidence comes	within the five years following the publication of utopia when	martin luther elaborates a new perception of the nature of the divine's	encounter with man.	4.808684603012521
1757. new indeed is luther's perception but	not modern as anyone knows who has ever tried to make intelligible	to modern students what luther was getting at.	3.6824102484891346
1758. although utopian	communism is both new in 1516 and also modern it is not modern communism	or even modern socialism as they exist or have ever existed in	theory or in practice.	5.150502187709015
1759. consider the features of utopian communism:	generous public provision for the infirm; democratic and secret elections	of all officers including priests meals taken publicly in common	refectories; a common habit or uniform prescribed for all citizens;	even houses changed once a decade; six hours of manual labor	a day for all but a handful of magistrates and scholars and careful measures	to prevent anyone from shirking; no private property no money;	no sort of pricing at all for any goods or services and therefore	no market in the economic sense of the term.	3.1259461814493603
1760. whatever the merits of	its intent utopian communism is far too naive far too crude to suit	any modern socialist or communist.	5.275932774771675
1761. it is not the details of utopian	communism that make utopia modern it is the spirit the attitude	of mind that informs those details.	4.8473705845355175
1762. what that spirit and attitude	were we can best understand if we see more precisely how it contrasts	with the communist tradition with the longest continuous history the	one which reached christianity by the way of stoicism through the	church fathers of late antiquity.	4.810947121328029
1763. during the dorr trial the democratic press condemned the proceedings	and heralded dorr as a martyr to the principles of the declaration	of independence.	4.001525722013477
1764. during the brown trial however the state's	most powerful democratic newspaper the providence daily post	stated that brown was a murderer a man of blood and that he and	his associates with the assistance of republicans and abolitionists	had plotted not only the liberation of the slaves but also the overthrow	of state and federal governments.	5.140930969540682
1765. the providence daily journal	answered the daily post by stating that the raid of john	brown was characteristic of democratic acts of violence and that he	was acting in direct opposition to the republican party who proclaim	as one of their cardinal principles that they do not interfere	with slavery in the states.	3.446041105225758
1766. the two major newspapers in providence	continued throughout the crisis to accuse each other of misrepresenting	the facts and attempting to falsify history.	4.895987298231051
1767. while the	daily post continued to accuse republicans and the daily journal	continued to accuse democrats the woonsocket patriot complained	that the virginia authorities showed indecent and cowardly	haste to condemn brown and his men.	3.3785903760348064
1768. editor foss stated of their	guilt h there can be no doubt h but they are entitled to sufficient	time to prepare for trial and h a fair trial.	5.41158315077985
1769. the providence	daily post thought that there were probably good reasons for	the haste in which the trial was being conducted and that the only thing	gained by a delay would be calmer feelings.	3.850414679179729
1770. the providence daily	journal stated that although the guilt of brown was evident the	south must guarantee him a fair trial to preserve domestic peace.	4.715725658310473
1771. on october 31 1859 john brown was found guilty of treason	against the state of virginia inciting slave rebellion and murder.	4.2861075564994495
1772. for these crimes he was sentenced to be hanged in public on friday	december 2 1859.	6.089169198273437
1773. upon receiving the news northern writers editors	and clergymen heaped accusations of murder on the southern states	particularly virginia.	3.91713772261723
1774. although rhode islanders were preparing	for the state elections they watched john brown's trial with	extreme interest.	5.737411495334116
1775. on wednesday morning november 2 1859 the providence	daily journal stated that although brown justly deserved	the extreme penalty no man however criminal ought to suffer the penalty	without a fairer trial.	3.472963095684131
1776. the editor's main criticism of the trial	was the haste with which it was conducted.	5.61236123547299
1777. the readers of the providence	daily post however learned that it was generally conceded	that old brown had a fair trial.	3.7513726580990165
1778. concerning the sentence	the editor asked what else can virginia do than to hang the men	who have	defied her laws organized treason and butchered her citizens.	4.67288338831304
1779. in the eastern section of the state the newspapers' reaction	to brown's trial and sentence were basically identical.	4.77669515941706
1780. j	wheaton smith editor of the warren telegraph stated that the	ends of justice must be satisfied a solitary example must be set	in order that all those misnamed philantropists sic who actuated	by a blind zeal dare to instigate riot treason and murder may	heed it and shape their future course accordingly.	4.3624998336216985
1781. the editor of	the newport advertiser could discover no evidence of extenuating	circumstances in the brown trial which would warrant making an exception	to the infliction of capital punishment.	3.285969766250561
1782. in direct contrast	to the other rhode island editors samuel s foss of the woonsocket	patriot outwardly condemned the trial as being completely	unfair.	4.977567281094271
1783. concerning the sentence foss wrote if it be possible	h that mercy shall override vengeance h and that john brown's	sentence shall be commuted to imprisonment it would be well- well	for the country h and for virginia.	3.387225094996286
1784. despite the excitement	being caused by the trial and sentence of john brown rhode islanders	turned their attention to the state elections.	6.54801286090714
1785. the state had	elected republican candidates in the past two years.	5.328788358547397
1786. there was no doubt	as to the control the republican party exercised throughout the	state.	7.064982707341651
1787. if it failed on occasion to elect its candidates for general state	offices by majorities the failure was due to a lingering remnant	of the know-nothing party which called itself the american republican	party.	3.5846922129516074
1788. the american republicans and the republicans both nominated	lieutenant-governor turner for governor.	5.886533201248608
1789. elisha r potter	was the democratic candidate.	5.219666477665999
1790. the results of the election of 1859	found republican candidates not only winning the offices of governor	and lieutenant-governor but also obtaining the two congressional offices	from the eastern and western sections of the state.	4.705114525192617
1791. during	the month of november hardly a day passed when there was not some mention	of john brown in the rhode island newspapers.	3.739124052661031
1792. on november	7 1859 the providence daily journal reprinted a letter sent	to john brown from e b a quaker lady in newport.	5.175397591164153
1793. in	reference to brown's raid she wrote though we are non-resistants	and religiously believe it better to reform by moral and not by carnal	weapons h we know thee was anemated sic by the most generous	and philanthropic motives.	3.268131341214724
1794. e b compared john brown	to moses in that they were both acting to deliver millions from	oppression.	5.729308597446827
1795. in contrast to e b most rhode islanders	hardly thought of john brown as being another moses.	4.108642553937785
1796. most attempts	to develop any sympathy for brown and his actions found an unresponsive	audience in rhode island.	5.69933189648018
1797. on wednesday evening november	23 1859 in warren rev mark trafton of new bedford gave	a mission of sympathy lecture in which he favorably viewed the	harper's ferry insurrection.	3.7256401597965136
1798. the warren telegraph stated	that many of rev trafton's remarks were inappropriate and savored	strongly of radicalism and fanaticism.	4.705010556909502
1799. in its account of the trafton	lecture the providence daily post said that the remarks	of	rev trafton made the people indignant.	4.388860132326044
1800. no sympathy or admiration	for brown could be found in the providence daily post	for the editor claimed that there were a score of men in the state prison	who were a thousand times more deserving of sympathy.	6.086149463229172
1801. the providence	daily journal however stated that brown's courage bravery	and heroism in a good cause would make a man a martyr; it gives	something of dignity even to a bad one.	3.3337813678557846
1802. the woonsocket patriot	admitted that john brown might deserve punishment or imprisonment	but he should no more be hung than henry a wise or james	buchanan.	4.456516269869767
1803. the newport mercury exhibited more concern over	the possibility of the abolitionists making a martyr of brown than it	did over the development of sympathy for him.	3.533702991163081
1804. in her letter	to john brown e b the quakeress from newport had	suggested that the american people owed more honor to john brown for	seeking to free the slaves than they did to george washington.	5.027030739838112
1805. during	the latter days of november to the day of brown's execution	it seems that most rhode islanders did not concur in e b's	suggestion.	3.809559836953468
1806. on november 22 1859 the providence daily journal	stated that although brown's pluck and honest fanaticism	must be admired any honor paid to brown would only induce other fanatics	to imitate his actions.	4.835366817542542
1807. a week later the daily journal	had	discovered the initial plans of some providence citizens to hold a	meeting honoring john brown on the day of his execution.	3.5249105267198795
1808. the editor	of the daily journal warned h that if such a demonstration	be made it will not find support or countenance from any of the men	whose names are recognized as having a right to speak for providence.	4.8578474217411864
1809. the providence daily post's editor wrote that he could	not	believe that a meeting honoring brown was to be held in providence.	4.105217814901806
1810. he further called upon the people of providence to rebuke the meeting	and avoid disgrace.	6.347974983683626
1811. on december 2 1859 john brown was	hanged at charles town virginia.	4.90532077966387
1812. extraordinary precautions were	taken so that no stranger be allowed in the city and no citizen within	the enclosure surrounding the scaffold.	5.728679419982057
1813. in many northern towns and	cities meetings were held and church bells were tolled.	4.461773146587562
1814. such was not	the case in rhode island.	7.849917960683684
1815. the only public demonstration in honor	of john brown was held at pratt's hall in providence on the	day of his execution.	3.725520860869334
1816. despite the opposition of the city newspapers	the pratt hall meeting brought together a very respectable	audience composed in part of those who had been distinguished for years	for their radical views upon the subject of slavery of many of our	colored citizens and of those who were attracted to the place by the	novelty of such a gathering.	5.442494088610628
1817. seated on the platform were amos c	barstow ex-mayor of providence and a wealthy republican stove	manufacturer; thomas davis an uncompromising garrisonian; the	reverend augustus woodbury a unitarian minister; the reverend	george t day a free-will baptist; daniel w vaughan	and william h h clements.	3.164684617466118
1818. the latter two were appointed secretaries.	7.413461662752312
1819. the first speaker was amos c barstow who had been unanimously	chosen president of the meeting.	4.957978625501366
1820. he spoke of his desire to promote	the abolition of slavery by peaceable means and he compared john	brown of harper's ferry to the john brown of rhode island's	colonial period.	4.944001282526678
1821. barstow concluded that as rhode island's john	brown became a canonized hero if not a saint so would it be with	john brown of harper's ferry.	3.4659768178505845
1822. the next speaker was george	t day.	7.180162431549053
1823. although admitting brown's guilt on legal grounds	day said that brown is no common criminal; his deed was not	below but above the law.	3.711136447759656
1824. following day was woodbury who spoke of his	disapproval of brown's attempt at servile insurrection his admiration	of brown's character and his opposition to slavery.	5.062660549805197
1825. woodbury's	remarks were applauded by a portion of the audience several times	and once there was hissing.	4.750084698499031
1826. the fourth and last speaker was thomas	davis.	6.69513321990128
1827. by this time large numbers of the audience had left the	hall.	6.437375467288985
1828. davis commenced his remarks by an allusion to the general feeling	of opposition which the meeting had encountered from many of the	citizens and all the newspapers of the city.	5.099864440410382
1829. he said that the propriety	or impropriety of such a gathering was a question that was to be settled	by every man in accordance with the convictions of private judgments.	4.752169863531596
1830. in the remainder of his speech davis spoke of his admiration for	brown and warned those who took part in the meeting that they are	liable to the charge that they are supporting traitors and upholding	men whom the laws have condemned.	5.145891720414662
1831. he recalled that in rhode island	a party opposed to the state's condemnation of a man	proclaimed the state's action as a violation of the law	of the land and the principles of human liberty.	3.9124248497963454
1832. at the close of davis'	speech the following preamble and resolutions were read by the president	and on the question of their adoption passed unanimously:	whereas john brown has cheerfully risked his life in endeavoring	to deliver those who are denied all rights h and is this day doomed	to suffer death for his efforts in behalf of those who have no helper:	therefore   resolved that while we most decidedly disapprove	the methods he adopted to accomplish his objects yet h in his	willingness to die in aid of the great cause of human freedom we still	recognize the qualities of a noble nature and the exercise of a spirit	which true men have always admired and which history never fails	to honor.	4.503656814419029
1833. resolved that his wrongs and bereavements in kansas	occasioned by the violence and brutality of those who were intent on	the propagation of slavery in that territory call for a charitable	judgment upon his recent efforts in virginia to undermine the despotism	from which he had suffered and commend his family to the special	sympathy and aid of all who pity suffering and reverence justice.	3.1886130745589707
1834. resolved h that the anti-slavery sentiment is becoming ripe for	resolute action.	5.9596864846392394
1835. resolved that we find in this fearful tragedy	at harper's ferry a reason for more earnest effort to remove the	evil of slavery from the whole land as speedily as possible h.	3.5870203906817744
1836. on the morning following the pratt hall meeting the editor of the	providence daily journal wrote that although the meeting was	milder and less extreme than those held in other areas for similar purposes	it could have been avoided completely.	5.24452742374665
1837. rather than being deceived the eye is puzzled; instead of seeing objects	in space it sees nothing more than- a picture.	3.9151716903006877
1838. through	1911 and 1912 as the cubist facet-plane's tendency to adhere to	the literal surface became harder and harder to deny the task of keeping	the surface at arm's length fell all the more to eye-undeceiving	contrivances.	4.623863211233904
1839. to reinforce and sometimes to replace the simulated	typography braque and picasso began to mix sand and other foreign	substances with their paint; the granular texture thus created likewise	called attention to the reality of the surface and was effective	over much larger areas.	3.5953506068519756
1840. in certain other pictures however braque began	to paint areas in exact simulation of wood graining or marbleizing.	5.438411841003271
1841. these areas by virtue of their abrupt density of pattern stated the	literal surface with such new and superior force that the resulting	contrast drove the simulated printing into a depth from which it could	be rescued- and set to shuttling again- only by conventional perspective;	that is by being placed in such relation to the forms depicted	within the illusion that these forms left no room for the typography	except near the surface.	3.1371310892696003
1842. the accumulation of such devices	however soon had the effect of telescoping even while separating	surface and depth.	5.387869840261396
1843. the process of flattening seemed inexorable and it	became necessary to emphasize the surface still further in order to	prevent it from fusing with the illusion.	3.6349132966433917
1844. it was for this reason and	no other that i can see that in september 1912 braque took the radical	and revolutionary step of pasting actual pieces of imitation-woodgrain	wallpaper to a drawing on paper instead of trying to simulate	its texture in paint.	5.11462100664854
1845. picasso says that he himself had already made	his first collage toward the end of 1911 when he glued a piece of	imitation-caning	oilcloth to a painting on canvas.	4.051071287374806
1846. it is true that his first	collage looks more analytical than braque's which would confirm	the date he assigns it.	5.681585976709684
1847. but it is also true that braque was the	consistent pioneer in the use of simulated textures as well as of typography;	and moreover he had already begun to broaden and simplify the	facet-planes of analytical cubism as far back as the end of 1910.	4.444898070458333
1848. when we examine what each master says was his first collage we	see that much the same thing happens in each.	6.323877502824014
1849. that braque's collage is on paper and eked out in charcoal	by its greater	corporeal presence and its greater extraneousness the affixed paper	or cloth serves for a seeming moment to push everything else into a more	vivid idea of depth than the simulated printing or simulated textures	had ever done.	3.1661271850525434
1850. but here again the surface-declaring device both	overshoots and falls short of its aim.	5.757408538537557
1851. for the illusion of depth created	by the contrast between the affixed material and everything else	gives way immediately to an illusion of forms in bas-relief which gives	way in turn and with equal immediacy to an illusion that seems	to contain both- or neither.	3.3496923523126383
1852. because of the size of the areas	it covers the pasted paper establishes undepicted flatness bodily	as more than an indication or sign.	6.500794826006312
1853. literal flatness now tends to	assert itself as the main event of the picture and the device boomerangs:	the illusion of depth is rendered even more precarious than before.	3.368686057931947
1854. instead of isolating the literal flatness by specifying and circumscribing	it the pasted paper or cloth releases and spreads it and	the artist seems to have nothing left but this undepicted flatness with	which to finish as well as start his picture.	5.050177586999809
1855. the actual surface	becomes both ground and background and it turns out- suddenly and paradoxically-	that the only place left for a three-dimensional illusion	is in front of upon the surface.	3.590857999155955
1856. in their very first collages	braque and picasso draw or paint over and on the affixed	paper or cloth so that certain of the principal features of their	subjects as depicted seem to thrust out into real bas-relief space-	or to be about to do so- while the rest of the subject remains	imbedded in or flat upon the surface.	4.772397514823254
1857. and the surface is driven back	in its very surfaceness only by this contrast.	4.503367591461173
1858. in the upper	center of braque's first collage fruit dish	a bunch of grapes is rendered with such conventionally	vivid sculptural effect as to lift it practically off the picture	plane.	4.739833019046428
1859. the trompe-l'oeil illusion here is no longer enclosed	between parallel flatnesses but seems to thrust through the surface	of the drawing paper and establish depth on top of it.	3.5135176843237876
1860. yet the	violent immediacy of the wallpaper strips pasted to the paper and the	only lesser immediacy of block capitals that simulate window lettering	manage somehow to push the grape cluster back into place on the picture	plane so that it does not jump.	5.183447573004275
1861. at the same time the wallpaper	strips themselves seem to be pushed into depth by the lines and	patches of shading charcoaled upon them and by their placing in relation	to the block capitals; and these capitals seem in turn to be pushed	back by their placing and by contrast with the corporeality	of the woodgraining.	3.472776901653841
1862. thus every part and plane of the picture keeps	changing place in relative depth with every other part and plane; and	it is as if the only stable relation left among the different parts	of the picture is the ambivalent and ambiguous one that each has with	the surface.	4.677976288330227
1863. and the same thing more or less can be said of the contents	of picasso's first collage.	5.974097411508362
1864. in later collages of both	masters a variety of extraneous materials are used sometimes in the	same work and almost always in conjunction with every other eye-deceiving	and eye-undeceiving device they can think of.	4.9135034094303505
1865. the area adjacent	to one edge of a piece of affixed material- or simply of a painted-in	form- will be shaded to pry that edge away from the surface while	something will be drawn painted or even pasted over another part of	the same shape to drive it back into depth.	3.4080210756939864
1866. planes defined as parallel	to the surface also cut through it into real space and a depth is	suggested optically which is greater than that established pictorially.	4.63479892887524
1867. all this expands the oscillation between surface and depth so as to	encompass fictive space in front of the surface as well as behind it.	4.6196840390583915
1868. flatness may now monopolize everything but it is a flatness become	so ambiguous and expanded as to turn into illusion itself- at least	an optical if not properly speaking a pictorial illusion.	5.129706837652187
1869. depicted	cubist flatness is now almost completely assimilated to the literal	undepicted kind but at the same time it reacts upon and largely transforms	the undepicted kind- and it does so moreover without depriving	the latter of its literalness; rather it underpins and reinforces	that literalness re-creates it.	3.3924763038650347
1870. out of this re-created literalness	the cubist subject reemerged.	8.227889623553734
1871. for it had turned out by a	further paradox of cubism that the means to an illusion of depth and	plasticity had now become widely divergent from the means of representation	or imaging.	3.675044907791035
1872. in the analytical phase of their cubism braque	and picasso had not only had to minimize three-dimensionality simply	in order to preserve it; they had also had to generalize it-	to the point finally where the illusion of depth and relief became abstracted	from specific three-dimensional entities and was rendered largely	as the illusion of depth and relief as such: as a disembodied	attribute and expropriated property detached from everything not itself.	4.2997024367259815
1873. in order to be saved plasticity had had to be isolated; and	as the aspect of the subject	was transposed into those clusters of more or less interchangeable	and contour-obliterating facet-planes by which plasticity	was isolated under the cubist method the subject itself became largely	unrecognizable.	3.7361804582202214
1874. cubism in its 1911-1912 phase	was on the verge of abstract art.	5.739974350684024
1875. it was then that picasso and braque were confronted with	a unique dilemma: they had to choose between illusion and representation.	4.078383411955185
1876. if they opted for illusion it could only be illusion per se-	an illusion of depth and of relief so general and abstracted as	to exclude the representation of individual objects.	4.974407354420258
1877. if on the other	hand they opted for representation it had to be representation per	se- representation as image pure and simple without connotations	of the three-dimensional space	in which the objects represented originally existed.	3.5941001005437383
1878. it was the	collage that made the terms of this dilemma clear: the representational	could be restored and preserved only on the flat and literal surface	now that illusion and representation had become for the first time	mutually exclusive alternatives.	5.0648460848396235
1879. in the end picasso and braque	plumped for the representational and it would seem they did so	deliberately.	4.693858254679376
1880. but the inner formal logic of cubism	as it worked itself out through the collage had just as much to do	with shaping their decision.	5.44306126369345
1881. when the smaller facet-planes of analytical	cubism were placed upon or juxtaposed with the large dense shapes	formed by the affixed materials of the collage they had to coalesce-	become synthesized- into larger planar shapes themselves	simply in order to maintain the integrity of the picture plane.	3.5488348514533383
1882. left	in their previous atom-like smallness they would have cut away too abruptly	into depth; and the broad opaque shapes of pasted paper would	have been isolated in such a way as to make them jump out of plane.	4.959127653694821
1883. large planes juxtaposed with other large planes tend to assert themselves	as independent shapes and to the extent that they are flat	they also assert themselves as silhouettes; and independent silhouettes	are apt to coincide with the recognizable contours of the subject	from which a picture starts.	3.5263279059579884
1884. it was	because of this chain-reaction as much as for any other reason- that	is because of the growing independence of the planar unit in collage	as a shape- that the identity of depicted objects or at least	parts of them re-emerged in braque's and picasso's papiers colles	and continued to remain more conspicuous there- but only as	flattened silhouettes- than in any of their paintings done wholly in	oil before the end of 1913.	4.79084662975645
1885. analytical cubism came to an end	in the collage but not conclusively; nor did synthetic cubism fully	begin there.	3.685338251241182
1886. only when the collage had been exhaustively translated	into oil and transformed by this translation did cubism become	an affair of positive color and flat interlocking silhouettes whose legibility	and placement created allusions to if not the illusion of	unmistakable three-dimensional identities.	4.6241305458691295
1887. synthetic cubism began	with picasso alone late in 1913 or early in 1914; this was the	point at which he finally took the lead in cubist innovation away from	braque never again to relinquish it.	3.4839327923756556
1888. but even before that picasso	had glimpsed and entered for a moment a certain revolutionary path	in which no one had preceded him.	5.7101038219070634
1889. it was as though in that instant	he had felt the flatness of collage as too constricting and had suddenly	tried to escape all the way back- or forward- to literal three-dimensionality.	3.6855857013134083
1890. this he did by using utterly literal means to carry	the forward push of the collage literally	into the literal space in front of the picture plane.	5.41164694655386
1891. some	time in 1912 picasso cut out and folded a piece of paper in the	shape of a guitar; to this he glued and fitted other pieces of paper	and four taut strings thus creating a sequence of flat surfaces in real	and sculptural space to which there clung only the vestige of a picture	plane.	3.1892282216939227
1892. the affixed elements of collage were extruded as it were	and cut off from the literal pictorial surface to form a bas-relief.	4.943383761200579
1893. and without	high density in the core rapid-transit systems cannot be maintained	economically let alone built from scratch at today's prices.	3.7146277578638487
1894. however the building of freeways and garages cannot continue forever.	7.157911864563925
1895. the new interchange among the four los angeles freeways including	the grade-constructed accesses occupies by itself no less than eighty	acres of downtown land one-eighth of a square mile an area	about the size of rockefeller center in new york.	3.5329777346121394
1896. it is hard to believe	that this mass of intertwined concrete constitutes what the law	calls the highest and best use of centrally located urban land.	5.233558875422109
1897. as it affects the city's fiscal situation such an interchange is	ruinous; it removes forever from the tax rolls property which should	be taxed to pay for the city services.	4.065243550357077
1898. subways improved land values	without taking away land; freeways boost valuation less	and reduce	the acreage that can be taxed.	5.521074398377426
1899. downtown los angeles is already	two-thirds freeway interchange street parking lot and garage- one	of those preposterous if statistics has already come to pass.	3.5860799631562674
1900. the freeway with narrowly spaced interchanges concentrates and	mitigates the access problem but it also acts inevitably as an artificial	isolating boundary.	4.759168586399779
1901. city planners do not always use this boundary	as effectively as they might.	4.2607360661217895
1902. less ambitious freeway plans may be	more successful- especially when the roadways and interchanges are	raised allowing for cross access at many points and providing parking	areas below the ramp.	4.755027791214721
1903. meanwhile the automobile and its friend	the truck have cost the central city some of its industrial dominance.	4.00647248218918
1904. in ever greater numbers factories are locating in the suburbs or	in industrial parks removed from the city's political jurisdiction.	5.469027653524917
1905. the appeal of the suburb is particularly strong for heavy industry	which must move bulky objects along a lengthy assembly line and wants	enough land area to do the entire job on one floor.	3.3977681905172386
1906. to light industry	the economies of being on one floor are much slighter but efficiency	engineers usually believe in them and manufacturers looking for	ways to cut costs cannot be prevented from turning to efficiency engineers.	4.593070865911011
1907. this movement of industry away from the central cities	is not so catastrophically new as some prophets seem to believe.	4.0014627441031925
1908. it	is merely the latest example of the leapfrog growth which formed the pattern	of virtually all american cities.	5.9692003974817505
1909. the big factories which are	relatively near the centers of our cities- the rubber factories in	akron chrysler's detroit plants ussteel's pittsburgh	works- often began on these sites at a time when that was the	edge of the city yet close to transport and	power.	3.573378081032905
1910. the leapfrog was a phenomenon of the railroad and	the steam turbine and the time when the belts of residence surrounding	the old factory area were not yet blighted.	4.709415924534301
1911. the truck and	the car gave the manufacturer a new degree of freedom in selecting his	plant site.	3.470558666016351
1912. until internal combustion became cheap he had to be near	a railroad siding and a trolley line or an existing large community	of lower-class homes.	5.743815627371927
1913. the railroad siding is still important- it	is usually though not always true that long-haul shipment by rail is	cheaper than trucking.	3.406917362585231
1914. but anybody who promises a substantial volume	of business can get a railroad to run a short spur to his plant these	days and many businesses can live without the railroad.	4.710981554864613
1915. and there	are now many millions of workers for whom the factory with the big parking	lot which can be reached by driving across or against the usual	pattern of rush hour traffic and grille-route bus lines is actually	more convenient than the walk-to factory.	3.4044018570668717
1916. willow run general	electric's enormous installations at louisville and syracuse the	pentagon boeing in seattle douglas and lockheed in los angeles	the new automobile assembly plants everywhere- none of these is	substantially served by any sort of conventional mass rapid transit.	4.505662051798856
1917. they are all suburban plants relying on the roads to keep them supplied	with workers.	4.893182341900413
1918. and wherever the new thruways go up their banks are	lined by neat glass and metal and colored brick light industry.	5.029322102730556
1919. the	drive along massachusetts' route 128 the by-pass which makes an	arc about twenty miles from downtown boston may be a vision of the future.	3.784593827309181
1920. the future could be worse.	6.51334578478144
1921. the plants along route 128	are mostly well designed and nicely set against the new england rocks	and trees.	3.7355529649614265
1922. they can even be rather grand like edward land's monument	to the astonishing success of polaroid.	5.98662265402013
1923. but they deny the values	of the city- the crowded competitive tolerant city the melting	pot which gave off so many of the most admirable american qualities.	4.531534171044271
1924. they are segregated businesses combining again on one site	the factory and the office drawing their work force from segregated	communities.	5.329703242133651
1925. it is interesting to note how many of the plants on massachusetts'	route 128 draw most of their income either from the government	in non-competitive cost-plus arrangements or from the exploitation	of patents which grant at least a partial monopoly.	4.0416178700675
1926. while	the factories were always the center of the labor market they were	often on the city's periphery.	5.976357498083123
1927. in spreading the factories even farther	the automobile may not have changed to any great extent the growth	pattern of the cities.	3.9129593927071773
1928. even the loss of hotel business to the outskirt's	motel has been relatively painless; the hotel-motel demarcation	is becoming harder to find every year.	5.560681731921372
1929. what hurts most is the damage	the automobile has done to central-city retailing especially in	those cities where public transit is feeble.	3.777327978562136
1930. some retailing	of course always spreads with the population- grocery stores drugstores	local haberdasheries and dress shops candy stores and the like.	5.081054198781015
1931. but whenever a major purchase was contemplated forty years ago- a	new bedroom set or a winter coat an easter bonnet a bicycle for junior-	the family set off for the downtown department store where the	selection would be greatest.	3.2765938771954044
1932. department stores congregated in the	one hundred per cent location where all the transit lines converged.	5.2288514545018705
1933. these stores are still there but the volume of the downtown	store has been on a relative decline while in many cities the suburban	branch sells more and more dry goods.	3.90107910730136
1934. if the retailer and	hotelman's downtown unit sales have been decreasing however his dollar	volume continues to rise and it is dollars which you put in the	bank.	5.36945044188006
1935. in most discussions of this phenomenon the figures are	substantially inflated.	4.916365850517278
1936. no suburban shopping-center branch- not even	hudson's vast northland outside detroit- does anything like	the unit volume of business or carries anything like the variety of merchandise	to be found in the home store.	5.35915621992862
1937. telephone orders distort the	picture: the suburbanite naturally calls a local rather than a central-city	number if both are listed in an advertisement especially if	the local call eliminates city sales tax.	3.4434753867070733
1938. the suburban branch is thereby	credited with a sale which would have been made even if its glass	doors had never opened.	5.503151963503262
1939. accounting procedures which continue to charge	a disproportionate overhead and warehouse expense to the main store	make the branches seem more profitable than they are.	3.449119589876722
1940. in many cases	that statement we break even on our downtown operation and make money	on our branches would be turned around if the cost analysis were	recalculated on terms less prejudicial to the old store.	4.824296423423962
1941. fear of the	competition- always a great motivating force in the american economy-	makes retailers who do not have suburban operations exaggerate	both the volume and the profitability of their rival's shiny new	branches.	3.972606877712099
1942. the fact seems to be that very many large branch stores are	uneconomical that the choice of location in the suburbs is as important	as it was downtown and that even highly suburbanized cities will	support only so many big branches.	5.01507527391383
1943. moreover the cost of operations	is always high in any new store as the conservative bankers who	act as controllers for retail giants are beginning to discover.	3.9683289622876563
1944. when all has been said however the big branch store remains a major	break with history in the development of american retailing.	6.041815786547183
1945. just	as the suburban factory may be more convenient than the downtown plant	to the worker with a car the trip to the shopping center may seem far	easier than to the downtown department store though both are the same	distance from home.	3.448039439079236
1946. indeed there are some cities where the suburban	shopping pulls customers who are geographically much nearer to downtown.	6.0425592431645905
1947. raymond vernon reports that residents of east st louis	have been driving across the mississippi through the heart of downtown	st louis and out to the western suburbs for major shopping simply	because parking is easier at the big branches than it is in the heart	of town.	3.9084257857482037
1948. to the extent that the problem is merely parking an aggressive	downtown management like that of lazarus brothers in columbus	ohio can fight back successfully by building a garage on the lot	next door.	5.303086920537601
1949. if the distant patron of the suburban branch has been frightened	away from downtown by traffic problems however the city store	can only pressure the politicians to do something about the highways	or await the completion of the federal highway program.	3.583669688946435
1950. and if the	affection for the suburban branch reflects a desire to shop with nice	people rather than with the indiscriminate urban mass which supports	the downtown department store the central location may be in serious	trouble.	5.126625372721051
1951. today according to land economist homer hoyt shopping	centers and their associated parking lots cover some 46000 acres	of land which is almost exactly the total land area in all the nation's	central business districts put together.	3.5487968870360356
1952. the downtown	store continues to offer the great inducement of variety both within	its gates and across the street where other department stores are immediately	convenient for the shopper who wants to see what is available	before making up her mind.	4.77621945814988
1953. if anything may be predicted in the quicksilver	world of retailing it seems likely that the suburban branch will	come to dominate children's clothing	household gadgetry and the discount business	in big-ticket items.	3.435809184987742
1954. department stores were built on dry goods especially	ladies' fashions and in this area in the long run the suburban	branches will be hard put to compete against downtown.	5.548825002224248
1955. if this	analysis is correct the suburban branches will turn out to be what management's	cost accountants refuse to acknowledge marginal operations	rather than major factors.	4.049393903213211
1956. historically in america the appeal	of cities has been their color and life the variety of experience	they offered.	5.488464210541893
1957. how ya gonna keep 'em down on the farm?	5.878967161659676
1958.  was	a question that had to be asked long before they saw paree.	6.349101407589748
1959. though	americans usually lived in groups segregated by national origin or religious	belief they liked to work and shop in the noise and vitality	of downtown.	3.499879517314526
1960. only a radical change in the nature of the population in	the central city would be likely to destroy this preference- and we	must now turn our attention to the question of whether such a change	gloomily foreseen by so many urban diagnosticians is actually upon us.	5.655828303030677
1961. in their book american skyline	christopher tunnard and henry hope reed argue that franklin roosevelt's	new deal was what made the modern suburb a possibility-	a fine ironical argument when you consider how suburbanites tend to	vote.	3.440332232682248
1962. the first superhighways- new york's henry hudson and chicago's	lake shore san francisco's bay bridge and its approaches	a good slice of the pennsylvania turnpike- were built as	part of the federal works program which was going to cure the depression.	4.813117635789447
1963. at the same time roosevelt's federal housing administration	coupled with henry morgenthau's cheap-money policy permitted	ordinary lower-middle-class families to build their own homes.	4.119233236656023
1964. bankers	who had been reluctant to lend without better security than the house	itself got that security from the u s government; householders	who had been unable to pick up the burden of short-term high-interest	mortgages found they could borrow for twenty-five years at 4 per	cent under government aegis.	5.011519205524884
1965. before losing itself in the sands of the 19th century the grand stream	of italian renaissance architectural decoration made a last appearance	in the brumidi frescos of the capitol rotunda in washington.	3.747933726778345
1966. the artistic generation after brumidi was trained in the paris	of that time to a more meticulous standard of execution and tended	to overlook greatness of conception where faults and weakness were	easy to find.	4.4213396952104125
1967. but it is a great conception.	10.189340917358702
1968. the open ceiling with	allegorical and classical figures thrown in masses against the sky:	the closed frieze formally divided into historical scenes and tightly	tied to the stone walls belong in their large ordering to the line	of correggio and his baroque followers.	4.152331802958107
1969. the descent may be remote	but this is surely the only full-scale example of that vigorous inheritance	in the united states.	3.3564185518874785
1970. constantino brumidi designed the	decorative scheme as a whole in collaboration with the architect charles	u walter at the time when plans were being made to replace	the wooden dome of bullfinch with the present much larger iron structure.	5.04440878222915
1971. after many years and many interruptions he was able to finish	the canopy fresco and slightly less than half the frieze beginning	with the liberty group opposite the east door and ending with william	penn all but one leg when a tragic accident ended his career.	3.45530482309249
1972. he left at his death sketches drawn to scale for the rest of the circle.	6.16879503516448
1973. these were carried out not too faithfully by filippo costaggini	who began by supplying the missing member to the founder of pennsylvania	and noting in pencil in italian that he began at this point.	3.3991710357195917
1974. when costaggini had used up all the sketches thirty-six	feet of empty frieze were left over.	5.945995372001781
1975. a blank undecorated void plastered	in roughcast disfigured the wall of the rotunda until 1951.	3.981840683965065
1976. then	advised by the architect of the capitol the joint committee	for the library traditionally responsible for the works of art in the	building ordered the space cleared and painted in fresco to show	the peace after the civil war the spanish-american war	and the birth of aviation to match as nearly as feasible	brumidi's technique and composition.	4.862005855962294
1977. later the cleaning and restoration	were ordered first of the older part of the frieze finally of	the canopy.	5.298864965377247
1978. what follows is therefore a description of three separate	undertakings the new frescoing of the gap and the successive essays	in conservation with some discussion of problems that arose in connection	with each.	4.875654853667039
1979. for the use of students and future restorers	a full day-by-day record was kept of all three undertakings complete	technical reports on what we found and what we did.	4.066724116611843
1980. these may be consulted	in the office of the architect of the capitol or the library	of congress.	6.319462361876148
1981. the first preliminary was inspecting the unfinished	length of frieze a jumble of roughcast and finish coats all	in	bad condition.	3.758905484521229
1982. it was decided to strip the whole area down to the bricks	and to replace the rough coats up to one inch thickness to agree	with the older artists' preparation with a mortar one part slaked	lime three parts sand to be put on in two layers.	4.772050221330066
1983. cartoons were drawn	full size after sketches had been made to satisfy all the authorities.	4.092411569102882
1984. there was some difficulty here.	10.220011015036953
1985. one had to manage the given subjects	three diverse recent events so as to make them part of a classical	frieze- that is a pattern of large figures filling the space	with not much else against a blank background.	3.8521805677261454
1986. moreover all three	representations must be squeezed comfortably into little more than the	length brumidi allowed for each one of his.	6.082928316089969
1987. when it was all	arranged to fit and not to interrupt the lengthwise flow of movement	in the frieze the cartoons were tried in place.	4.201506660504697
1988. the scaffolding a	confusion of heavy beams hanging from the gallery above was strong and	safe but obscured visibility.	4.705010556909502
1989. nothing could be seen from the floor	but by moving around the gallery one could get glimpses; and we were	able to decide on some amplification of scale.	3.593234252299905
1990. to be sure of matching	color as well as form pieces of cartoon were traced on the roughcast	and large samples painted in fresco then left two months to dry	out to their final key.	5.409253825178524
1991. later it was gratifying to note that they had	set so solidly as to be hard to remove when the time came.	4.3868040756402245
1992. the	scaffold was the length of the space to be painted.	7.604024103479929
1993. what bits of brumidi	and costaggini could be reached at either end seemed in good	order though the roughish sandy surface was thick with dust.	3.666071727063683
1994. washed	they came out surprisingly clear and bright.	6.743273855772659
1995. it could be seen that	both artists used a very thick final coat of plaster one half inch	and that both followed the traditional italian fresco technique as described	by cennino cennini in the 14th century and current in italy	to this day.	3.412704973540326
1996. that is they used opaque color throughout getting solid	highlights with active lime white.	6.298484908345059
1997. painting a secco is much	in evidence.	5.219666477665999
1998. a brown hatching reinforces and broadens shadows and	much of the background is solidly covered with a dark coat.	5.078284996494666
1999. this brown	is sometimes so rich in medium as to appear to be oil paint.	4.295493139325422
2000. in our own practice to have the last intonaco plaster coat thick	enough to match and at the same time to avoid fine cracks in	drying	we found that it had to be put on in two layers letting the first	set awhile before applying the second.	5.526112803093115
2001. the mortar was three parts sand	to two of lime.	3.9843222565600884
2002. some of the lime that is always on hand in the capitol	basement for plaster repairs was slaked several months for us;	but to make it stiffer of a really putty-like consistency to avoid cracking	we added a little hydrated lime- hard on the hands but we	could see no other disadvantage.	4.873312534092596
2003. i am told that a mortar longer slaked	might have remained longer in condition for painting.	4.401252136203605
2004. as it was it	took the pigment well for six hours enough for our purpose and held	it firmly in setting.	5.976969958533369
2005. it was obvious that to match brumidi white must	be mixed with all but the darkest tones.	4.346189004282185
2006. lime white hard and brilliant	has a tendency to jump away from the other colors in drying	and also by its capacity to set to preclude the use of ready-made	gradations so useful in decorative work.	5.305890775801409
2007. in older italian practice	lime dried and reground bianco sangiovanni entered into such	prepared shades.	4.129223173049631
2008. for convenience we chose a stronger pigment	unknown	to the early italians or to brumidi titanium oxide reserving the	active lime white for highest lights put on at the end of the day's	stint.	5.105884778428044
2009. other pigments were mostly raw umber some burnt umber and	a little yellow ochre.	4.284776815102127
2010. this last was probably not in brumidi's palette	but was needed to take the chill bluish look off the new work next	to the old where softening effects	of time were seen even after thorough	cleaning.	4.8506322710243035
2011. the use of secco we tried to restrict to covering	joints.	4.895908513661044
2012. experience showed however that it is very difficult to	paint a dark umber background in fresco that will not dry out spotty	and uneven.	5.965829353065839
2013. later brumidi and costaggini will be seen coping with this	same problem.	4.850488527910637
2014. we were forced as they were to work a good deal of	tempera into background and dark areas.	7.348169010853981
2015. we made it by doerner's	recipe five parts thoroughly washed cheese curd to one of lime putty;	ground together they made a strong adhesive which became waterproof	in drying.	3.7276666691222125
2016. figure 1 was taken in 1953.	7.163184125958424
2017. the new part is finished.	6.0635976940625325
2018. on the right is the brumidi liberty group as it looked after	cleaning operations which had not yet come around to the other end;	where of costaggini only some foliage has been washed at the point	where his work stopped.	4.958568525460401
2019. one is led to speculate as to why the empty	space was there left for our century to finish.	4.40183660723939
2020. costaggini said it	was brumidi's fault in not providing enough material to fill the circle.	5.855267973934804
2021. brumidi's son later maintained that costaggini had compressed	and mutilated his father's designs ambitiously coveting a bit he	could claim for his very own.	3.467766426174774
2022. this question might be settled by comparing	the measurement of the actual circumference with the dimensions	noted presumably in brumidi's hand above the various sections of	his long preparatory drawing which has been kept.	4.779127346683367
2023. whose ever	fault	it is evident that brumidi intended to fill out the whole frieze with	his histories and come full circle with the scene of the discovery	of california gold.	3.5011219909922757
2024. in painting a fresco the handling of wet mortar	compels one always to move from top to bottom and from left to right	not to spoil yesterday's work with today's plastering.	4.650979805575045
2025. at the	very first then brumidi was required by the classically pyramidal	shape of his central group to fill in the triangular space above the	seated girl on liberty's right before starting on the allegorical	figures themselves.	3.4797151201950247
2026. here he put a small man whose missing hands	might have left his function doubtful until comparison with the first	sketches showed that when the artist came back to the beginning this	was to be the closing figure of the party of forty-niners and	was to hold a basket.	5.841895673289365
2027. one sees costaggini's rendering of the same	figure more than thirty feet away.	4.6531097606811125
2028. the photograph figure 1 of the completed	frieze shows how having been separated from his fellows in	useless isolation for eighty years he has now been given a hand and	by juxtaposition given a new job	to represent the witnesses of the first flight at kitty hawk in	1903.	4.424595561830103
2029. the startlingly bright effect of the first washings led	the committee to order the rest of the brumidi-costaggini cycle cleaned	and restored to go with them.	4.234396013290443
2030. the fixed wooden scaffold was removed	and so as to reach all the frieze one of pipe on wheels built	up from the floor.	4.7223655909193125
2031. every few days in the early morning as the work	progressed twenty men would appear to push it ahead and to shift the	plank foundation that distributed its weight widely on the rotunda	pavement supported as it is by ancient brick vaulting.	3.817463490136137
2032. on this	giddy and oscillating platform over fifty feet from the floor after	a first dusting we began to wash.	5.946904322413961
2033. a most useful tool for wetting the	surface without running down was made from a greenhouse mist spray	nozzle welded to a hose connection to be used at low water pressure.	3.6138712733124216
2034. a valve in the handle let us cut the pressure still lower.	5.535226767350575
2035. one	man sprayed with a sponge in hand to check excess wetting.	4.3319909034751385
2036. a second	assistant mopped with two sponges.	7.064901200998796
2037. in parts a repeated sponging was	needed but everywhere we found that water alone was enough to restore	the original brightness.	3.8760258761651207
2038. no soap or other cleaning agent was used that	might bring in unwanted chemical reactions.	5.755469585402549
2039. the painting a fresco	stood up superbly; a little of the secco came off.	3.6311665274219016
2040. necessary	retouching was put on at once.	7.163184125958424
2041. altogether we found the craftsmanship	first rate especially brumidi's.	4.6724501027054846
2042. we were greatly helped by	there being no traces of former restoring.	6.703232231793325
2043. apparently not more than	dusting had ever been done and not much of that.	4.504309734766431
2044. the plaster was sound	the intonaco firmly attached all over and the pigment solidly incorporated	with it in all but a few unimportant places.	4.58402790427742
2045. the greatest	source of trouble was rain which had repeatedly flowed from openings	above soaking the surface and leaving streaks of dissolved lime	very conspicuous even after cleaning particularly in the landing	of columbus oglethorpe and the indians and yorktown.	3.080545876941812
2046. here the architect referring to the use of the capitol as a	public building not a museum requested some repainting to maintain decorative	effect rather than leaving blank unsightly patches.	5.854140043296859
2047. these frescos have had no care for eighty years.	5.3442686800918615
2048. with naked gas jets	below and leaky windows above enough to ruin wall paintings in any	medium they have survived in a building long unheated in winter hot	and damp under the iron dome in summer.	4.6555878658311265
2049. those whom i wish to address with this letter are for the most	part unknown to me.	4.328119925000125
2050. it may well be that when rudy pozzatti and i	visited your country last spring you were living and working close	to the places we saw and the streets we walked.	5.07776535142827
2051. as american artists	it was natural that we would want to meet as many soviet artists as	possible.	4.115932425784339

2053. even though we did not	see many of your faces it appears now quite evident that a considerable	number of your profession heard from those whom we had the fortune	to encounter that we had been in your midst.	3.782875704609476
2054. i am very pleased that	quite a number of you found ways to communicate to me your desire to	hear of our reactions and experiences in the ussr.	5.425937297077195

2058. there should	be no reason to misinterpret or ignore the intent of this letter.	7.149268655165408
2059. pozzatti	and i endeavored earnestly to record our impressions without the	prejudice that the anxiety of our time so easily provokes.	3.7289827761611933
2060. the time-span	of little more than a month cannot entitle me to pose as an expert	on anything i saw.	5.532182887677444

2062. nevertheless i consider it reasonable because of my commitment	as an artist to assume that the rights and responsibilities of creative	individuals are related to humanity as a whole rather than to specific	geo-political interests.	5.36469239636826
2063. if this attitude is seriously questioned	in the soviet union it does not necessarily follow that the majority	of the society in which i live is too aware of the necessity for	clarity on this ethical as well as aesthetic point of view.	4.265298573429023
2064. it is	a matter of some disappointment to me that still many of my own countrymen	are too shortsighted to ascribe any symbolic significance to the	plight of a minority such as artists in any social order.	4.827829948416424
2065. i encountered	many questions and great interest upon my return from the soviet union	about my reactions to that experience.	3.9037207939758165
2066. that which i found most	profound and most disturbing appeared to evoke a curiously muted reaction.	5.840422843857378

2068. apparently	this is not the time and the climate in which people will listen	objectively or at least dispassionately to individual impressions	of a subject which preoccupies a good deal of their waking moments.	5.9661526208923865
2069. personal	predispositions tend to blunt the ear and in turn the voice	as well.	4.425120857946609

2072. difficult as it may have been at times pozzatti and i saw	enough talked to enough artists historians and others to realize	that the issue is quite clear.	5.0543017721003745
2073. artists and poets are the raw nerve-ends	of humanity; they are small in number and their contribution is not	immediately decisive in everyday life.	3.4952481155558908
2074. by themselves they may not	be able to save the life on this planet but without them there would	be very little left worth saving.	5.195447695020047
2075. it cannot be said that our	very first day in the soviet union turned out to be an ordinary one.	5.862089551558409

2086. a struggle that is	being waged all over the world in the half-light of disinterest.	6.685515515102379

2111. to save time some clarification seemed necessary.	5.422338772471507
2112. the following	is a statement read to a large and friendly group of your fellow artists	in leningrad:   we have come to your land with the	express intention of understanding and respecting your ideas and your	ways.	4.815132230400526
2113. our presence here should also be considered further sincere evidence	of the attempts by our people and their chosen government to seek	any and all possible ways to effect closer peaceful ties among all	people.	3.384901849771465

2117. your past history	is resplendent with the fruits of the intellect.	5.021356218602994

2120. while we as american	artists	believe deeply in the universal character of all intellectual	activity we would be less than honest with you or ourselves	if we failed to state a specific attitude toward our own society as	well as the international community as a whole.	4.691176676699402

2124. like yourselves we have pride and love for our country.	6.703604640584531

2127. the sane society is an ambitious work.	4.280553672808819
2128. its scope is as	broad as the question: what does it mean to live in modern society?	6.467201377941844
2129. 	a work so broad even when it is directed by a leading idea and informed	by a moral vision must necessarily fail.	3.9267869418887815
2130. even a hasty reader	will easily find in it numerous blind spots errors of fact and	argument important exclusions areas of ignorance and prejudice undue	emphases on trivia examples of broad positions supported by flimsy	evidence and the like.	4.663685780653277
2131. such books are easy prey for critics.	5.720075445684095
2132. nor need	the critic be captious.	9.260665106749666
2133. a careful and orderly man who values precision	and a kind of tough intellectual responsibility might easily be	put off by such a book.	3.7661783646255764
2134. it is a simple matter for one so disposed to	take a work like the sane society and shred it into odds and	ends.	5.2485402392723435
2135. the thing can be made to look like the cluttered attic of a large	and vigorous family- a motley jumble of discarded objects some outworn	and some that were never useful some once whole and bright but	now chipped and tarnished some odd pieces whose history no one remembers	here and there a gem everything fascinating because it suggests	some part of the human condition- the whole adding up to nothing more	than a glimpse into the disorderly history of the makers and users.	3.3372978688781414
2136. that could be easily done but there is little reason in it.	8.713701002800855
