2432. a poem by dylan	thomas a saxophone solo by charles parker a painting by jackson	pollock- these are pure confabulations as ends in themselves.	4.73375195894849
2433. confabulation	has come to determine structure.	5.619635421798327
2434. uninhibited lyricism should	be distinguished from its exact opposite- the sterile extraneous	invention of the corn-belt metaphysicals or present blight of poetic	professors.	4.861416487662795
2435. just as hart crane had little influence on anyone	except very reactionary writers- like allen tate for instance	to whom valery was the last word in modern poetry and the felicities	of an apollinaire let alone a paul eluard were nonsense- so dylan	thomas's influence has been slight indeed.	3.2799255866871806
2436. in fact his only	disciple- the only person to imitate his style- was w s graham	who seems to have imitated him without much understanding and	who has since moved on to other methods.	5.044412331368424
2437. thomas's principal influence	lay in the communication of an attitude- that of the now extinct	british romantic school of the new apocalypse- henry treece j	f hendry and others- all of whom were quite conventional	poets.	3.938158273042053
2438. parker certainly had much more of an influence.	7.91403853425583
2439. at one	time it was the ambition of every saxophone player in every high school	band in america to blow like bird.	4.216592371030908
2440. even before his death this influence	had begun to ebb.	8.09201667589676
2441. in fact the whole generation of the founding	fathers of bop- gillespie monk davis blakey and the	rest-	are just now at a considerable discount.	4.103559666789241
2442. the main line of development	today goes back to lester young and by-passes them.	5.841002181891036
2443. the point	is that many of the most impressive developments in the arts nowadays	are aberrant idiosyncratic.	5.262980537675642
2444. there is no longer any sense of continuing	development of the sort that can be traced from baudelaire to	eluard or for that matter from hawthorne through henry james to	gertrude stein.	5.980960159356516
2445. the cubist generation before world war 1 and	on a lower level the surrealists of the period between the wars both	assumed an accepted universe of discourse in which to quote andre	breton it was possible to make definite advances exactly as in the	sciences.	3.4192850500882788
2446. i doubt if anyone holds such ideas today.	7.633187733199164
2447. continuity exits	but like the neo-swing music developed from lester young it is	a continuity sustained by popular demand.	3.685338251241182
2448. in the plastic arts	a very similar situation exists.	7.058866214174952
2449. surrealists like hans arp and max	ernst might talk of creation by hazard- of composing pictures by	walking on them with painted soles or by tossing bits of paper up in	the air.	3.2653762695140407
2450. but it is obvious that they were self-deluded.	11.022760091001807
2451. nothing looks	anything like an ernst or an arp but another ernst or arp.	4.317614708512467
2452. nothing	looks less like their work than the happenings of random occasion.	5.739974350684024
2453. many of the post-world war 2 abstract expressionists apostles	of the discipline of spontaneity and hazard look alike and do look	like accidents.	4.105675319585626
2454. the aesthetic appeal of pure paint laid on at random	may exist but it is a very impoverished appeal.	6.0802154349821365
2455. once again what has	happened is an all-consuming confabulation of the incidentals the accidents	of painting.	4.457074832017884
2456. it is curious that at its best the work of this	school of painting- mark rothko jackson pollock clyfford still	robert motherwell willem de-kooning and the rest- resembles	nothing so much as the passage painting of quite unimpressive painters:	the mother-of-pearl shimmer in the background of a henry mcfee	itself a formula derived from renoir; the splashes of light and	black which fake drapery in the fashionable imitators of hals and sargent.	4.510100777827486
2457. often work of this sort is presented as calligraphy- the pure	utterance of the brush stroke seeking only absolute painteresque values.	3.9433707971683143
2458. you have only to compare such painting with the work of say	sesshu to realize that someone is using words and brushes carelessly.	6.335979770305357
2459. at its best the abstract expressionists achieve a simple rococo	decorative surface.	4.699750026330829
2460. its poverty shows up immediately when compared	with tiepolo where the rococo rises to painting of extraordinary profundity	and power.	5.287357895345115
2461. a tiepolo painting however confabulated is a	universe of tensions in vast depths.	4.033407084863062
2462. a pollock is an object of art-	bijouterie- disguised only by its great size.	5.404383207843004
2463. in fact once the size	is big enough to cover a whole wall it turns into nothing more than	extremely expensive wallpaper.	3.985664505564643
2464. now there is nothing wrong with complicated	wallpaper.	10.607191029628995
2465. there is just more to tiepolo.	6.635859572537576
2466. the great ashikaga	brush painters painted wallpapers too- at least portable ones	screens.	5.764057425862458
2467. a process of elimination which leaves the artist with	nothing but the play of his materials themselves cannot sustain interest	in either artist or public for very long.	3.517573447921184
2468. so in the last couple	of years abstract expressionism has tended toward romantic suggestion-	indications of landscape or living figures.	6.367320877995432
2469. anglo-saxon and greek epic each provide on two occasions	a seemingly authentic account of the narration of verse in the heroic	age.	3.6293302210817977
2470. hrothgar's court bard sings of the encounters at finnsburg	and improvises the tale of beowulf's exploits in	a complimentary comparison of the geatish visitor with sigemund	; alcinou^s' court bard sings of the discovered adultery	of ares and aphrodite and takes up	a tale of odysseus while the ithacan wanderer listens on	.	4.214965621865877
2471. nothing in all this is autobiographical: unlike	the poets of deor and widsith the poet of beowulf is	not concerned with his own identity; the poet of the odyssey	reputed blind reveals himself not at all in singing of the blind minstrel	demodocus.	3.78893445195082
2472. since none of these glimpses of poetizing without writing	is intended to incorporate a signature into the epic matter there	is prima-facie evidence that beowulf and the homeric poems each	derive from an oral tradition.	4.766640660954833
2473. that such a tradition lies behind	the iliad and the odyssey at least is hard to deny.	4.652114854522662
2474. milman	parry rigorously defended the observation that the extant homeric	poems are largely formulaic and was led to postulate that they could	be shown entirely formulaic if the complete corpus of greek epic survived;	he further reasoned that frequent formulas in epic verse indicate	oral composition and assumed the slightly less likely corollary	that oral epic is inclined towards the use of formulas.	4.29930144644441
2475. proceeding from	parry's conclusions and adopting one of his schemata francis p	magoun jr argues that beowulf likewise was created from	a legacy of oral formulas inherited and extended by bards of successive	generations and the thesis is striking and compelling.	3.314406960956084
2476. yet a fresh	inspection will indicate one crucial amendment: beowulf and	the homeric poems are not at all formulaic to the same extent.	6.014928990302228
2477. the bondage endurable by an oral poet is to be estimated only by a	very skilful oral poet but it appears safe to assume that no sustained	narrative in rhyme could be composed without extreme difficulty even	in a language of many terminal inflections.	3.2739960022737784
2478. assonance seems nearly	as severe a curb although in a celebrated passage william of malmesbury	declares that a song of roland was intoned before the battle	commenced at hastings.	4.622632268446216
2479. the anglo-saxon alliterative line and the	homeric hexameter probably imposed less of a restraint; the verse	of beowulf or of the iliad and the odyssey was not easy	to create but was not impossible for poets who had developed their talents	perforce in earning a livelihood.	3.1556273147309257
2480. yet certain aids were valuable	and quite credibly necessary for reciting long stretches of verse without	a pause.	5.623753058039811
2481. the poet in a written tradition who generally never blots	a line may once in a while pause and polish without incurring blame.	3.2711328379838163
2482. but the oral poet cannot pause; he must improvise continuously	with no apparent effort.	6.007673384703963
2483. even though the bondage of his verse is not	so great as the writing poet can manage it is still great enough for	him often to be seriously impeded unless he has aids to facilitate rapid	composition.	3.7294568266130463
2484. the germanic poet had such aids in the kennings which	provided for the difficulties of alliteration; the homeric poet	had epithets which provided for recurring needs in the hexameter.	4.563260486724028
2485. either	poet could quickly and easily select words or phrases to supply	his immediate requirements as he chanted out his lines because the kennings	and the epithets made possible the construction of systems of numerous	synonyms for the chief common and proper nouns.	3.214582740864731
2486. other synonyms	could of course serve the same function and for the sake of ease i	shall speak of kennings and epithets in the widest and loosest poss1ble	sense and name for example gar-dene a kenning for the danes.	4.8642088119208635
2487. verbal and adverbial elements too participated in each epic diction	but it is for the present sufficient to mark the large nominal and	adjectival supply of semantic near-equivalents and to designate the	members of any system of equivalents as basic formulas of the poetic	language.	3.3969269980500933
2488. limited to a few thousand lines of heroic verse in anglo-saxon	as in the other germanic dialects we cannot say how frequently	the kennings in beowulf recurred in contemporary epic on the same	soil.	4.903939752620039
2489. but we can say that since a writing poet with leisure before	him would seem unlikely to invent a technique based upon frequent and	substantial circumlocution the kennings like the epithets must reasonably	be ascribed to an oral tradition.	3.448938765462612
2490. one of the greatest	homerists of our time frederick m combellack argues that when	it is assumed the iliad and the odyssey are oral poems the	postulated single redactor called homer cannot be either credited with	or denied originality in choice of phrasing.	4.65853184903839
2491. any example of grand	or exquisite diction may have been created by the poet who compiled numerous	lays into the two works we possess or may be due to one of his	completely	unknown fellow-craftsmen.	3.957669559073923
2492. the quest of the historical homer	is likely never to have further success; no individual word in the	iliad or the odyssey can be credited to any one man; no strikingly	effective element of speech in the extant poems can with assurance	be said not to have been a commonplace in the vaster epic corpus	that may have existed at the beginning of the first millennium before	christ.	4.605206450555311
2493. this observation is of interest not only to students of homeric	poetry but to students of anglo-saxon poetry as well.	3.9011603678732576
2494. to the	extent that a tale is twice told its final author must be suspect although	plagiarism in an oral tradition is less a misdemeanor than the	standard modus dicendi.	4.729676241752395
2495. combellack argues further and here	he makes his main point that once the iliad and the odyssey	are thought formulaic poems composed for an audience accustomed to	formulaic poetry homeric critics are deprived of an entire domain they	previously found arable.	3.188358338318412
2496. with a few important and a few more unimportant	exceptions no expression can be deemed le mot juste for its	context because each was very probably the only expression that long-established	practice and ease of rapid recitation would allow.	4.945917469850835
2497. words	or phrases that connoisseurs have admired as handsome or ironic or	humorous must therefore lose merit and become regarded as mere inevitable	time-servers sometimes accurate and sometimes not.	3.3515864650355898
2498. this observation	too may have reference to anglo-saxon poetry.	6.600382403185883
2499. to the extent that	a language is formulaic its individual components must be regarded	as no more distinguished than other cliches.	4.158424170708115
2500. w f bryan	suggests that certain kennings in beowulf were selected sometimes	for appropriateness and sometimes for ironic inappropriateness but	such a view would appear untenable unless it is denied that the language	of beowulf is formulaic.	4.428040294691671
2501. if the master of scops who was most	responsible for the poem ever used kennings that were traditional he	was at least partly deprived of free will and not inclined towards shrewd	and sophisticated misuse of speech elements.	3.4244659282132353
2502. once many significant	phrases are found in theory or in recurrent practice to provide for	prosodic necessity they are not to be defended for their semantic properties	in isolated contexts.	5.8827338453512485
2503. it is false to be certain of having discovered	in the language of beowulf such effects as intentional irony.	4.121308220480805
2504. yet if the argument is turned awry there may be found a	great deal in bryan's view after all.	5.850325114284141
2505. a formulaic element need not	be held meaningless merely because it was selected with little conscious	reflection.	4.087980982007486
2506. time-servers though the periphrastic expressions are	they may nevertheless be handsome or ironic or humorous.	5.331440467598945
2507. a long evolution	in an oral tradition caused the poetic language of the heroic	age to be based upon formulas that show the important qualities of things	and these formulas are therefore potentially rather than always actually	accurate.	3.3832813169678695
2508. true we do not know how they were regarded in their	day but we need not believe the epic audience to have been more insensitive	to the formulas than the numerous scholars of modern times who	have read germanic or homeric poetry all their lives and still found	much to admire in occasional occurrences of the most familiar phrases.	5.033034880903297
2509. nouns and adjectives in a written tradition are chosen for the nonce;	in an oral tradition they may be chosen for the entire epic corpus	and tend towards idealization rather than distinctive delineation.	3.4860179279479935
2510. reliance is therefore not to be placed upon the archaeological particulars	in an oral poem; no-one today would hope to discover the unmistakable	ruins of heorot or the palace of priam.	4.912808192259401
2511. a ship at dry-dock	could be called a foamy-necked floater in anglo-saxon or a swift	ship in greek.	3.812991877133981
2512. even when defenseless of weapons the danes would be	gar-dene and priam would be |e|u|m|m|e|l|i|h|s.	6.154261912120119
2513. achilles like siegfried in the nibelungenlied	is potentially the swiftest of men and may accordingly	be called swift-footed even when he stands idle.	3.587426875308265
2514. in coriolanus	the agnomen of marcius is used deliberately and pointedly but the	homeric epithets and the anglo-saxon kennings are used casually and	recall to the hearer a familiar story or situation or a useful or	pleasant quality of the referent.	4.607447647353628
2515. the epic language was not entirely	the servant of the poet; it was partly his master.	3.5177069743400518
2516. the poet's	intentions are difficult to discern and except to biographers unimportant;	the language however is a proper object of scrutiny and the	effects of the language are palpable even if sometimes inevitable.	4.5056166070789105
2517. beowulf and the homeric poems appear oral compositions.	4.6724501027054846
2518. yet	they are written; at some stage in their evolution they were transcribed.	5.6380004005191555
2519. albert b lord suggests that the homeric poems were dictated	to a scribe by a minstrel who held in his mind the poems fully matured	but did not himself possess the knowledge of writing since it	would	be useless to his guild and magoun argues that the beowulf	poet and cynewulf may have dictated their verse in the same fashion.	3.277794593762794
2520. this explanation is attractive but is vitiated at least in part by	the observation that cynewulf though he used kennings in the traditional	manner was a literate man who four times inscribed his name by runes	into his works.	4.645492155498875
2521. if cynewulf was literate the beowulf poet	may have been also and so may the final redactor of the iliad and	the odyssey.	3.7192981579478324
2522. in lieu of the amanuensis to the blind or illiterate	bard one may conceive of a man who heard a vast store of oral poetry	recited and became intimately familiar with the established aids	to poetizing and himself wrote his own compositions or his edition of	the compositions of the past.	4.710083803632038
2523. other theories of origin are compatible	with the formulaic theory: beowulf may contain a design for	terror and the iliad may have a vast hysteron-proteron pattern answering	to a ceramic pattern produced during the geometric period in	pottery.	3.450316184911042
2524. the account of the growth and final transcription of these	epics rests partly however upon the degree to which they were formulaic.	5.509023301352352
2525. carl eduard schmidt counted 1804 different lines repeated	exactly in the two homeric poems and by increasing this figure so	as to include lines repeated with very slight modifications he counted	2118 different lines used a total of 5612 times.	3.3809043873292945
2526. thus one line in	five from the iliad and the odyssey is to be found somewhere	else in the two poems.	6.674107299884356
2527. the ratio is thoroughly remarkable because the	lines are so long- half again as long as those of beowulf.	3.891940575707934
2528. anglo-saxon	poetry appears to have no comparable amount of repetition;	there is no reason to think that the scop used and re-used whole lines	and even lengthy passages after the manner of his homeric colleague.	5.07323606529614
2529. in determining the extent to which any poem is formulaic it is idle	however to inspect nothing besides lines repeated in their entirety	for a stock of line-fragments would be sufficient to permit the poet	to extemporize with deftness if they provided for prosodic needs.	3.3743369727703008
2530. the closest scrutiny is owed to the anglo-saxon kennings and the homeric	epithets; if any words or phrases are formulaic they will be.	4.489155318941073
2531. the iliad has two words for the shield |a|s|p|i|s	and |s|a|k|o|s.	3.873635296338494
2532. recent criticism of great expectations has tended to emphasize	its symbolic and mythic content to show as m d zabel has	said of dickens generally that much of the novel's impact resides	in its allegoric insight and moral metaphor.	4.857107774351506
2533. j h miller's	excellent chapter on great expectations has lately illustrated	how fruitfully that novel can be read from such a perspective.	3.6436827247720274
2534. in his analysis however he touches upon but fails to explore an idea	generally neglected in discussions of the book which i believe is	central to its art- the importance of human hands as a recurring feature	of the narrative.	4.968540213083418
2535. this essay seeks to make that exploration.	5.569119605363294
2536. dickens was not for nothing the most theatrical of the great victorian	writers.	6.277662158503808
2537. he knew instinctively that next to voice and face an	actor's hands are his most useful possession- that in fiction as	in the theatre gesture is an indispensable shorthand for individualizing	character and dramatizing action and response.	3.3392966295180173
2538. it is hardly accidental	therefore that many of his most vivid figures do suggestive or	eccentric things with their hands.	6.063532480437199
2539. in great expectations the hands	become almost an obsession.	4.939479607666261
2540. mr jaggers habitually bites his	forefinger	a gesture which conveys both contempt and the inscrutable abstractedness	that half fascinates half terrifies all who have dealings with him.	4.846603700304824
2541. miss havisham's withered hands heavy as if her unhappiness were	somehow concentrated in them move in restless self-pity between her	broken heart and her walking stick.	3.584233017505336
2542. pumblechook's signature	is the perpetually extended glad hand.	6.743273855772659
2543. wemmick reveals his self-satisfaction	by regularly rubbing his hands together.	4.477601198394805
2544. old mr pocket's	frantic response to life imprisonment with a useless social-climbing	wife is to put his two hands into his disturbed hair and make	an extraordinary effort to lift himself up by it whereas	joe gargery endures the shrewish onslaughts of mrs joe by apologetically	drawing the back of his hand across and across his nose.	4.358138962888235
2545. such mannerisms would be less worthy of remark were it	not that in great expectations as in no other of dickens' novels	hands serve as a leitmotif of plot and theme- a kind of unifying	symbol or natural metaphor for the book's complex of human interrelationships	and the values and attitudes that motivate them.	3.439439173024857
2546. dickens	not only reveals character through gesture he makes hands a crucial	element of the plot a means of clarifying the structure of the novel	by helping to define the hero's relations with all the major characters	and a device for ordering such diverse themes as guilt pursuit	crime greed education materialism enslavement	friendship romantic love forgiveness and redemption.	4.542064706999979
2547. we have only to think of lady macbeth or the policeman-murderer	in thomas burke's famous story the hands of mr ottermole	to realize that hands often call up ideas of crime and punishment.	3.8558476834044573
2548. so it is with great expectations whether the hands be	orlick's	as he strikes down mrs gargery or pip's as he steals a	pie from her pantry.	5.188164490353615
2549. such associations suit well with the gothic or	mystery-story aspects of dickens' novel but on a deeper plane they	relate to the themes of sin guilt and pursuit that have recently	been analyzed by other critics.	3.414207047642511
2550. the novel opens with a fugitive	convict frantically trying to avoid the nemesis of being laid hands	on- a mysterious figure who looks into pip's frightened	eyes in the churchyard as if he were eluding the hands of the dead	people stretching up cautiously out of their graves to get a twist	upon his ankle and pull him in.	4.692250581022424
2551. magwitch terrifies pip into	stealing a pork pie for him by creating the image in the boy's imagination	of a bogy man who may softly creep h his way to him and tear	him open in him.	3.466480540174415
2552. as pip agonizes	over the theft that his own hands have committed his guilty conscience	projects itself upon the wooden finger of a local signpost transforming	it into a phantom devoting me to the hulks.	4.924834260142421
2553. held	upside down in the graveyard pip clings in terror with both hands	to his convict; later he flees in panic from the family table	just as his theft is about to be discovered and is blocked at the	front door by a soldier who accusingly holds out a pair of handcuffs which	he has brought to gargery's forge for mending.	3.2754584981480317
2554. through such details	dickens indicates at the outset that guilt is a part of the ironic	bond between pip and magwitch which is so unpredictably to alter	both their lives.	5.703605346905786
2555. since they commonly translate thoughts and	feelings into deeds hands naturally represent action and since nearly	half the characters in great expectations are of the underworld	or closely allied to it the linking of hands with crime or violence	is not to be wondered at.	3.5413992418161135
2556. dickens for excellent psychological reasons	never fully reveals magwitch's felonious past but pip at the	convict's climactic reappearance in london shrinks from clasping	a hand which he fears might be stained with blood.	4.481223380679198
2557. orlick	slouches about the forge like cain with his hands in his pockets	and when he shouts abuse at mrs joe for objecting	to his holiday she claps her hands in a tantrum beats them upon her	bosom and upon her knees and clenches them in her husband's	hair.	3.1860275258183326
2558. this last rampage is only the prelude to the vicious	blow upon her head dealt by some unknown hand whose identity	is later revealed not verbally but through a manual action- the tracing	of orlick's hammer upon a slate.	4.534415220077208
2559. pip himself is to feel the	terror of orlick's murderous hand in his secret rendezvous	at the sluicehouse on the marshes.	3.5853166747464886
2560. dickens lays great emphasis on	the hands in this scene.	6.144814417540349
2561. orlick shakes his hand at pip bangs the table	with his fist draws his unclenched hand across his mouth as if	his mouth watered for his victim lets his hands hang loose and	heavy at his sides and pip observes him so intensely that he knows	of the slightest action of his fingers.	3.0444225021029774
2562. orlick might almost	be magwitch's bogy man come alive a figure of nemesis from pip's	phantasy of guilt.	5.267194435410776
2563. the scarred disfigured wrists of mr	jaggers' housekeeper are the tell-tale marks of her sinister	past for her master coolly exhibiting them to his dinner guests makes	a point of the force of grip there is in these hands.	3.282890559296826
2564. jaggers'	iron control over her	any dish she put before him hesitatingly as if she dreaded his calling	rests on his having once got her acquitted	of a murder charge by cleverly contriving her sleeves at the trial to	conceal her strength and by passing off the lacerations on the backs	of her hands as the scratches of brambles rather than of human fingernails.	4.173215468926734
2565. it is the similarity between estella's hands and molly's	that provides pip with a vital clue to the real identity of both and	establishes a symbolic connection between the underworld of crime and	the genteel cruelty of satis house.	3.569165267170449
2566. finally magwitch's pursuit	of compeyson his archenemy and betrayer begins by his holding him	in a vicelike grip on the river flats to frustrate his escape and culminates	in his laying his hand on his cloak to identify him	thus precipitating the death-locked struggle in the water during which	compeyson drowns.	4.477830048779578
2567. magwitch's hand here ironically becomes the agent	of justice.	4.6724501027054846
2568. but only in one of its aspects is great expectations	a tale of violence revenge and retribution.	6.6182689678617646
2569. money so	important a theme elsewhere in dickens is here central and hands are	often associated in some way with the false values- acquisitiveness	snobbery self-interest hypocrisy toadyism irresponsibility injustice-	that attach to a society based upon the pursuit of wealth.	3.3635831713296227
2570. dickens suggests	the economic evils of such a society on the first page	of his novel in the description of pip's five little dead brothers	who gave up trying to get a living exceedingly early in that universal	struggle who seemed to have all been born on their backs	with their hands in their trousers-pockets and had never taken them	out	in this state of existence.	4.842217318366729
2571. pip's great expectations his	progress through illusion and disillusionment turn somewhat as they	do for the naive hero of dreiser's american tragedy upon	the	lure of genteel prosperity through unearned income- what wemmick calls	portable property and what jaggers reproaches pip for letting	slip through his fingers.	3.113042431664915
2572. since a gentleman	must if possible avoid sullying them by work his hands as importantly	as his accent become the index of social status.	5.130552176600155
2573. almost the first	step in the corruption of pip's values is the unworthy shame he	feels when estella cruelly remarks the coarseness of his hands: they	had never troubled me before but they troubled me now as vulgar	appendages.	3.3119027646840338
2574. pip imagines how estella would look down upon	joe's hands roughened by work in the smithy and the deliberate contrast	between her white hands and his blackened ones is made to symbolize	the opposition of values between which pip struggles- idleness	and work artificiality and naturalness gentility and commonness coldness	and affection- in fact between satis house and the forge.	4.3768964593780995
2575. when the snobbery that alienates pip from joe finally gives way before	the deeper and stronger force of love the reunion is marked by an	embarrassed handshake at which pip exclaims no don't wipe it	off- for god's sake give me your blackened hand!	pip's abject leave-taking of miss havisham during which he kneels	to kiss her hand signalizes his homage to a supposed patroness who	seems to be opening up for him a new world of glamour; when on the	journey to london that immediately follows he pauses nostalgically	to lay his hand upon the finger-post at the end of the village the wooden	pointer symbolically designates a spiritual frontier between innocence	and the corruption of worldly vanity.	3.065710877715331
2576. incidentally one cannot	miss the significance of this gesture for dickens reintroduces it associatively	in pip's mind at another moral and psychological crisis-	his painful recognition in a talk with herbert pocket that his	hopeless attachment to estella is as self-destructive as it is romantic.	4.883726298369852
2577. in both cases the finger-post represents pip's heightened awareness	of contrary magnetisms.	4.995232012157048
2578. a variety of hand movements helps	dramatize the moral climate of the fallen world pip encounters beyond	the forge.	5.667362091139212
2579. the vulturelike attendance of the pocket family upon	miss havisham is summed up in the hypocritical gestures of miss camilla	pocket who puts her hand to her throat in a feigned spasm of	grief-stricken choking then lays it upon her heaving bosom with	an unnatural fortitude of manner and finally kisses it to	miss havisham in a parody of the lady's own mannerism toward estella.	3.073618015009534
2580. pumblechook's hands throughout the novel serve to travesty greed	and hypocritical self-aggrandizement.	5.739974350684024
2581. we first see him shaking mrs	joe's hand on discovering the sizable amount of the premium paid	to her husband for pip's indenture as an apprentice and later pumping	pip's hands for the hundredth time at least	in effusive congratulation to pip on	his expectations.	3.25511140940159
2582. we take leave of pumblechook as he gloats over pip's	loss of fortune extending his hand with a magnificently forgiving	air and exhibiting the same fat five fingers one of which	he identifies with the finger of providence and shakes at pip	in a canting imputation of the latter's ingratitoode and	his own generosity as pip's earliest benefactor.	4.2575030667353335
2583. pip first learns the stupendous power of money from the	sycophantic tailor mr trabb whose brutality to his boy helper exactly	matches	the financial resource of each new customer and whose fawning	hands touch the outside of each elbow and rub	pip out of the shop.	3.3674284239272274
2584. the respectability which money confers implies	a different etiquette and upon taking up the life of a london gentleman	pip must learn from herbert pocket that the spoon is not generally	used over-hand but under.	4.584440355775043
2585. the following items may be specified in actual or symbolic form in the	operands of those instructions which refer to the particular items:	channel unit combined channel and unit combined arm and file unit	record synchronizers inquiry synchronizers and alteration switches.	3.2344944752712403
2586. the declarative operation equ is used to equate symbolic names	to item numbers.	5.63118571888574
2587. certain autocoder	statements make provision for more parameters than may be contained	in the operand of a single line on the autocoder	coding sheet.	3.6512723635703526
2588. when this is the case the appropriate section of this	manual will indicate that continuation cards may be used.	6.661805226300341
2589. thus	when specifically permitted the operand of a given line on the autocoder	coding sheet may be continued in the operand of from one to	four additional lines which immediately follow.	3.4160442230177934
2590. the label and	operation columns must be blank and the continuation of the operand	must begin in column 21; ie it must be left-justified in the	operand column of the coding sheet.	4.667285061932153
2591. the operand need not extend across	the entire operand column of either the header card or continuation	cards but may end with the comma following any parameter.	3.2680496116419313
2592. remarks may	appear to the right of the last parameter on each card provided they	are separated from the operand by at least two blank spaces.	6.1548879944251516
2593. illustration	of the use of continuation cards are included throughout the	examples illustrating the various statements.	4.496372313877282
2594. if a continuation	card follows a statement that does not permit continuation cards	the compiler will generate a nop and issue an error message.	5.556207795268219
2595. additional	restrictions regarding the use of continuation cards with macro-instructions	appear on page 106.	4.795548250448698
2596. electronic switches	the assignment of actual addresses to symbolic	index word and electronic switch names occurs in phase 3 of the	autocoder processor.	4.861416487662795
2597. the initial availability of index words and electronic	switches is determined by a table which is included in the compiler	systems tape.	3.654600125336438
2598. this table originally indicates that index words	1 through 96 and electronic switches 1 through 30 are available for	assignment to symbolic references; index words 97 through 99 are	not available.	4.585766400110222
2599. the initial setting of this table may be altered however	as described in the 70707074 data processing system bulletin	ibm 70707074 compiler system: operating procedure	form j28-6105.	3.3181748516739686
2600. during the first pass of phase 3 references	to the actual addresses of index words and electronic switches	are collected and the availability table is updated.	5.333751433572961
2601. at the end	of this pass the table indicates which index words and electronic switches	are not available for assignment to symbolic references.	3.796769213186821
2602. both index words and electronic switches may have been made unavailable	before the start of assignment in one of the following ways:	the initial setting of the availability table indicated that the	index word or electronic switch was not available for assignment.	5.500001555589773
2603. the one- two-digit number of the index word or electronic switch	was used in the operand of a symbolic machine instruction to specify	indexing or as a parameter which is always an index word or electronic	switch eg   the one- or two-digit number of	the index word or electronic switch was used in the operand of an equ	statement eg    when the index words or electronic	switches are reserved because of actual usage in the statements	described above the position or order of the statements within the program	is not important; any such reference will make the index word	or electronic switch unavailable at the end of this pass.	3.2164646417695932
2604. during	the assignment pass of phase 3 index words and electronic switches	are reserved as they are encountered during assignment.	5.677675727989302
2605. index	words and electronic switches may be reserved in the following ways.	4.556724863803106
2606. the first two methods apply to both index words and electronic switches;	the third applies only to index words.	5.536084174799315
2607. during the assignment	pass each instruction is examined for reference to the symbolic	name of an index word or electronic switch.	4.2110051882307555
2608. when such a reference	is found an actual address is assigned and the availability table is	changed so that the assigned index word or switch is no longer available	for later assignment.	5.345897023945526
2609. if the one- or two-digit address of	an index word or electronic switch is used or is included in the operand	of an xreserve or sreserve statement	the corresponding index word or electronic switch is reserved.	3.5346594999546803
2610. if a statement has been assigned an address in the index word	area  by means of an	origin statement which refers to an actual address the	corresponding index word will be reserved.	5.158111217937675
2611. these entries should normally	appear at the beginning of the program or immediately following each	litorigin statement.	5.208894926609246
2612. otherwise symbolic names may have	previously been assigned to these same index words.	6.0729446567627745
2613. the preceding methods allow	efficient use of index words and electronic switches during a sectionalized	or multi-phase program particularly when used in conjunction	with the litorigin statement.	3.3189567747104705
2614. extreme caution should	be used however to avoid the conflicting usage of an index word or electronic	switch which may result from the assignment of more than one	name or function to the same address.	5.111760828230261
2615. if the symbolic name or	actual address of an index word or electronic switch appears or is included	in the operand of an xrelease or srelease	statement the specified index word or electronic switch	will again be made available regardless of the method by which it	was reserved.	3.322996349651052
2616. it will not however be used for symbolic assignment until	all other index words or electronic switches have been assigned for	the first time.	5.898928317744477
2617. if at any time during the assignment pass	the compiler finds that there are no more index words available for assignment	the warning message no more index words available	will be placed in the object program listing the table will be altered	to show that index words 1 through 96 are available and the assignment	will continue as before.	3.609946498771787
2618. if the compiler finds that there are	no more electronic switches available for assignment the warning message	no more electronic switches available will be placed in	the object program listing the table will be altered to show that electronic	switches 1 through 30 are available and assignment will continue	as before.	4.627395696314482
2619. the resultant conflicting usage of index words or electronic	switches may be avoided by reducing the number of symbolic names	used eg through the proper use of the equ xrelease	or srelease statements.	3.9558549644649315
2620. as noted in appendix	c index words 97 through 99 are never available for assignment	to symbolic names by the compiler; also index words 93 through	96 may have been made unavailable for assignment.	5.035142386117929
2621. statements	autocoder declarative statements provide the processor	with the necessary information to complete the imperative operations	properly.	3.8849121559715263
2622. declarative statements are never executed in the object program	and should be separated from the program instruction area placed	preferably at its beginning or end.	4.714137561967006
2623. otherwise special care must be	taken to branch around them so that the program will not attempt to execute	something in a data area as an instruction.	3.9102056617741963
2624. if the compiler does	encounter such statements a warning message will be issued.	6.197852301026256
2625. 70707074	autocoder includes the following declarative statements: da	dc drdw	dsw dline	equ code dtf	diocs	and duf.	4.0683852436856025
2626. da dc	dtf and dline require more than one entry.	7.252162285116746
2627. the da statement is used to name and define the positions and	length of fields within an area.	3.709395804549459
2628. the dc statement is used to name	and enter constants into the object program.	5.492517946490919
2629. since the 7070 and 7074	make use of record definition words to read write move	and otherwise examine blocks of storage the da and dc statements	provide the option of generating rdws automatically.	3.511810433270544
2630. when so instructed autocoder will generate one or more rdws	and assign them successive locations immediately preceding the area	with which they are to be associated.	6.030858320170726
2631. an rdw will be of the	form f where xxxx is the starting location of the area and yyyy	is its ending location.	4.277352888440706
2632. these addresses are calculated automatically	by the processor.	7.27148984511837
2633. in some cases it may be more advantageous	to assign locations to rdws associated with da and dc	areas in some other part of storage ie not immediately preceding	the da or dc areas.	3.927671301072172
2634. the drdw statement may be	used for this purpose.	5.650577481330174
2635. the drdw statement may also be used to	generate an rdw defining any area specified by the programmer.	3.7816762416673746
2636. as many as ten digital switches may be named and provided	by the dsw statement for consideration by the setsw and	logic macro-instructions.	5.5410965861943735
2637. each switch occupies one digit position	in a word can be set on or off and is considered	as logically equivalent to an electronic switch.	3.627869846009788
2638. it cannot however	be referred to by electronic switch commands eg esn bsn	etc.	6.313086495667379
2639. an individual switch or the entire set of switches in	a word may be tested or altered as desired.	3.80936245007775
2640. through use of	the dline statement a means is provided for specifying both	the editing of fields to be inserted in a print line area and the layout	of the area itself.	4.830631225468638
2641. the area may include constant information supplied	by the programmer.	4.476748791562384
2642. the area may also be provided with additional	data during the running of the object program by means of edmov	or move macro-instructions.	5.52510076966727
2643. the declarative statement	equ permits the programmer to equate symbolic names to actual	index words electronic switches arm and file numbers tape channel	and unit numbers alteration switches etc and to equate a symbol	to another symbol or to an actual address.	3.0344204261226424
2644. the diocs	dtf and duf statements are used when required by the inputoutput	control system.	4.983240996215937
2645. diocs is used to select the major	methods of processing to be used and to name the index words used	by iocs.	4.213283561414565
2646. each tape file must be described by tape file specifications	produced by dtfs.	6.071224567134386
2647. in addition to information related	to the file and its records the file specifications contain subroutine	locations and the location of tape label information.	3.996418208974855
2648. a duf	entry must be supplied for every unit record file describing the type	of file and the unit record equipment to be used.	4.80996771909749
2649. the duf also	supplies the locations of subroutines written by the user that are	unique to the file.	3.50677758235622
2650. a full description of the diocs	dtf and duf statements is contained in the 7070 data processing	system bulletin ibm 7070 inputoutput control system	form j28-6033-1.	5.407528253450359
2651. brief descriptions of these three declarative	statements and detailed descriptions of the formats and functions	of each of the other 70707074 autocoder declarative statements follow	below.	4.095910554837393
2652. when	the inputoutput control system is to be used in a program a	diocs statement must be used to select the major methods of processing	to be used.	6.5374975382738825
2653. this statement also allows the naming of the index	words used by iocs.	4.269761367400614
2654. the basic	format of the diocs statement is as follows:  anylabel	is any symbolic label; it may be omitted.	5.25403774386004
2655. the entry diocs	must be written exactly as shown.	4.1174608023645085
2656. the first item in the	operand iocsixf is used to specify the first iocs index	word for programs using tape files.	5.462758257373802
2657. this item may be a symbolic	name or an actual one-digit or two-digit index word address in the range	3-94.	4.048017981814048
2658. if the first item in the operand is omitted the symbolic name	iocsixf will be assigned.	5.7035995234404915
2659. when an actual index word or a	symbolic address is specified autocoder will equate the name iocsixf	to it.	3.9503556363661336
2660. the second item in the operand iocsixg	is used to specify the second iocs index word for programs	using tape files.	5.011869889604735
2661. this item may be a symbolic name or an actual one-digit	or two-digit index word address in the range 3-94.	3.9764234169967625
2662. if the second	item in the operand is omitted the symbolic name iocsixg	will be assigned.	5.850066769124922
2663. when an actual index word or a symbolic address	is specified autocoder will equate iocsixg to it.	4.027312145857736
2664. in the midwest oxidation ponds are used extensively for the treatment	of domestic sewage from suburban areas.	5.593931972473908
2665. the high cost of land	and a few operational problems resulting from excessive loadings have	created the need for a wastewater treatment system with the operational	characteristics of the oxidation pond but with the ability to treat	more organic matter per unit volume.	3.692928082414203
2666. research at fayette missouri	on oxidation ponds has shown that the bod in the treated	effluent varied from 30 to 53 mgl with loadings from 8 to	120 lb boddayacre.	4.7109898582590555
2667. since experience indicates that effluents	from oxidation ponds do not create major problems at these bod	concentrations the goal for the effluent quality of the accelerated	treatment system was the same as from conventional oxidation ponds.	3.7120759108068073
2668. recent studies by weston and stack had indicated that a turbine	aerator could be added to an oxidation pond to increase the rate of oxygen	transfer.	5.34574881953708
2669. their study showed that it was possible to transfer 3	to 4 lb of oxygenhrhp.	4.660089355027404
2670. o'connor and eckenfelder	discussed the use of aerated lagoons for treating organic wastes.	6.581147521563909
2671. they indicated that a 4-day retention aerated lagoon would give 60	to 76 per cent bod reduction.	4.106300382549409
2672. later eckenfelder increased	the efficiency of treatment to between 75 and 85 per cent in the summer	months.	6.2199081750369976
2673. it appeared from the limited information available that the	aerated lagoon might offer a satisfactory means of increasing the capacity	of existing oxidation ponds as well as providing the same degree	of treatment in a smaller volume.	3.624521173746867
2674. with	the development of the red bridge subdivision south of kansas city	missouri the developer was faced with the problem of providing adequate	sewage disposal.	6.575169754391627
2675. the sewage system from kansas city was not	expected to serve the red bridge area for several years.	3.487388510322654
2676. this necessitated	the construction of temporary sewage treatment facilities with	an expected life from 5 to 15 yr.	5.228155654399123
2677. for the initial development an	oxidation pond was constructed as shown in figure 1.	4.983329210158887
2678. the oxidation pond	has a surface area of 4.	5.650577481330174
2679. 77 acres and a depth of 4 ft.	4.6724501027054846
2680. the pond	is currently serving 1230 persons or 260 persons per acre.	5.187735111958531
2681. in the summer	of 1960 the oxidation pond became completely septic and emitted	obnoxious odors.	4.2488020146845535
2682. it was possible to maintain aerobic conditions in the	pond by regular additions of sodium nitrate until the temperature decreased	and the algae population changed from blue-green to green algae.	4.750497075489872
2683. the anaerobic conditions in the existing oxidation pond	necessitated examination of other methods for supplying additional oxygen	than by sodium nitrate.	3.3564185518874785
2684. at the same time further expansion in the	red bridge subdivision required the construction of additional sewage	treatment facilities.	6.458002924284277
2685. the large land areas required for oxidation	ponds made this type of treatment financially unattractive to the developer.	3.9172811902434055
2686. it was proposed that aerated lagoons be used to eliminate the	problem at the existing oxidation ponds and to provide the necessary	treatment for the additional development.	5.638380598617593
2687. the lack	of adequate data on the aerated lagoon system prompted the developer	to construct an aerated lagoon pilot plant to determine its feasibility	for treating domestic sewage.	3.33646931496923
2688. the pilot plant was a circular lagoon	81 ft in diam at the surface and 65 ft in diam at the bottom	4 ft below the surface with a volume of 121000 gal.	4.400956818388731
2689. the	side slopes were coated with fiberglas matting coated with asphalt to	prevent erosion.	4.0683852436856025
2690. the pilot lagoon was located as shown in figure 1	to serve the area just south of the existing housing area.	5.062135473260568
2691. the major	contributor was a shopping center with houses being added to the system	as the subdivision developed.	3.94493572804161
2692. the pilot lagoon was designed to handle	the wastes from 314 persons with a 4-day aeration period.	4.848279856743894
2693. initially	the wastewater would be entirely from the shopping center with the	domestic sewage from the houses increasing over an 18-month period.	3.592527040520332
2694. this	operation would permit evaluation of the pilot plant with a slowly	increasing load over a reasonable period of time.	4.985333447698777
2695. the pilot	plant was equipped with a 3-hp turbine aerator.	4.339089847010241
2696. the	aerator had a variable-speed drive to permit operation through a range	of speeds.	5.583228874976599
2697. the sewage flow into the treatment plant was metered and	continuously recorded on 24-hr charts.	3.570845587849075
2698. the raw sewage was introduced	directly under the turbine aerator to insure maximum mixing of the	raw sewage with the aeration tank contents.	4.524657308186351
2699. the effluent was collected	through two pipes and discharged to the blue river through a surface	drainage ditch.	3.470558666016351
2700. composite samples were collected at	weekly intervals.	7.163184125958424
2701. the long retention period and the complete mixing	concept prevented rapid changes in either the mixed liquor or in the effluent.	4.102246525558196
2702. weekly samples would make any changes more readily discernible	than daily samples.	5.739974350684024
2703. the composite samples were normally collected	over a 6-hr period but an occasional 24-hr composite was made.	3.470558666016351
2704. examination of the operations of the shopping center permitted correlation	of the 6-hr composite samples with 24-hr operations.	5.139404540790458
2705. the	data indicated that the organic load during the 6-hr composites was	essentially 50 per cent of the 24-hr organic load.	4.368021377815322
2706. grab samples	were collected from the existing oxidation pond to determine its	operating conditions.	5.583228874976599
2707. efforts were made to take the grab samples at	random periods so that the mass of data could be treated as a 6-hr	composite sample.	4.30774910309319
2708. a single 24-hr composite sample indicated that the	sewage flow pattern and characteristics were typical.	5.288480479759236
2709. operations	the bod of the influent to the pilot plant varied	between 110 and 710 mgl with an average of 350 mgl.	3.9293402192171936
2710. this was equivalent to 240 mglbod on a 24-hr basis.	6.859434136514463
2711. the	bod of the raw sewage was typical of domestic sewage from a	subdivision.	4.285326150552956
2712. the bod in the effluent averaged 58 mgl a 76-per	cent reduction over the 24-hr period.	4.827508206929211
2713. examination of the data	in table 1 shows that a few samples contributed to raising the effluent	bod.	3.847263205000952
2714. the periods of high effluent bod occurred during	cold periods when operational problems with the aerator resulted.	4.762804453309085
2715. ice caused the aerator to overload straining the drive belts.	4.317068102383446
2716. the	slippage of the drive belts caused the aerator to slow down and reduce	oxygen transfer as well as the mixing of the raw sewage.	5.7621067543240345
2717. the	organic loading on the unit averaged 32 lb of bodday or about	2 lb bodday1000 cu ft aeration capacity.	3.632711015013689
2718. needless	to say the organic load was very low on a volumetric basis but was	270 lb boddayacre on a surface loading basis.	4.807873378411027
2719. it seems that	the aerated lagoon was a very heavily loaded oxidation pond or a lightly	loaded activated sludge system.	4.218303286579949
2720. the flow rate remained relatively	constant during the winter months as shown in table 1.	5.341250996940546
2721. with	the spring rains the flow rose rapidly due to infiltration in open	sewers.	4.102132295226146
2722. as construction progresses the volume of storm drainage will	be sharply reduced.	7.131783929225788
2723. the retention period in the aerated lagoon ranged	from 9.	3.9843222565600884
2724. 6 days averaging 6.	8.677302482075584
2725. the large amount	of vegetable grindings from the grocery store in the shopping center	created a suspended solids problem.	3.7356169100354437
2726. the vegetables were not readily metabolized	by the bacteria in the aeration unit and tended to float on	the surface.	4.653079438027171
2727. a skimming device at the effluent weir prevented loss of	most of these light solids.	3.8552083837030713
2728. the average volatile suspended solids in	the effluent was 75 mgl while mlss averaged 170 mgl	volatile suspended solids.	4.9294672226539955
2729. the average sludge age based on displacement	of solids was calculated to be 14.	3.8463616694480267
2730. the oxygen uptake rate	in the mixed liquor averaged 0.	5.4678654398730995
2731. 8 mglhr during the first	four months of this study.	4.8477274878269
2732. variations in aerator speeds during the latter	two months of this study caused increased mixing and increased oxygen	demand.	5.057556181613073
2733. the increase in oxygen uptake rates from 1.	4.935466254965754
2734. 6 mglhr	which followed an increase in rotor speed was believed to	be related to resuspension of solids which had settled at the lower	rotor speeds.	5.00730290339166
2735. it appeared that most of the mixed liquor suspended solids	were active microbial solids with the heavier less active solids	settling out.	4.421079472023096
2736. the suspended solids discharged in the effluent	were found to be the major source of the bod.	5.53779239425945
2737. removal of the suspended	solids by a membrane filter yielded an average effluent containing	only 20 mgl bod.	3.744109221929566
2738. the bod in the drainage ditch	receiving the pilot plant effluent averaged 12 mgl.	4.983240996215937
2739. this low bod	was due to removal of the excess suspended solids by sedimentation	since the only dilution was surface runoff which was very low during	this study.	3.41794617188886
2740. routine microscopic examinations	were made of the mixed liquor as indicated by mckinney and	gram for the various types of protozoa.	5.371513078576806
2741. it was found that the	aerated lagoon was an activated sludge system rather than an oxidation	pond.	4.212905676717951
2742. at no time were algae found in the mixed liquor.	8.250191029480348
2743. the bacteria	formed typical activated sludge floc.	4.484814815711922
2744. the floc particles were all small	as the heavier floc settled out.	5.187735111958531
2745. initially the flagellated	protozoa predominated but they soon gave way to the free swimming ciliated	protozoa.	4.90305544900944
2746. as the temperature decreased the number of free swimming	ciliated protozoa decreased.	7.85253180921311
2747. very little protozoa activity existed	below 40`f.	6.260548774951739
2748. when the temperature reached 32`f all protozoan	activity ceased; but as the temperature rose the numbers of	protozoa increased rapidly.	5.984762511696929
2749. only once were stalked ciliates found in	the mixed liquor.	5.1298183412245
2750. the predomination of free swimming ciliated protozoa	is indicative of a high bacterial population.	5.1450070816080435
2751. one of the important aspects of this study was to determine the oxygen	transfer relationships of the mechanical aerator.	4.575949596079474
2752. routine determinations	were made for dissolved oxygen in the mixed liquor and for oxygen	uptake rates.	5.367289396080528
2753. the data given in table 2 show the routine operation	of the aerator.	3.7002464386011096
2754. the dissolved oxygen in the aeration unit was consistently	high until january 29 1961.	4.983240996215937
2755. an extended cold spell caused	ice to build up on the aerator which was mounted on a floating platform	and caused the entire platform to sink lower in the water.	3.761446102210694
2756. the added	resistance to the rotor damaged the drive belts and reduced the oxygen	transfer capacity.	4.998913848101039
2757. it was approximately one month before the belt	problem was noticed and corrected but at no time was there a deficiency	of dissolved oxygen.	3.7374123583357464
2758. a series of eight special tests were	conducted at different rotor speeds to determine the oxygen transfer	rate.	6.196890478910967

2779. thus the three main categories of antisubmarine warfare operations	are defense of shipping defense of naval forces and area defense.	3.98208871260441
2780. the last category overlaps the others in amphibious operations and	near terminals and bases.	5.691691007657431
2781. to effect these operations five elements	exist	fixed installations.	5.423348419931135
2782. surface forces have been used to provide defense	zones around naval and merchant ship formations air to furnish area	surveillance and mines for protection of limited areas.	5.005038670471196
2783. submarines and	shore installations are new elements.	5.219666477665999
2784. the submarine now has a definite	place in submarine defense particularly in denying enemy access to	ocean areas.	4.762782422141702
2785. fixed installations offer possibilities for area detection.	4.913686410369733
2786. mine warfare is being reoriented against submarine targets.	6.412214371980113
2787. a sixth element not always considered is intelligence.	4.618964815664445
2788. it includes	operational intelligence of the enemy and knowledge of the environment.	7.79282656726
2789. operational intelligence presumably will be available from our	national intelligence agencies; intelligence on the environment will	come from the recently augmented program in oceanography.	3.467766426174774
2790. the major	postwar development is the certainty that these elements should not be	considered singly but in combination and as being mutually supporting.	4.524741011976274
2791. thinking on submarine defense	has not always been clear-cut.	4.6724501027054846
2792. proponents of single elements tend	to ensure predominance of that element without determining if it is justified	and the element with the most enthusiastic and vociferous proponents	has assumed the greatest importance.	5.090046709079396
2793. consequently air surface	and submarine elements overshadow the mine fixed installations	and intelligence.	4.215574404376171
2794. these have sought more and more of what they have.	8.233360385527586
2795. each seems to strive for elimination of the necessity for the others.	4.467112996019944
2796. this despite postwar experience demonstrating that all elements are	necessarily mutually supporting.	5.874336267393343
2797. thus the most productive areas are	not necessarily the most stressed.	5.3266967368183975
2798. this is stated to emphasize the necessity	for an over-all concept of submarine defense one which would	provide positions of relative importance to asw elements based on	projected potentialities.	5.124351896224234
2799. then the enthusiasm and energy of all elements	can be channeled to produce cumulative progress toward a common	objective.	4.1298075888652255
2800. an over-all concept would have other advantages.	7.420998401046182
2801. it would	allow presentation to the public of a unified approach.	5.58615949389162
2802. now the problem	is presented piecemeal and sometimes contradictorily.	7.886847157998231
2803. while one	element	is announcing progress another is delineating its problems.	4.982266224732081
2804. the	result can only be confusion in the public mind.	7.615785351857987
2805. a unified concept	can serve as a guide to budgeting and if public support is gained will	command congressional support.	3.9246312297202706
2806. industry's main criticism of the	navy's antisubmarine effort is that it cannot determine where any	one company or industry can apply its skills and know-how.	5.262167161787179
2807. lacking guidance	industry picks its own areas.	5.753418555381722
2808. the result coupled with the salesmanship	for which american industry is famous is considerable expenditure	of funds and efforts in marginal areas.	5.097680758930345
2809. an over-all concept	will guide industry where available talents and facilities will yield	greatest dividends.	4.224004506010002
2810. therefore a broad concept of over-all submarine	defense is needed for co-ordination of the navy's efforts for a logical	presentation to the public for industry's guidance and as a	basis for a program to the congress.	5.088399386915421
2811. concept	that which follows will be a discussion of principles	and possible content for an over-all concept of antisubmarine warfare.	4.1960125076960475
2812. russia possesses the preponderance of submarines in the world divided	between her various fleets.	6.8979654212949635
2813. some are also in albania and others	are on loan to egypt.	4.7195396680159005
2814. other countries which may willingly or unwillingly	become communist can furnish bases.	6.254968645394336
2815. communist target areas can	be assumed but there is no certainty that such assumptions coincide	with soviet intentions.	4.8335697995697755
2816. attack can come from almost any direction against	many locations.	6.144814417540349
2817. logically then the first principle of the plan	must be that it is not rigidly oriented toward any geographical area.	4.575084057535092
2818. it is often stated that the submarine can be destroyed while	building at bases in transit and on station.	5.37015738615747
2819. destruction of the enemy's	building and base complex however requires attacks on enemy	territory which is possible only in event of all-out hostilities.	3.808464369558499
2820. in	transit or on station it may not be possible to attack the submarines	until commission of an overt act.	5.814037129664659
2821. the communists are adept at utilizing	hostilities short of general war and will do so whenever it is	to their advantage.	3.6283482901876045
2822. therefore the second principle of the plan must be	that while providing for all-out hostilities its effectiveness is	not dependent on general war.	5.40021769498571
2823. antisubmarine warfare does not involve	clashes between large opposing forces with the decision a result	of a single battle.	3.685338251241182
2824. it is a war of attrition of single actions	of an exchange of losses.	6.746921879130105
2825. this exchange must result in our ending up	with some effective units.	4.280509275523906
2826. initially having fewer units of some elements-	especially submarines- than the opponent our capabilities need	to be sufficiently greater than theirs so that the exchange will	be in our favor.	4.942892431876948
2827. therefore the third principle of the plan must be that	it does not depend for effectiveness on engagement by the same types	unless at an assured favorable exchange rate.	3.8910197980600616
2828. the submarine	has increased its effectiveness by several orders of magnitude since	world war 2.	4.983240996215937
2829. its speed has increased it operates at increasingly	greater depths its submerged endurance is becoming unlimited and	it will become even more silent.	3.689511067769841
2830. the next developments will probably	be in weaponry.	6.757802316104118
2831. the missile can gradually be expected to replace the	torpedo.	4.57187747752113
2832. as detection ranges increase weapons will be developed to	attack other submarines and surface craft at these ranges.	5.511543313018439
2833. therefore	the fourth principle of the plan must be that it provide for continuously	increasing capabilities in the opponent.	4.13887205000663
2834. no element can accomplish	the total objective of submarine defense.	6.831689567118745
2835. some elements support	the others	but all have limitations.	5.411014586580643
2836. some limitations of one element	can be compensated for by a capability of another.	5.799208642707734
2837. elements used	in combination will increase the over-all capability more than the sum	of the capabilities of the individual elements.	4.451401458630323
2838. therefore the plan's	fifth principle must be that it capitalize on the capabilities of	all elements in combination.	5.577304145814093
2839. conceivably the submarine defense	problem can be solved by sufficient forces.	4.317068102383446
2840. numbers would be astronomical	and current fiscal policies make this an impractical solution.	5.583228874976599
2841. shipbuilding aircraft procurement and weapon programs indicate that	there will not be enough of anything.	4.358172054902242
2842. therefore any measures taken	in peacetime which will decrease force requirements in war will contribute	greatly to success when hostilities occur.	5.157932635070325
2843. therefore the sixth	principle of the plan must be that it concentrate on current measures	which will reduce future force requirements.	3.966396731292977
2844. the world is constantly	changing; what was new yesterday is obsolescent today.	6.624877928679237
2845. the	seventh principle of the plan is self-evident; it must be flexible enough	to allow for technological breakthroughs scientific progress and	changes in world conditions.	4.089665590825743
2846. to this point the need for an over-all plan for submarine defense	has been demonstrated the mission has been stated broad principles	delineating its content laid down and the supporting elements listed.	5.230818413892396
2847. before considering these elements in more detail an additional	requirement should be stated.	4.566798315352863

2849. therefore because reduction in tasks results in reduction	of forces required the plan should provide for expanding area coverage.	3.8163373800112947

2859. the ocean presently co-operates with the	target.	4.4846074056149545

2973. experiments carried out over long periods of time	in order to allow establishment of a steady state have shown that the	onset of contraction and its completion are confined to an interval of	several degrees centigrade and to a concentration range of only several	per cent.	3.316529322392553

2976. one of the principal aims of anionic polymerization techniques	is the synthesis of polymers of extremely narrow molecular weight	distribution.	5.834764045940301
2977. a simple process for the preparation of nearly monodisperse	polystyrene of predictable molecular weight has been developed.	3.71797660683748
2978. the preparation of such products is not new but the systems heretofore	employed in polymerizations have commanded considerable experimental	skill and starting materials of a high purity.	4.481675959529195
2979. in the new process	impurities present in the solvent the monomer and in the	reaction system which would cause deactivation of propagation centers	are rendered inactive prior to polymerization by gradual addition of	initiator a mixture of butyl-lithium and telomeric styryl-lithium at	a temperature low enough to suppress chain growth.	3.4731657907661275
2980. upon completion	of the purging step additional initiator appropriate for the molecular	weight of the sample desired is added and the system is then warmed	to the polymerization temperature at which the reaction is allowed	to go to completion.	4.769126312767803

3085. the groth institute	the groth institute	which was established in 1958 is a group activity affiliated	with the physics department of the pennsylvania state university	university park pa.	3.2613839151051423

3091. all crystalline	substances and other solid-state materials.	5.998790625931075
3092. the	aim is to collect a very broad range of physical chemical morphological	and structural data for crystals on an encyclopedic scale and to	seek all possible useful and revealing correlations of properties with	internal structure.	4.603859727107717
