3101. because individual classes of foods differ in their requirements	for preservation a number of methods have been developed over the years	involving one or a combination of procedures such as dehydration	fermentation salting chemical treatment canning refrigeration and	freezing.	3.89737168389572
3102. the basic objectives in each instance are to make available	supplies of food during the intervals between harvesting or slaughter	to minimize losses resulting from the action of microorganisms and	insects and to make it possible to transport foods from the area of	harvest or production to areas of consumption.	4.73107488237771
3103. in earlier years	the preservation of food was essentially related to survival.	4.372974062082154
3104. in	the more sophisticated atmosphere of today's developed nations food-preservation	techniques have sought also to bring variety peak freshness	and optimum taste and flavor in foods at reasonable cost to the	comsumer.	4.7333509329714545
3105. with the development of nuclear technology isotopic	materials and machine radiation sources in recent years the possibilities	of applying ionizing radiation to the preservation of foods attracted	the attention of investigators in the united states and throughout	the world.	4.250485872587822
3106. an early hope that irradiation might be the ultimate	answer to practically all food preservation problems was soon dispelled.	5.627786287036887
3107. interest remained however in the possibility that it would serve	as a useful supplementary method for counteracting spoilage losses	and for preserving some foods at lower over-all costs than freezing or	without employing heat or chemicals with their attendant taste alterations.	3.4279843379181387
3108. the chief	factors responsible for the spoilage of fresh foodstuffs are microorganisms	such as bacteria molds and yeasts insects	sprouting and chemical reactions.	4.890670422055402
3109. microorganisms are often	responsible for the rapid spoilage of foods.	4.574358047656773
3110. of special concern is	the growth of bacteria such as clostridium botulinum which generate	poisonous products.	6.101135284216327
3111. enzymatic action in stored food produces changes	which can adversely affect the appearance of food or its palatability.	3.846964104076588
3112. spoilage by chemical action results from the reaction of one group	of components in the food with others or with its environment as in	corrosion of the walls of metal containers or the reaction of fats with	oxygen in the air to produce rancidity.	4.6647336382461635
3113. sprouting is a naturally	occurring phenomenon in stored potatoes onions carrots beets	and similar root vegetables.	3.8849121559715263
3114. insect infestation is a problem of importance	chiefly in stored grain.	6.518614693353166
3115. the presence of parasitic organisms	such as trichinella spiralis in pork introduces another factor which	must be dealt with in food processing.	3.6263626275524823
3116. to permit the storage	of food for long periods of time a method of preservation must accomplish	the destruction of microorganisms and inhibition of enzymatic	action.	5.3905289144755955
3117. the term sterilization applies to methods involving essentially	complete destruction of all microorganisms.	3.809395861547629
3118. food treated in	this manner and protected from recontamination by aseptic methods of packaging	and containment presumably could be stored for long periods without	refrigeration.	5.001742336120245
3119. the process of pasteurization involves milder	and less prolonged heat treatment which accomplishes the destruction	of most but not all of the microorganisms.	4.1751470081943145
3120. less severe thermal	treatment as by blanching or scalding serves to inactivate enzymes.	6.037731258679057
3121. effects of ionizing radiation	ionizing radiation can cause	the destruction of microorganisms and insects involved in food spoilage	or at lower doses can inhibit their action.	3.4350960928305088
3122. it furnishes a means	of destroying insects in stored grain products as well as certain parasitic	organisms present in meats.	6.0952157432386835
3123. deactivation of enzymes is also	possible although some types require extremely heavy doses of 10 mrad	or more.	3.744109221929566
3124. because of undesirable flavors odors colors and generally	low palatability associated with radiation treatment of this magnitude	the inactivation of enzymes is best accomplished prior to irradiation	by the conventional heat-processing methods of blanching.	4.800609648913088
3125. radiation does not retard the chemical spoilage of food.	4.477601198394805
3126. it will	however inhibit the sprouting of potatoes and other root vegetables.	6.379957507003579
3127. the radiation doses required for the preservation of foods	are in the following ranges:  for radiosterilization to destroy	all organisms for long-term preservation- about 4.	3.5288892540801284
3128. 5 mrad for	nonacid foods of low salt content.	7.703185156653452
3129. for radiopasteurization	to partially destroy microorganisms; results vary with types of food	storage conditions and objectives of treatment- commonly of the	order of 0.	3.714556196189282
3130. 2 mrads but up to about 0.	8.688984421874535
3131. for	destruction of insects- about 25000 rads.	5.219666477665999
3132. for inhibiting	the sprouting of root vegetables- 4000 to 10000 rads.	6.380184945172053
3133. preserving foods with ionizing radiation leads to some undesirable side	effects particularly at the higher radiation dosages.	3.744109221929566
3134. in this respect	the general palatability and individual acceptance of most radiosterilized	foods has to date been found to be low in comparison with	fresh and commercially processed foods.	4.997247210885902
3135. a number of foods are quite	acceptable as regards taste and palatability however at dosages substantially	less than sterilization levels.	4.077733353902817
3136. moreover the nutritive value	of irradiated foods apparently undergoes little if any change although	some of the fat-soluble vitamins are affected by sterilization	doses.	5.197045842133396
3137. for irradiation of food the results	obtained depend upon the dose rather than the specific type of radiation	and x-ray gamma and high-energy electron radiation are suitable.	3.760806227569995
3138. aside from availability and economic considerations each has certain	practical advantages; for example gamma rays give deeper penetration	but cannot be focused or collimated whereas unidirectional electron	beams may be split and directed to both the top and bottom of the	food package to be irradiated.	4.647798736572662
3139. selection of a source for commercial irradiation	would involve consideration of numerous factors including required	dose rate load factor throughput convenience safety and most	important costs.	3.4350960928305088
3140. of the potentially useful sources of ionizing	radiations gamma sources cobalt-60 cesium-137 fission products	or a reactor irradiation loop system using a material such as an indium	salt have received most attention for food-preservation systems.	4.771840494244955
3141. of the various particle accelerators the van de graff machines resonant	transformers and linear accelerators are the principal ones available	for commercial use.	4.0458754183765855
3142. costs of the effective energy produced	by these sources is a major obstacle in the development of food-preservation	processes.	6.077467455091562
3143. estimated production costs of radiation energy	from machine and nuclide sources range from $1 to $10 per kwhr.	3.685338251241182
3144. conventional	energy for processing foods is available in the range of	at most a few cents per kwhr for electric power and the equivalent	of a few mills per kwhr for process steam.	4.760675194093627
3145. radiation therefore is	at an initial cost disadvantage even though only 1 to 10 per cent as	much radiation energy as heat energy is required for radiopasteurization	or radiosterilization.	3.591462690718159
3146. what are the possibilities of lowered radiation	production costs for the future?	7.392532263645993
3147.  it has been estimated that for	applications on a megawatt scale costs might reach values in the neighborhood	of 10 cents per kwhr for large-scale accelerators or for	gamma radiation generated in a reactor core.	3.5606746668881533
3148. no comparable reductions	in the cost of nuclide radiation are foreseen.	7.659734702791485
3149. such projections however	appear highly	speculative and the capacities involved are far beyond	those foreseen for food-preservation facilities.	4.160544595616035
3150. because agricultural	activities are seasonal and the areas of production and harvest	of many foods are widely scattered geographically and because of	the high cost of transporting bulk food items any substantial distance	to a central processing location the use of large central processing	stations where low-cost radiation facilities approaching the megawatt	range might be utilized is inherently impracticable.	4.643080804782696
3151. of irradiation preservation of foods	the objective of complete	sterilization of foods is to produce a wholesome and palatable product	capable of being stored without refrigeration for extended periods	of time.	3.6921048147323567
3152. chief interest in radiosterilization resides in the military	services.	6.934299865841975
3153. for them providing appetizing food under battle or emergency	conditions is a paramount consideration.	4.217123366535278
3154. they require completely	sterile foods capable of being stored without refrigeration preferably	items already cooked and ready to eat.	5.259879187274401
3155. high nutritional value variety	palatability and appetizing appearance are important for reasons	of morale.	4.466343726507149
3156. foods for rear stations which require cooking but no refrigeration	are also of interest.	5.495671946616734
3157. of primary interest are meats.	7.053807932700675
3158. radiopasteurization which produces fewer adverse sensory changes	in food products has potential usefulness in prolonging the keeping	qualities of fresh and refrigerated food items.	4.758972536424235
3159. thus food so processed	might reach more remote markets and permit the consumer to enjoy more	produce at peak freshness and palatability.	3.9377932674031597
3160. commercial interest is chiefly	in this type of treatment as is military interest under peacetime	conditions.	5.820796813416292
3161. the present status of food preservation by ionizing	radiation is discussed by food classes in the following paragraphs.	4.101453749095813
3162. the radiation processing of meat has received extensive	investigation.	5.8365087727519045
3163. to date the one meat showing favorable results at	sterilization doses is pork.	4.353362639586338
3164. of particular interest to the military	services is the demonstration that roast pork after radiosterilization	is superior in palatability to available canned pork products.	5.524476387641136
3165. tests	with beef have been largely unsuccessful because of the development	of off-flavors.	4.94289034871194
3166. a prime objective of the army quartermaster corps	program is to find the reasons for beef's low palatability and means	of overcoming it since it is a major and desirable dietary item.	6.120972101739742
3167. partly	because low-level heat treatment is needed to inactivate enzymes	before radiosterilization treated fresh meats have the appearance of	boiled or canned meat.	3.542415248362911
3168. off-flavor is a less severe problem with	the radiopasteurization of meats but problems of commercial acceptability	remain.	5.2288514545018705
3169. moderate radiation doses of from 100000 to 200000 rads	can extend the shelf life of fresh beef from 5 days	to 5 or 6 weeks.	3.4350960928305088
3170. however the problem of consumer acceptability remains.	10.229036253854472
3171. the preradiation blanching process discolors the treated beef	and liquid accumulates in prepackaged cuts.	3.6311862882065773
3172. cooked beef irradiated in	the absence of oxygen assumes an unnatural pink color.	5.583228874976599
3173. when lamb	and mutton are irradiated at substerilization doses the meat becomes	dehydrated the fat become chalky and again unnatural changes in	color occur.	3.716212850671366
3174. ground meats such as fresh pork sausage and hamburger	have a relatively short shelf life under refrigeration and radiopasteurization	might be thought to offer distinctly improved keeping	qualities.	4.726892725546913
3175. however a major problem here is one of scale of processing;	ground meats are usually prepared from scrap meats at the local	level whereas irradiation at economic volumes of production would require	central processing and distribution facilities.	3.627742455766138

3201. if a wedge-shaped coating of increasing thickness is removed from	a substrate by an instrument like the hesiometer with a knife of constant	rake angle a number of removal mechanisms are often observed	which depend upon the thickness of the coating.	3.632574623169823
3202. at low thicknesses a	cutting phenomenon is often encountered.	7.4256039461491135
3203. as the coating	becomes thicker the cutting may abruptly change to a cracking type of	failure.	4.392440692673179
3204. if the coating becomes still thicker a peeling type failure	finally can occur.	6.197852301026256
3205. the typical appearance of these various mechanisms	is illustrated in figs 2 3 and 4 which are single frame enlargements	of high speed movies taken during the course of the knife removal	process.	3.504853765033716
3206. it can be seen from fig 2 that the cutting removal	of a coating from its substrate involves pure cohesive failure of the	coating.	5.943657351968494
3207. the molecular forces holding the coating to the substrate are	obviously greater than the cohesive strength of the coating and	failure occurs by shear along a plane starting at the tip of the knife	and extending to the coating surface.	3.245106416046471
3208. the pictures of figs	3 and	4 show the cracking and peeling types of removal where the coating	is detached by failure in a region at or close to the interface between	coating and substrate.	4.573862664757355

3211. it can be seen that	the force is characteristic of the removal process and changes abruptly	from cutting to cracking to peeling removal.	4.6295786502489005
3212. also it can be readily	seen that the cutting and peeling types of failure show a steady state	response while the cracking mechanism is of a dynamic nature.	5.2865638621510875
3213. it should be recalled that these three mechanisms can occur on the	same coating deposited upon the same substrate merely as a function of	changes in coatings thickness.	4.032910876181826

3358. at this point the drains are readjusted so	that the suds box drain will discharge directly into the waste line	and the main tub drain is set at the 2-12 mark on the drain gauge.	4.873937263656402

3360. the	run is complete when all the water has drained off into the waste line.	6.048852170511314

3437. high-gain photoelectronic image intensification is applied under	conditions of low incident light levels whenever the integration time	required by a sensor or recording instrument exceeds the limits of	practicability.	3.3515864650355898
3438. examples of such situations are night reconnaissance	the recording of radioactive tracers in live body tissues	special radiography in medical or industrial applications track recording	of high energy particles etc.	4.566786271575569
3439. high-gain photoelectronic	image intensification may be achieved by several methods; some of	cascading single stages by coupling	lens systems	image intensifier based upon the multipactor	transmission secondary electron multiplication	cascading of single	stages enclosed in one common envelope.	3.3150269316597085
3440. cascading single stages	by coupling lens systems is rather inefficient as the lens systems	limit the obtainable gain quite severely.	4.985333447698777
3441. channel-type image intensifiers	are capable of achieving high-gain values; suffer however	from an inherently low resolution.	3.8849121559715263
3442. image intensifiers based upon	the multipactor principle appear to hold promise as far as obtainable	resolution is concerned.	5.742551335066376
3443. however the unavoidable low-duty cycle restricts	the effective gain.	5.730525374321069
3444. tsem tubes have been constructed showing	high gain and resolution.	6.144814417540349
3445. however electrostatic focus important	for many applications has not been realized for these devices.	4.795670060030977
3446. resolution	limitations with electrostatic focus might be anticipated due to	chromatic aberrations.	5.9245075971793435
3447. furthermore the thin film dynodes appear to	have a natural diameter limitation wherever a mesh support cannot be	tolerated.	3.899646889934861
3448. cascaded single stages enclosed by a common envelope	have been constructed with high gain and high resolution.	5.254645499078215
3449. these	tubes may differ both in the choice of the electron optical system	and in the design of the coupling members.	4.339222921423539
3450. the electron optical system	may be either a magnetic or electrostatic one.	5.187735111958531
3451. the magnification	may be smaller equal or larger than unity.	3.9843222565600884
3452. an electrostatic	system suffers generally from image plane curvature leading to defocusing	in the peripheral image region if a flat viewing screen	is utilized while a magnetic system requires accurate	adjustment of the solenoid which is heavy and bulky.	4.489992563236836

3464. the electron optical system is	based in principle on the focusing action of concentric spherical cathode	and anode surfaces.	4.705010556909502

3531. the set of all decisions is called the operating policy or more simply	the policy.	3.6408628380888155
3532. an optimal policy is one which in some sense gets the	best out of the process as a whole by maximizing the value of the product.	6.449917899477667
3533. there are thus three components to an optimal design problem:	the specification of the operating variables and the transformation	the specification of the objective function	of which the optimization is desired.	3.507288811837616
3534. for a chemical process	the	first of these might involve the concentrations of the different chemical	species and the temperature or pressure of the stream.	5.458012926091542
3535. for the	second we might have to choose the volume of reactor or amount of cooling	to be supplied; the way in which the transformation of state depends	on the operating variables for the main types of reactors is discussed	in the next chapter.	3.7196396195221832
3536. the objective function is some measure of	the increase in value of the stream by processing; it is the subject	of chapter 4.	5.53153334789869
3537. the essential characteristic of an optimal policy	when the state of the stream is transformed in a sequence of stages	with no feedback was first isolated by bellman.	3.536317746945316
3538. he recognized that	whatever transformation may be effected in the first stage of an r-stage	process the remaining stages must use an optimal f-stage policy	with respect to the state resulting from the first stage if there	is to be any chance of optimizing the complete process.	5.078708287329782
3539. moreover by	systematically varying the operating conditions in the first stage and	always using the optimal f-stage policy for the remaining stages	we shall eventually find the optimal policy for all r stages.	3.712882145490841
3540. proceeding	in this way from one to two and from two to three stages we	may gradually build up the policy for any number.	5.2419729127195005
3541. at each step of the	calculation the operating variables of only one stage need be varied.	4.395967828843386
3542. to see how important this economy is let us suppose that there	are m operating variables at each stage and that the state	is specified by n variables; then the search for the maximum	at any one stage will require a number of operations of order f	.	5.273606336026359
3543. to proceed from	one stage to the next a sufficient number of feed states must be investigated	to allow of interpolation; this number will be of the order	of f.	3.811512230080725
3544. if however we are seeking the optimal r-stage policy	for a given feed state only one search for a maximum is required at	the final step.	5.060029301245277
3545. thus a number of operations of the order of f are	required.	6.798192742705066
3546. if all the operating variables were varied simultaneously	f operations would be required to do the same job and as r	increases this increases very much more rapidly than the number of operations	required by the dynamic program.	5.336618449926797
3547. but even more important than	this is the fact that the direct search by simultaneously varying all	operating conditions has produced only one optimal policy namely that	for the given feed state and r stages.	3.889331777450906

3554. bellman has annunciated in the	following terms:   an optimal policy has the property that	whatever the initial state and initial decision are the remaining decisions	must constitute an optimal policy with respect to the state resulting	from the first decision.	4.737418827790316
3555. this is the principle which	we will invoke in every case to set up a functional equation.	5.00589709583759

3609. a gyro-stabilized platform system using restrained gyros is	well suited for automatic leveling because of the characteristics of the	gyro-platform-servo combination.	3.9739748771773598

3627. with these factors included an upper	limit is placed on the allowable loop gain by stability considerations.	4.577165875761653
3628. in this type of system a high loop gain is desirable because it	provides a fast response time.	6.016850636441393
3629. when the frequency response characteristics	of practical components are considered their effect on	stability does not present the most serious limit on the system loop	gain.	3.721670715968107
3630. the time required for the system to reach a level position is approximately	inversely proportional to the servo loop gain.	4.974450989879804

3632. this problem	usually determines the lower limit of loop gain rather than response	time.	5.705664484268808
3633. it must be noticed in fig 7-1 that the accelerometer	responds to any input acceleration.	4.760933968751193
3634. the equation relating input	acceleration to output platform angle is f in practice the preflight	leveling process takes place with the system mounted in the airframe.	4.426289510158595
3635. when the system is arranged for automatic leveling the platform	angles respond to any horizontal components of acceleration acting on	the accelerometers.	4.110702197051016
3636. there are many such components of acceleration present	due to the effect of wind gusts engine noise turbulence around	the vehicle etc.	6.055124557939788
3637. one of the greatest problems associated with automatic	leveling is establishing a true level in the presence of high-level	acceleration noise.	4.914265442217263
3638. one solution to the problem is to operate	with a low loop gain and to include low-pass filters.	6.7462186262462245
3639. this technique	causes the system to respond only to low frequency acceleration components	such as the platform tilt.	3.80965061478659
3640. since a lower loop gain and low-pass filtering	increases the response time a practical compromise must be reached.	5.498742261129303
3641. one of the most desirable solutions is achieved by the	use of a non-linear amplifier for f.	4.5747471951267435
3642. the amplifier is designed so	that its gain is large for accelerometer signals above a certain threshold	level.	4.762804453309085
3643. below this level the amplifier gain f is proportional	and is of small value in order to provide adequate noise filtering.	4.145688631956537
3644. the	effect is that the platform returns from an off-level position at	a rapid rate until it is nearly level at which point the platform is	controlled by a proportional servo with low enough frequency response	so that the noise has little effect on the leveling process.	4.674683714819685
3645. when	the system is on automatic leveling the gyro drift is canceled by	the output of the leveling system.	3.8435090052941394
3646. the platform actually	tilts off level so that the accelerometer output when amplified	by f will supply the correct current to the gyro torquer to cancel	the gyro drift.	4.728665728345589
3647. the amount of platform dip required depends upon the	scale factors of the system.	4.225829768834559

3665. platform	heading consists of orienting the sensitive axis of the accelerometers	parallel to the desired coordinate system of the navigator.	3.730051849018153

3669. with the gyro-stabilized platform leveled it can be	headed in the proper direction by using surveying techniques.	4.273653874202895
3670. the platform	accelerometers must be slightly modified for this procedure.	5.504585613369078
